**Deuce FinCo plc**


**€300,000,000 Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes due 2027**


**£645,000,000  % Senior Secured Notes due 2027**

Deuce FinCo plc (the “Issuer”), a public limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, is offering €300,000,000 senior secured floating rate notes
due 2027 (the “Euro Notes”) and £645,000,000  % senior secured notes due 2027 (the “Sterling Notes” and, together with the Euro Notes, the “Notes”) (the “Offering”).
The Issuer is a wholly owned finance subsidiary of Deuce MidCo Limited (the “Company”), a private limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales.
The proceeds of the Notes, together with the proceeds from certain other equity financing transactions described herein, will be used (i) to repay existing indebtedness,
(ii) for general corporate purposes, including working capital requirements, capital expenditures and strategic acquisitions, and (iii) to pay fees and expenses incurred in
connection with the Transactions (as defined herein). See “Use of proceeds.”


The Notes will be issued on , 2021 (the “Issue Date”). The Euro Notes will bear interest at a rate equal to three-month EURIBOR (with a 0% floor), plus   % per
annum, reset quarterly. The Sterling Notes will bear interest at a rate of  % per annum. The Issuer will pay interest on the Euro Notes quarterly in arrears on  ,  ,
and   of each year, commencing on , 2021. The Issuer will pay interest on the Sterling Notes semi-annually in arrears on   and   of each year, commencing on ,
2021. The Notes will mature on , 2027.

The Issuer may redeem some or all of the Sterling Notes on or after , 2023 at the redemption prices set forth in this preliminary offering memorandum (the “Offering
_Memorandum”), plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. Prior to , 2023, the Issuer may redeem some or all of the Sterling_
Notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Sterling Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption,
plus the applicable “make-whole” premium, as described in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, prior to , 2023, the Issuer may redeem up to 40% of the Sterling
Notes (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Sterling Notes issued) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at the redemption prices
set forth in this Offering Memorandum, plus accrued but unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption, provided that at least 50% of the original
principal amount of the Sterling Notes (not including any additional Sterling Notes issued) remains outstanding. Prior to , 2023, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of
the aggregate principal amount of the Sterling Notes originally issued (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Sterling Notes issued) in each twelvemonth period commencing on the Issue Date at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but
excluding, the date of redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Optional redemption—Optional redemption of the Sterling Notes.”

The Issuer may redeem some or all of the Euro Notes on or after , 2022 at the redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum, plus accrued and unpaid interest,
if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. Prior to , 2022, the Issuer may redeem some or all of the Euro Notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount
of the Euro Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption, plus the applicable “make-whole” premium, as described
in this Offering Memorandum. See “Description of the Notes—Optional redemption—Optional redemption of the Euro Notes.”

Additionally, upon the occurrence of certain change of control events, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to redeem the Notes at a price equal to 101% of the
principal amount redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have
occurred if certain consolidated leverage ratios are not exceeded in connection with such an event. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may
elect to redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to,
but excluding, the date of redemption. See “Description of the Notes.”

On the Issue Date, the Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer, rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness
that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, senior to all existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is subordinated in right of payment to the Notes
and effectively senior to all existing and future unsecured indebtedness of the Issuer to the extent of the assets securing the Notes. No later than two business days from
the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein), the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Company, David Lloyd Leisure
Limited, David Lloyd Leisure GR Limited, David Lloyd Clubs Limited, Deuce Acquisitions Limited, David Lloyd Leisure Operations Holdings Limited, David Lloyd
Leisure Group Limited, David Lloyd Clubs Holdings Limited and David Lloyd Leisure Properties No. 3 Limited (together, the “Guarantors,” and, such guarantees, the
“Guarantees”). The Guarantors and the Issuer will also guarantee the obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors under the New Revolving Facilities Agreement (as
defined herein), any Hedging Obligations (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein)) and any Operating Facility (as defined in the Intercreditor
Agreement). See “Description of the Notes—Note Guarantees.” The Guarantees of the Notes by each Guarantor will rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the
existing and future indebtedness of such Guarantor that is not subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantor’s Guarantee, senior to all existing and future indebtedness
of such Guarantor that is subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantor’s Guarantee and effectively senior to all existing and future unsecured indebtedness of such
Guarantor to the extent of the assets securing the Guarantor’s Guarantee. No later than the Issue Date, subject to the release of the guarantees and security securing the
Group's existing financing arrangements and to the Agreed Security Principles and certain applicable perfection requirements, the Notes and the Guarantees will be
secured by a limited recourse English law share charge over all shares in the Company and an English law security assignment over any structural intercompany loans
from Deuce ParentCo Limited to the Company (the “Closing Date Collateral”). No later than two business days from the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security
Principles and certain applicable perfection requirements, the Notes and the Guarantees will be secured by an English law debenture over certain material assets of the
Issuer and the Guarantors that are incorporated in England, including first fixed equitable security over any leasehold interests other than any leasehold interest that has
35 years or less to run, subject to receipt of landlord consent (if required) (the “Post Closing Date Collateral” and together with the Closing Date Collateral, the
“Collateral”). See “Description of the Notes—Security—The Collateral.” The Collateral will also secure the obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors under the New
Revolving Facilities Agreement, any Hedging Obligations and any Operating Facility. Pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, any liabilities in respect of
the New Revolving Facilities Agreement and any Hedging Obligations (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) that are secured by the Collateral will receive priority
with respect to any proceeds received upon any enforcement action over such Collateral.

The Guarantees and the security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the security
and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain significant limitations as described in “Risk factors—Risks related to our financial
_profile, the Notes and the Guarantees—The Notes will be secured only to the extent of the value of the Collateral that will have been granted as security for the Notes and_
_the Guarantees, and such security may not be sufficient to satisfy the obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.” Subject to the terms of the Indenture, the New_
Revolving Facilities Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement, the Collateral may be pledged to secure future indebtedness. This Offering Memorandum includes more
detailed information on the terms of the Notes and the Guarantees, including redemption and repurchase prices, security, covenants, events of default and transfer
restrictions.

**Financial statements presented**

**_Financial information of the Issuer and the Company_**

The Issuer is a newly formed entity incorporated on May 6, 2021 for purposes of facilitating

the Transactions and performing certain activities related thereto. The Issuer is a wholly owned
direct subsidiary of the Company. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer has no
revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business operations, material assets or liabilities
other than those acquired or incurred in connection with its incorporation and the Transactions. As
a result, no historical financial information of the Issuer is included in this Offering Memorandum.

The Company was incorporated on May 18, 2018 as a holding company. The Company is

indirectly owned by Deuce Holdco Limited (“HoldCo”). As of the date of this Offering
Memorandum, the Company has no revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business
operations, material assets or liabilities other than (i) certain existing indebtedness which will be
repaid with the proceeds of the Transactions (see “Use of proceeds”) and (ii) a £2.0 million annual
monitoring fee payable to TDR Capital. As a result, no historical financial information of the
Company is included in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Historical Financial Information of Holdco_**

The consolidated historical and other financial data presented in this Offering

Memorandum have been derived from (i) the audited consolidated financial statements of HoldCo
as of and for the period from January 4, 2018 to December 31, 2018 and as of and for the years
ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, including the accompanying notes thereto, which have been
prepared in accordance with IFRS and which have been audited by Deloitte LLP and (ii) the
unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of HoldCo as of and for the three
months ended March 31, 2021, including accompanying notes thereto (with comparable financial
information for the three months ended March 31, 2020), which have been prepared in accordance
with IAS 34 Interim Financial Reporting, in each case included elsewhere in this Offering
Memorandum. References to the “Group,” “us” or “our” in the context of historical financial
information or other financial information relate to HoldCo and its subsidiaries. The audit reports
for the period from January 4, 2018 to December 31, 2018 and as of and for the years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, express an
unqualified opinion for each of the respective periods and the audit report in relation to the audited
consolidated financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 include a
material uncertainty paragraph related to going concern as set forth in Note 2 to such financial
statements.

IFRS 16 (Leases) was published on January 13, 2016 by the International Accounting

Standard Board. It became effective on January 1, 2019 and applies to the first full financial year
commencing on or after that date. Our first full financial year following the effective date of IFRS
16 began on January 1, 2019, and we applied the modified retrospective approach of adopting the
new standard, which did not require a restatement of comparative results for the financial period


-----

ended December 31, 2018. On adoption of IFRS 16, the Group recognized lease liabilities in
relation to leases which had previously been classified as “operating leases” under the principles
of IAS 17. These liabilities were measured at the present value of the remaining lease payments,
discounted using the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate as of January 1, 2019. The weighted
average lessee’s incremental borrowing rate applied to the lease liabilities on January 1, 2019 was
6.8%. For leases previously classified as “finance leases,” the carrying amount of the lease asset
and lease liability immediately before transition were recognized as the carrying amount of the
right-of-use asset and the lease liability at the date of initial application. For more information on
the adoption of IFRS 16 and the adjustments made in relation thereto, see “Management’s
_discussion and analysis of financial conditions and results of operations—Factors affecting_
_comparability of our results of operations—Adoption of IFRS 16” and Note 33 to the HoldCo_
consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2019.

During the year ended December 31, 2020, we identified that both deferred tax asset

balances and reserves had been understated by £21 million as of December 31, 2019. As a result,
we have restated the consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2019. As
mentioned above, the Group adopted IFRS 16 Leases retrospectively with the cumulative effect of
its application being recognized as of January 1, 2019, but did not restate comparatives for the
2018 reporting period, as permitted under the specific transition provisions in the standard. The
adjustments arising from the new leasing rules were therefore recognized in the opening balance
sheet on January 1, 2019. There were no errors related to the adoption of IFRS 16 itself. The error
was restricted to the deferred tax calculation. The misstatement of the deferred tax balances related
to the complexities of the adoption of IFRS 16 Leases retrospectively from January 1, 2019. There
is no impact on the consolidated income statement for the year ended December 31, 2019 and the
effect on the consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2019 was to increase
the opening January 1, 2019 deferred tax assets by £21 million and to reduce accumulated losses
as of January 1, 2019 by £21 million.

In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain financial and other operating data as of

and for the year ended December 31, 2019. In addition to its usefulness as regards our historical
performance, this data represents the ordinary course operations of our business in a steady state,
before the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. We have also presented the historical financial and
other operating data as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the three months ended
March 31, 2021, which represents the impact on our business of the COVID-19 pandemic as the
majority of our clubs were closed during the First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown (each as
defined herein).

Our consolidated financial statements include the results of operations and financial

position of HoldCo, which are not attributable to the Company or its subsidiaries. As a result, the
consolidated financial statements of HoldCo are not directly comparable to the historical financial
information of the Company and its subsidiaries, which is prepared in accordance with IFRS. The
main differences between the consolidated financial position and results of operations of HoldCo
and the Company (i) as of and for the period from January 4, 2018 to December 31, 2018, related
to interest income in relation to shareholder loans from HoldCo to its direct and indirect
shareholders and cash on balance sheet held under HoldCo’s name, which amounted to £2.3
million and £1.0 million, respectively, and a shareholder loan from HoldCo to the Company which
amounted to £5.9 million; (ii) as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, related to the


-----

balance of a shareholder loan from HoldCo to its shareholder and cash on balance sheet held under
HoldCo’s name, which amounted to £2.1 million and £1.5 million, respectively, and £0.2 million
additional finance cost incurred by the Company in relation to interest paid on a £5.3 million
shareholder loan from HoldCo to the Company; (iii) as of and for the year ended December 31,
2020, related to the balance of a shareholder loan from HoldCo to its shareholder and cash on
balance sheet held under HoldCo’s name, which amounted to £2.2 million and £1.4 million,

**Non-IFRS measures**

We have included certain non-IFRS financial measures in this Offering Memorandum.

Non-IFRS financial measures are derived on the basis of methodologies other than IFRS and the
non-IFRS measures we present may also be defined differently than the corresponding terms under
the Indenture. We present the following non-IFRS financial measures in this Offering
Memorandum:


-----

- “Adjusted EBITDA” represents loss for the financial year, before net finance cost, income
tax (credit)/charge on ordinary activities and depreciation and amortization and further
adjusted for long-term incentive plan charges and non-recurring redundancies, profit/(loss)
on disposal of property, plant and equipment, pre-opening costs, monitoring fees –
managerial advice, non-executive director fees, closed club costs, acquisition and aborted
expenses, insurance proceeds from damage to property, plant and equipment, IFRS 16
transition and other diligence costs, foreign exchange difference, utilization of onerous
lease provision, non-cash rent accrual (excluding lease incentive accrual), share of loss of
equity accounted investments, exceptional and other non-recurring items including
impairment of property, plant and equipment, impairment of right-of-use assets,
impairment of intangible assets, cost of lease re-negotiations, business restructuring,
refinancing transaction and acquisition related costs, impairment of investment, India joint
venture losses, onerous lease provision charge and release of legal provision and includes
all rental payments in respect of finance leases and rent expense (replaced with depreciation
and interest under IFRS 16).

- “Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is calculated by dividing Adjusted EBITDA for a period by
the revenue for such period.

- “Adjusted EBITDAR” represents Adjusted EBITDA for a period before rental payments in
respect of finance leases for such period.

- “Cash Conversion Ratio” is calculated by subtracting Maintenance Capital Expenditure
and change in net working capital for a period from Adjusted EBITDA for such period and
dividing the result thereof by Adjusted EBITDA for such period.

- “Free Cash Flow Post-Exceptional Items” represents Adjusted EBITDA for a period, less
Maintenance Capital Expenditure for such period, adjusted for the change in net working
capital, less Investment Capital Expenditure, Pipeline Capital Expenditure, business
restructuring costs and refinancing transaction and acquisition related costs for such period.

- “Investment Capital Expenditure” is the discretionary spend comprising refurbishment
works and club upgrades that improve an existing club’s offering. See “Management’s
_discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations—Capital_
_expenditures.”_

- “Like-for-like ancillary revenue” represents the ancillary revenue of our Legacy 90
Portfolio;

- “Like-for-like average monthly yield” represents the average monthly yield of our Legacy
90 Portfolio;

- “Like-for-like EBITDA” represents the Adjusted EBITDA of our Legacy 90 Portfolio;

- “Like-for-like membership base” represents the membership base of our Legacy 90
Portfolio;


-----

- “Like-for-like _membership_ _subscriptions_ _revenue”_ represents the membership

subscriptions revenue of our Legacy 90 Portfolio;

- “Like-for-like operating cash” represents the operating cash of our Legacy 90 Portfolio;

- “Like-for-like rent costs” represents the rent costs of our Legacy 90 Portfolio;

- “Like-for-like revenue” represents the revenue of our Legacy 90 Portfolio;

- “Like-for-like yield” represents the average monthly yield of our Legacy 90 Portfolio;

- “Maintenance Capital Expenditure” is our spend required to keep our facilities at a high
standard and to support our back-office services, such as IT and networking services. See
“Management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations—
_Capital expenditures.”_

- “Net debt” represents our current and non-current loans and borrowings less our cash and
cash equivalents as of a certain date.

- “Pipeline Capital Expenditure” is the discretionary spend relating to the expansion of our
facilities through the development or acquisition of new sites. See “Management’s
_discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations—Capital_
_expenditures.”_

- “Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA” represents Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended
December 31, 2019 further adjusted for (i) the annualized effect of our blended price rises
implemented in January 2020, cost inflation, additional rent costs following our sale and
lease back transactions completed in the second half of 2019 and in December 2020, the
impact of rent negotiations and our estimate of the full period impact of costs savings
resulting from our Fit For Growth Program implemented in December 2020 and (ii) the
standalone EBITDA of the Meridian Group for the year ended December 31, 2019, which
we acquired in January 2020, adjusted for our estimate of the expected increase in EBITDA
following our extensive refurbishment works and improvements of the Meridian clubs
bringing club quality and offering in line with our estate (which contributes to yield and
volume gains) and our estimate of the full period impact of expected head office and head
count cost savings as a result of synergies between the Group and the Meridian Group and
management initiatives, including quasi-proprietary pricing and promotional techniques
used to drive new membership sales, as well as data science used to reduce attrition rates.
_Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA is not adjusted for the closure of two non-_
performing clubs in Dordrecht in December 2020 and in Solihull in January 2021, which
had a negative aggregate Adjusted EBITDA of £0.3 million for the year ended December
31, 2019.

- “Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is calculated by dividing Pro Forma Run
Rate Adjusted EBITDA for a period by the Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue for such period.


-----

  - “Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue” represents revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019
adjusted for (i) the annualized effect of our blended price rises implemented in January
2020 and (ii) the standalone revenue of the Meridian Group for the year ended December
31, 2019, which we acquired in January 2020, adjusted for our estimate of the expected
increase in revenue following our extensive refurbishment works and improvements of the
Meridian clubs bringing club quality and offering in line with our estate (which contributes
to yield and volume gains) and our estimate of the full period impact of expected
management initiatives, including quasi-proprietary pricing and promotional techniques
used to drive new membership sales, as well as data science used to reduce attrition rates.
_Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue is not adjusted for the closure of two non-performing clubs_
in Dordrecht in December 2020 and in Solihull in January 2021, which had an aggregate
revenue of £2.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019.

We present a reconciliation of the non-IFRS measures to the most directly comparable

measure calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS under “Summary historical
_consolidated financial and other data.”_

Our management uses Adjusted EBITDA, Cash Conversion Ratio, Pro Forma Run Rate

Adjusted EBITDA and _Pro Forma_ Run Rate Revenue to assess our operating performance.
Adjusted EBITDA is considered the key measure of profitability. It is considered by management
to be the supplemental measure to understand the underlying trading and financial performance of
our business and is the measure used to report to both the board and external lenders. In addition,
we believe these metrics are measures that are useful to investors. Adjusted EBITDA, Cash
Conversion Ratio, Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue are
not presentations made in accordance with IFRS, and our use of such terms varies from others in
our industry. These metrics should not be considered as alternatives to revenue, profit/(loss),
operating profit/(loss) or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS as
measures of operating performance or operating cash flows as measures of liquidity. In addition,
Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA may be defined differently from
the definition of “Consolidated EBITDA” under the Indenture. Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma
Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA have important limitations as analytical tools and you should not
consider them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our results as reported under IFRS. For
example, Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA:

  - exclude certain tax payments that may represent a reduction in cash available to us;

  - do not reflect any capital expenditure;

  - do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

  - do not reflect the significant financial expense, or the cash requirements necessary to
service interest payments, on our debts;

  - adjust for items of which we believe the quantum, nature or volatility would distort the
underlying trading performance of the Group, as they are not expected to repeat in future
periods, including the tax effect thereof; and


-----

  - in the case of Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted
EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue, do not reflect the impact on our
results of operation of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Because of these limitations, our non-IFRS measures should not be considered as measures

of discretionary cash available to us in order to invest in the growth of our business or as measures
of cash that will be available to us in order to meet our obligations. You should compensate for
these limitations by relying primarily on our IFRS results and using these non-IFRS measures only
in a supplemental manner to evaluate our performance. Such non-IFRS financial information has
not been audited or reviewed by Deloitte LLP.

Key performance indicators and the other non-financial operational data included in this

Offering Memorandum are not part of our financial statements and have not been audited or
reviewed. Our use or computation of these indicators may not be comparable with the use or

**Overview**

We are the leading premium lifestyle club operator in Europe based on revenue for the year

ended December 31, 2019. On a pro forma run-rate adjusted basis, pre-COVID-19 pandemic, we
had approximately 668 thousand members as of December 31, 2019. As of March 31, 2021 we
operated 99 clubs in the U.K., one club in the Republic of Ireland and 22 clubs in continental
Europe. Our mission is to provide high-quality destinations suitable for the whole family and all
age ranges with an emphasis on the quality of our offering and expert delivery of multiple products
and services, creating a sense of belonging and improving our members’ lives. Our clubs are places
for me-time, together-time, work, rest and play-time under one roof, improving the lives of our
members and providing a home away from home under our “My Club for My Life” ethos.

We differentiate ourselves from our competitors by blending our distinguished social

offerings with our market-leading sports and leisure facilities and fitness offerings, allowing us to


-----

cultivate a loyal and “sticky” membership base. Our club rooms and outdoor spaces encourage
member interaction and provide a social, destination environment where members can relax and
socialize in a vibrant setting. The breadth and quality of our offering allows us to attract and retain
members of all ages, including families and older demographics, whom we believe are more likely
to become long-term members because our clubs become an integral part of their lives. We believe
our distinctive family focus, with programs and services catered to the whole family, enhances
member engagement, promotes membership retention and differentiates us from our competitors.
We believe that we have maintained markedly lower attrition rates than our peers, with a prepandemic attrition rate of 32.6% for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to up to
approximately 100% reported by certain low cost operators pre-pandemic (Source: public
_information), and the average membership tenure for our long-term members (i.e. those who had_
their membership for over 18 months) was seven years and our long-term members represented
63% of our member base, in each case, as of February 29, 2020 (excluding our Meridian clubs).
Based on the aggregate monthly membership fees paid by our long-term members for the month
February 2020, our aggregate implied recurring revenue over the seven year tenure would have
been approximately £1.9 billion. Our total membership subscription revenue, including joining
fees and administration fees, represented 78.2% of our total revenue for the year ended December
31, 2019. Our retail revenue generated by services such as our food and beverage offering,
childcare services and wellness products and our other revenue generated primarily by personal
training sessions and swimming and tennis tuition produce significant ancillary revenue and
represented 10.2% and 11.6%, respectively, of our total revenue in the year ended December 31,
2019.

Our business model focuses on operating a portfolio of strategically located clubs in

suburban areas, with each site situated in close proximity to an affluent demographic population.
Our clubs are well-invested and include heated indoor and outdoor pools, top-class racquet
facilities, well-equipped group exercise studios, state-of-the-art gyms, luxurious spas, crèches,
family-oriented club rooms and outdoor spaces, lounges with restaurants and bars as well as a fully
complementary digital offering, thereby delivering an outstanding customer experience to our
members. In addition, the range and breadth of services offered by our clubs results in longer
customer dwell-time, increased secondary spending, higher market penetration and improved
retention rates compared to our competitors.

While we operate mainly in the U.K., with 99 of our clubs located in the U.K. as of March

31, 2021, we see significant growth potential in Europe. Our recent acquisition of the eight
Meridian Group clubs in Germany has increased our penetration significantly into one of the most
important European markets. We expect to continue to consider additional international sites
through selective, value-enhancing strategic acquisitions of small portfolios as well as standalone
sites in Europe, in line with our overall growth plan. We believe that there are currently no
European competitors of significant scale in the premium health and fitness market segment, which
presents us an opportunity to capture additional market share through organic growth and
opportunistic acquisitions. The map below illustrates the location of our clubs:


-----

For the year ended December 31, 2019, we generated £519.5 million of revenue, a loss of

£51.5 million and £577.4 million of Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue with a Pro Forma Run Rate
Adjusted EBITDA of £170.9 million and Cash Conversion Ratio of 72.9%. We increased _Pro_
_Forma Run Rate Revenue, Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA and actual operating cash at_
a compound annual growth rate (“CAGR”) of 14.8%, 28.0% and 27.2%, respectively, from the
financial year ended January 3, 2016 to December 31, 2019.

**Our strengths**

**_Leading player in structurally attractive and growing U.K. and European health and fitness_**
**_club market with further growth expected post the COVID-19 pandemic_**

We are the leading premium lifestyle club operator in Europe based on revenue for the year

ended December 31, 2019, with 99 clubs in the U.K., one club in the RoI and 22 clubs in
continental Europe. The U.K. and European health and fitness club market in which we operate is
large and growing. We believe that this market is structurally attractive, particularly as the world
emerges from the COVID-19 pandemic. The total value of the U.K. health and fitness club market
increased from £4.3 billion as of December 2015 to £5.1 billion as of December 2019, reflecting
a CAGR of 4.4% (Source: LDC Report). Over this same period, the number of U.K. health and
fitness clubs grew from 6,312 to 7,239, reflecting a CAGR of 3.5%, while the number of health
and fitness club members grew from 8.8 million to 10.4 million, reflecting a CAGR of 4.3%
(Source: LDC Report). As of December 2019, 16% of the U.K. population, or approximately one
in six people, were a member of a health and fitness club (Source: LDC Report) and 11%, or
approximately one in ten people, were a member of a private health and fitness club. The total
value of the European health and fitness club market increased from €24.6 billion as of December
2015 to €26.2 billion as of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 1.6% (Source: Statista). Over
this same period, the number of health and fitness clubs in Europe grew from 51,204 to 63,644,
reflecting a CAGR of 5.6%.

We believe that growth in the U.K. and European health and fitness club market, including

a growth in penetration rates, is largely attributable to the increasing focus of consumers on health
and wellbeing and a growing awareness of the significant benefits of a healthy lifestyle. These


-----

same consumers also increasingly view health and fitness as an essential rather than discretionary
expenditure. Modest population growth, increases in consumers’ disposable incomes and
innovation and new technology in fitness may also have driven growth of the U.K. and European
health and fitness club markets over the past five years. We anticipate that demand for health and
fitness clubs will accelerate post-pandemic as the COVID-19 pandemic has reinforced the benefits
of a healthy lifestyle.

We believe the COVID-19 pandemic is shaping trends that will benefit our industry over

the mid-term. With more people working from home, our members have greater flexibility to
spend more time at our clubs, which are predominantly located in suburban areas. According to
Barclays’ research, post-pandemic, white collar employees in the U.K. expect working from home
days to increase by 60% (to 1.6 days per week on average), while employers in the U.K. expect
working from home days to double (to 2.0 days per week on average) (Source: Barclays Research
_Work from Home: A Global Revolution Special Report). We believe that this trend is further_
supported by a long-term shift to experiential spend by our target demographics, with 35% of
people in the U.K. with no prior gym membership surveyed during April 2020 reporting that they
would consider buying a membership following the uplifting of COVID-19 restrictions, according
to research conducted by UKactive.

Our expectations for growth in the U.K. and European health and fitness club market post
pandemic present an opportunity for our business. As a result of market growth and recent healthfocused trends, we anticipate more members being able to join and spend time at our clubs.

**_A broad and highly differentiated offering that makes us more than just a gym which is_**
**_unmatched by any scale competitor_**

We offer our members a distinguished selection of facilities and services which we believe

are unrivalled in breadth and quality. In particular, we differentiate ourselves from our competitors
by blending our social and wellness offerings with our market-leading sports and fitness facilities,
thus cultivating a loyal and “sticky” membership base.

_Our social offering_

Our “clubiness” is a key to driving our social offering. We want our members to feel they

belong to their club rather than visiting solely for exercise and our vibrant club rooms and social
outdoor spaces are a key component of our offering which provide members with a destination
environment where they can relax and interact with each other. We pride ourselves upon our local,
and often member self-started, societies among our clubs, which build loyal communities centered
around common interests and create a distinctive “clubs with clubs” culture. We also organize
various bespoke social events to drive member engagement and retention, all of which are tailored
to meet the specific needs of our members. In addition, several of our training options, such as
tennis leagues and running and triathlon clubs, feature a strong social element to encourage
participation via group coaching and friendly competitions. Most of our clubs have lounges with
a restaurant service and licensed bar, which represents our largest source of ancillary revenue
(47.5% of ancillary revenue (including retail and other revenue) in the year ended December 31,
2019). Many of our outdoor pool areas also have a barbecue or other food and beverage service,
thereby creating a destination area in the summer months. We regularly update our menus in


-----

response to member feedback to maximize the appeal of our food and beverage offering and stay
in touch with our customers’ preferences.

Our clubs are open to all ages and have a distinctive family focus, with families and couples

representing approximately two thirds of our membership base as of March 31, 2021, leading our
clubs to become an integral part of the families’ lives. We believe that this offering enhances
member engagement, promotes membership retention and differentiates us from our competitors.
We believe, based on management estimates, that we are one of the largest U.K. child activity
providers, as we offer extensive facilities for children (who represented approximately a quarter
of our members as of March 31, 2021). These include daycare, crèches, structured activity
programs, kids play-frames, child-friendly tablets, dedicated splash pools and family friendly areas
such as soft play and DL Kids activity areas, family lounges and family changing rooms, with an
average of approximately 500 family classes every week and 38,500 kids enrolled in the swimming
and tennis lessons of our All Stars programs for children aged 3–11 during the year ended
December 31, 2019.

More recently, we have further expanded our social offering by introducing quiet spaces

within our clubs to allow members to work directly from our premises. Our dedicated adult-only
business lounges have been designed so that members are given sufficient flexibility to take
advantage of our facilities while tending to their professional duties, in line with the recent
working-from-home trend spurred on as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. As an increasing
number of our members are choosing or needing to work from home, we seek to facilitate the
transition to a comfortable and reliable remote working environment by offering on-site spaces to
work from, thereby further strengthening our “clubiness.” As of March 31, 2021, all of our clubs
offered large and spacious lounges with complimentary WiFi access. In addition, we offer
dedicated adult-only lounges and business hubs in a select number of clubs.

_Our sports, fitness and wellness offering_

We believe we are one of the market leaders in privately-owned sports facilities in the U.K.

Our racquets, swimming and sports facilities are some of the highest quality in the market and are
accompanied by leading professional coaches. As of March 31, 2021, we operated 117 squash
courts and, based on management estimates, we operated approximately 36% of all indoor tennis
courts in the U.K. Further, as of March 31, 2021, we operated 196 indoor and outdoor pools across
the U.K. Our innovative group exercise programs, extensive studio facilities and state-of-the-art
gyms complement the full suite of our offering, helping us meet the varied needs of our members.
We believe group exercise is a significant driver of member retention, and have capitalized on this
trend by offering weekly 18,800 adult classes across all our clubs in the year ended December 31,
2019. We also offer extensive high-quality gym facilities, with an average of 120 pieces of gym
equipment per club as of March 31, 2021.

Our holistic approach to health includes what we believe to be market-leading wellness

offerings, which includes relaxing spa facilities, dedicated mind and body studios and a healthy
and nutritious menu. As of March 31, 2021, approximately 99% of our clubs included saunas,
steam rooms and jacuzzies. During the year ended December 31, 2019, we hosted approximately
2,500 mind and body classes every week. A select number of our U.K. clubs now include Spa
Retreats, which provides members with a high-end, luxurious wellness experience.


-----

Lastly, we are cognizant of the preference of some of our members to exercise from home,

and have bolstered our digital offering in order to keep our members engaged and connected during
the First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown. Our @home app is the flagship of our digital
offering and offers our members a weekly timetable of fitness classes and interactive events and
an extensive library of on-demand classes and tailored workout plans, all of which are designed
by our professional staff. The @home app also benefits from the integrated services of ancillary
service providers such as Boditrax and Myzone, which further reinforce our digital ecosystem. As
of March 31, 2021, our @home app had over 1,500 pieces of content, which were viewed 8.2
million times and used by approximately half of our members during the First Lockdown and the
Second Lockdown.

_No scale competitors with comparable offerings_

We offer a wide breadth of services and facilities that traditional gym groups and country

clubs do not match on a comparable scale, which reinforces our competitive advantage. Our
comprehensive club offering includes gyms, exercise and spinning studios, group exercise classes,
indoor and outdoor pools, saunas, steam rooms, jacuzzies, crèches, tennis courts with a range of
surface types, treatment rooms and squash courts. By contrast, most private clubs are only able to
provide a subset of our offering. For example, as of March 31, 2021, while 100% of our clubs had
dance studios, group exercise classes and indoor pools, private clubs that include those services
only amounted to 60%, 52% and 35%, respectively (according to management estimates). As of
March 31, 2021, approximately 99% of our clubs included saunas, steam rooms and jacuzzies,
while only 48%, 38% and 30% of private clubs included those same facilities, respectively
(according to management estimates). Moreover, while as of March 31, 2021, 90% of our clubs
included a crèche, 83% included a tennis offering and 73% included an outdoor pool, only 8%,
3% and 4% of private clubs featured those same services (according to management estimates).

We believe that our varied offering, including our outdoor facilities, tennis courts,

swimming pools, spas, restaurants, crèches and both live and on-demand workouts with our
@home app, allows us to stand out competitively within the premium segment of the market, and
that there are no scale competitors with a comparable offerings. The breadth of our offering as

**_Our scale and well-invested and strategically located club offering is difficult to replicate_**

_Catchment areas_

We believe that new entrants to the premium segment of the health and fitness club market

would experience difficulties in attempting to disrupt our strong presence and member base, both
in the U.K. and Europe. This is because significant capital, time, know-how and available land are
required to locate and develop a site that can be operated profitably. An attractive catchment area
is crucial for our clubs to be successful. As of March 31, 2021, according to management estimates,
there were only 39 target catchments in the U.K. that we had identified as suitable for the
development of a profitable club where we do not yet have a presence. The below charts illustrate
our current incumbency in the U.K. and the limited number of attractive target catchments where
we are not present:

David Lloyd’s incumbency Available sites


-----

Developing a profitable club requires finding a sufficiently affluent catchment area.

Against this background, we have a well-invested portfolio of premium locations throughout the
majority of affluent catchment areas in the U.K, which we believe are located in prime locations
and easily accessible by most of the population. As of March 31, 2021, based on management
estimates, 91% of our current members lived within a 20 minute drive of our clubs.

In addition, the significant capital requirements, time and know-how required to develop a

site, once located, present a significant investment cost to any new entrant. Our sites, from the
purchase of land to the fit-out of the club, cost approximately £13 million on average to develop.
To achieve a scale comparable to that of David Lloyd, we estimate that a potential new entrant
would need to invest over £1.5 billion over a significant period of time and with high execution
risk, while also having to source considerable know-how and devote a significant amount of time
to each site development project. We estimate that the full process from the initial scope (including
planning permission, detailed design, construction and fit out) to the opening of a site (including
membership ramp-up to the maturity of the site) would take a competitor six to seven years to
complete for each new club.

_Geographic diversification_

While our operations are primarily concentrated in the U.K., we also cover some of the

most affluent areas in some of Europe’s most important markets. Our European clubs in Italy,
Spain, Belgium and Germany are placed and marketed strategically to achieve affluent catchment
in some of Europe’s most affluent markets by Affluence Mix, as illustrated by the below chart:

We have substantially increased our market share in key European markets and we

currently have a presence in countries that represent more than 72% of the entire European market
(Source: Statista, 2020). We also have plans for further selective expansion via value-enhancing
strategic acquisitions. For example, our recent acquisition of eight clubs in Germany has increased
our penetration significantly into one of the most important European markets.

**_Loyal, affluent and diversified member base delivers resilient and recurring revenues_**

membership fees paid by our long-term members for the month February 2020, our aggregate
implied recurring revenue over the seven year tenure would have been approximately £1.9 billion.
We believe we have one of the lowest attrition rates in the industry with a pre-pandemic attrition
rate of 32.6% for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to up to approximately 100%
reported by certain low cost operators pre-pandemic (Source: public information). We believe that
our low attrition rates and the fact that a vast majority of our members join us with a 12-month
contract with a three-month notice period (providing us visibility and an opportunity to engage
with and convince leaving members before their contract ends) make us resilient to adverse market

**_Consistent delivery of growth and strong cashflow generation_**

Our rapid topline growth, underpinned by new member sales and price increases and

combined with a disciplined approach towards cost control, allows us to drive substantial cash
generation. We were operating at all-time highs in revenue, Adjusted EBITDA and operating cash
flow prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, with strong underlying performance driven by multiple
levers. In particular, our membership subscriptions revenue grew at a CAGR of 12.4% between
the financial year ended January 3, 2016 and the year ended December 31, 2019.

Between the financial year ended January 3, 2016 and the year ended December 31, 2019,

our total revenue increased from £330 million to £520 million (£413 million on a like-for-like
basis), representing a 12.0% increase in CAGR (5.8% on a like-for-like basis), our EBITDA
increased from £65 million to £135 (£108 million on a like-for-like basis), representing a 19.9%
increase in CAGR (13.3% on a like-for-like basis) and our operating cash increased from £38
million to £99 million, representing a 27.3% increase in CAGR, in each case as illustrated by the
charts below:

Our impressive earnings growth and margin expansion prior to the COVID-19 pandemic,

which we believe will resume following the staggered reopening of our facilities at the end of the
Second Lockdown, is supported by a well-controlled cost base. We have also implemented new
cost saving initiatives. Our Fit For Growth Program implemented in December 2020 is expected
to yield approximately £10 million of annual labor cost savings from 2021 onwards compared to
our labor costs for the year ended December 31, 2019, following a full review of club structures,
duty manager shifts and benchmarking of departmental hours as well as an increased focus on
digital solutions to optimize our staff and overhead costs. However, while management’s


-----

disciplined approach towards cost control has made our substantial revenue growth visible at
Adjusted EBITDA level, with our staff costs, overheads, club support and rent costs growing at a
CAGR substantively below our revenue CAGR between the financial year ended January 3, 2016
and the year ended December 31, 2019, our primary focus remains on delivering a best in-class
service and outstanding customer experience for our members. Therefore, while cost discipline
remains important, it does not take precedence over delivering a high-quality experience for our
members.

**_Industry leading management team_**

Our management team has a deep wealth of experience and talent. Their track-record of

proven success places us in a position to expand upon our robust market position. Our Executive
Chairman, Glenn Earlam, joined us from Merlin Entertainments (formerly Tussauds), where he
was Managing Director of Midway Attractions. Mr. Earlam was responsible for a successful
cultural change at Tussauds and led the global rollout of Midway Attractions. Under Mr. Earlam’s
leadership, we have been focusing on a number of operational initiatives aimed at improving our
customer service delivery, lowering customer attrition and bolstering brand awareness. While at
Merlin Entertainments, Mr. Earlam worked with our Chief Executive Officer, Russel Barnes for
over 20 years. Mr. Barnes brings considerable transformation and rollout experience to the team.
Another key member of our team, Patrick Burrows joined us as Chief Financial Officer from
London City Airport where he oversaw the £2.4 billion sale of the business. Prior to London City
Airport, Mr. Burrows worked at New Look and Tesco. The current management team expanded
our footprint through strategic value-enhancing acquisitions and organic growth, including the
acquisition of 14 Virgin Active clubs in 2017 and the acquisition of eight Meridian clubs in
Germany, growing our number of clubs from 94 clubs in 2016 to 122 in 2021. Our team is rounded
out by a dedicated group of directors with over 60 years of tenure between them.

**Our strategy**

The core of our strategy is to continue to deliver sustainable, profitable growth by focusing

on creating a premium experience for our club members. With our well-invested estate and wide
product offering, we put our members at the heart of our proposition, enabling us to deliver yield
and growth. Through reinvesting our profits into our existing estate to deliver an ever-improving
member experience, we create a virtuous circle that is proven and sustainable, as illustrated by the
chart below:


-----

**_Listening to members_**

We want our members to feel like David Lloyd is their club. We have a sophisticated,

comprehensive and targeted member communications program in place, covering the duration of
a member’s lifetime with us to encourage a high level of engagement and to allow us to understand
the desires of our members. We emphasize the quality of our offering and expert delivery of
multiple products and services, and we focus on member engagement and a tailored
communication strategy in order to stay in touch with our members frequently and effectively. We
ask our members for feedback on a regular basis, with an average of approximately 15 thousand
pieces of feedback received weekly through feedback stations in our clubs and push notifications
received through our @home app after each member visit. In addition, we track our members’ club
visits and directly reach out to them when we notice a drop in attendance, which allows us to assess
each member’s particular needs, offer bespoke programs, demonstrate our strong commitment to
member satisfaction and altogether rekindle engagement. We believe that this model allows us to
closely stay in touch with our members’ needs and foster a unique sense of belonging within our
clubs.

**_Improving our product offering_**

Our members have a keen view on value for money. Our track-record has proven that our

members are generally willing to pay membership fees at a premium provided that the quality of
our product offering and their experience justifies this cost. We leverage the feedback and insights
received from our members by investing heavily in our clubs to deliver a premium and
differentiated product proposition. For example, we rolled out our Spa Retreats and grew the
number of Blaze studios across our estate based on membership feedback. Our facilities include
heated indoor and outdoor pools, top class racquet facilities, well-equipped group exercise studios,
luxurious spas, family-oriented club rooms and outdoor spaces, lounges with restaurants and bars,
high-quality gyms as well as a fully complementary digital offering. The success of our product
initiatives is evidenced by the increasing quality scores our facilities have received from members
based on our internal surveys, with the quality of our facilities being endorsed by 92% of our
members in 2019 compared to 73% in 2015.

**_Enhancing the quality of the service that we provide to our members_**

We focus on enhancing the quality of the services we provide to our members by ensuring

that our clubs are staffed with great personnel who are motivated and engaged with the business.
Accordingly, we will continue to select our staff carefully and invest in their training to deliver
consistent, high-quality service to our members. Every new staff member receives formal training
during which they learn about our clubs and our culture and receive bespoke training in customer
service to ensure they are capable of delivering the premium experience our members expect. We
also have ongoing training for our staff covering health and safety protocols, as well as an online
training academy from which all employees can access a variety of courses, including child
safeguarding and a wide range of technical training. Our personal trainers and coaches are selected
in accordance with strict standards in order to ensure that they can deliver up-to-date advice on
training, fitness, nutrition and lifestyle changes to our members. In recognition of the pivotal role
our employees play in executing our strategy and delivering premium member services, we pay
the majority of our staff at levels above minimum wage and provide them with a comprehensive


-----

benefits package, including a club membership that allows them to use our facilities and gain a
first-hand understanding of our members’ needs. Based on regular employee surveys, employee
engagement improved from 80.0% in 2015 to 94.4% in 2019. We also consistently rank on the
Sunday Times’ Top 25 Best Companies to work for in the U.K. list.

**_Increasing member satisfaction_**

The combination of our high-quality facilities and outstanding customer services allows us

to maintain and increase our members’ satisfaction, leading to our members becoming advocates
for our business, with our Net Promoter Score increasing from 22.0 in 2015 to 57.2 in 2019,
according to our own survey. We intend to deploy a number of new initiatives in order to keep our
members engaged and maintain consistently high satisfaction levels. Since the start of the COVID19 pandemic, we have deployed an extensive digital and social media strategy that enhances our
members’ experience and exploits the power of digital commerce. For instance, both our website
and @home app allow online booking of group classes, and we continue to focus on delivering
fully complementary digital solutions to our members. Our strategy to increase member
satisfaction also hinges on our “clubiness,” as we believe that members value our clubs as a place
to socialize in a family-friendly setting. We will continue to put the social scene at the core of our
offering by organizing a wide spectrum of social events at our clubs and ensuring that our
members’ needs are always taken into consideration.

**_Growing our membership base_**

Our strong and experienced sales team will continue to sell our high-quality offering which

is synonymous with the significant recognition of the “David Lloyd” brand in the markets in which
we operate. In order to increase our membership base, our sales process is organized to encourage
potential members to visit our clubs and experience the full range of our facilities and services,
rather than choosing a club based on price alone. Our sales and marketing activities are also
benefiting from our increasing focus on digitalization and the rollout of our @home app. In order
to cater for situations where prospective members are unwilling or unable to visit our clubs before
purchasing a membership, we now offer a digital joining process, which has generated
approximately £11 million in revenue from its inception to April 2021. We view digital and social
media as an important new channel of communication with prospective members, and this vision
has been further strengthened by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Our social media
presence enables us to tailor our communications to each individual member based on factors such
as demographics and usage patterns, thereby enhancing the relevance of our member
communications and increasing each member’s engagement with their club. We will continue to
advertise our offering through a broad range of media platforms in the U.K., both nationally and
locally, including television, radio as well as all major social media platforms.

Our sales and marketing efforts have successfully increased our membership base at a

CAGR of 8.5% from 452 thousand as of 2015 to 626 thousand as of 2019 and at a CAGR of 2.5%
from 449 thousand as of 2015 to 496 thousand as of 2019 (on a like-for-like basis). Our
membership growth was achieved thanks to consistent net member gains during the same period,
with an average of 37.4 thousand net new members added each year between 2015 and 2019. In
addition, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, we had identified approximately ten of our clubs that
were approaching their maximum capacity, which indicates ample room for further growth of our


-----

like-for-like membership base. The charts below illustrate the growth of our total membership
base, net new members and average yield:

**_Confidently pricing membership fees_**

We will continue to collect feedback from our members and measure members’ satisfaction

with the quality and availability of our product offering and the prices paid for membership. Our
pricing strategy reflects our understanding, based on feedback, that our members are willing to
pay premium prices for a premium offering as members have acknowledged our investments in
our clubs and accepted price increases linked with improved quality and availability of our product
offerings and customer service. We generally announce price increases to our existing members
highlighting and reflecting investments that improve the facilities in their clubs. We
simultaneously update the membership fees for new members of the relevant clubs to reflect the
improvements at those clubs. Since 2016, we have delivered annual yield growth in excess of
annual retail price index (“RPI”) increases while continuously growing our membership base. In
addition, if based on certain capacity indicators, we identify clubs that are reaching their maximum
level of utilization, we implement price increases to manage the utilization levels at those clubs,
which allows us to generate further yield and EBITDA growth. For example, prior to the COVID19 pandemic, we had identified a small number of our clubs with limited excess parking or class
booking availability at peak times, and implemented price increases as demand for those clubs
exceeded availability. We intend to maintain our successful pricing strategy in order to continue
to deliver accretive and sustainable profit growth while continuing to increase our membership
base.

**_Reinvesting our growing profits_**

Enabled by our strong cash conversion, we will continue to reinvest our growing profits

into our estate in order to modernize, refurbish and expand our portfolio and thereby further
improve our product offering and enhance the quality of our services, which in turn drives
members’ satisfaction and yield growth, which can then be reinvested, creating a virtuous circle
that is proven and sustainable and which constitutes the basis of our strategy.

As our members value the quality of their clubs, we will continue to refresh and improve

our facilities with the latest, highest-quality offering and equipment. Capital expenditures are an
essential part of our strategy, and we have invested approximately £284 million into refurbishing
and transforming our clubs over the last six years. By October 2020, we had rolled out Spa Retreats
at a select number of clubs located in our most affluent catchment areas, which provide members


-----

with a high-end, luxurious wellness experience and deliver significant uplift in club Adjusted
EBITDAR. For example, we invested £3.6 million in the rollout of the Spa Retreat in our Royal
Berkshire club in the first half of 2019 and achieved a 31% return on investment with an increase
of £1.1 million in club Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended February 29, 2020 (based
on the club Adjusted EBITDAR for the eleven-month period April 2019 to February 2020, runrated for a twelve-month period), compared to the club Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months
ended prior to the investment of the capital expenditure. We have also been developing our free
weight capacity, adding more Olympic platforms on our gym floors and increasing the space in
our studios, and plan on bolstering our offering of onsite self-administered health products such as
cholesterol and DNA tests while also adding massage and stretching rooms to our clubs, offering
members a more bespoke fitness experience.

Historically, returns on Investment Capital Expenditure have been strong. Phase 1 of our

investment plan was completed in 2014 and comprised a £22.1 million investment into 18 clubs,
an average of £1.2 million per club. Phase 2 was completed in 2015 and comprised a £18.8 million
investment into 18 clubs, with an average of £1 million per club. Phase 3 was completed in 2016
and comprised a £32.4 million investment into 41 clubs, with an average of £800,000 per club. We
achieved a 43% return on investment from phase 1 with an increase of £9.5 million in club
Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017, a 42% return on investment from
phase 2 with an increase of £7.9 million in club Adjusted EBITDAR for twelve months ended June
30, 2017 and a 48% return on investment from phase 3 with an increase of £15.5 million in club
Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended June 30, 2018, in each case compared to the club
Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended prior to the investment of the capital expenditure.

**_Expanding our footprint in the U.K. and in Europe via selective value-enhancing strategic_**
**_acquisitions_**

We have implemented a successful acquisition strategy since Glenn Earlam joined the

Group in 2015, pursuing value-enhancing investments which have granted us access to new
catchment areas and increased our membership base. We proactively manage our club portfolio
by pursuing value-enhancing strategic acquisitions of small portfolios as well as standalone sites
in Europe, in line with our overall growth plan.

Prospective acquisitions are consistently assessed according to strict investment criteria, as

we look for a demonstrated ability to deliver returns both on a standalone and an aggregate basis.
We seek locations in a catchment area that has a significant affluent target population within a 20
minute drive, ideally without a competing club in the catchment area. A detailed demographic
analysis of the catchment area allows us to calculate a potential membership number for the site
to determine maximum club size and potential profitability. We then produce a detailed model for
each new site, using assumptions based on local catchment area characteristics and similar clubs
from our existing portfolio. Our approach enables us to determine the layout, mix of facilities,
membership categories and pricing characteristics of each club on an individual basis.

Our value accretive greenfield expansions are generally assessed on a single site basis,

given the factors associated in finding a suitable catchment area for a premium club. The
economics of sale and leaseback transactions allow us to maximize our return on our Pipeline
Capital Expenditure spend on greenfield expansions by combining a one-off profit on the sale of


-----

the freehold of the club, with EBITDA generation by the club during our leasehold period. For
example, we spent approximately £13 million in Pipeline Capital Expenditure to develop our
Emersons Green club in 2018 and 2019, which was expected to generate a mature EBITDA of
£2.6 million per year, and in December 2020, we sold the site for a net consideration of £21.1
million, representing an immediate profit of approximately £8.1 million. Simultaneous with the
sale, we agreed with the buyer to lease the club for an annual rent cost of £1.1 million, generating
a mature club EBITDA of £1.5 million per year. We will endeavour to use cash on balance sheet
or a prudent mixture of equity and debt to finance any future acquisitions. In addition, we will
continue to use complex data-analytics to assess new opportunities, which has been a key to our
well-proven record of both successful acquisitions and organic openings.

While our operations are currently primarily concentrated in the U.K., we expect to

consider further international sites via selective, value-enhancing strategic acquisitions of small
portfolios as well as standalone sites in Europe, in line with our overall growth plan. In particular,
we see significant growth potential in our current offerings in Europe, having already identified
approximately 700 potential development sites across the continent. Our European clubs represent
a differentiated proposition in several European markets with affluent demographics and we
believe there are no competitors of scale in the premium segment of the health and fitness market.
Our recent acquisition of eight clubs in Germany has significantly increased our penetration into
one of the most important European markets. This acquisition also provides a blueprint for further
strategic and selective European expansion into markets with high membership growth potentials
and low penetration rates.
