**_Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic_**

The First Lockdown

Prior to the First Lockdown, our business was performing on an upward growth trajectory,

with our latest annual price increase enacted in January 2020. Excluding the impact of the COVID19 pandemic, we generated £519.5 million of revenue, a loss of £51.5 million and £577.4 million
of Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue with a Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £170.9 million
for the year ended December 31, 2019. However, in March 2020, the governments of the U.K. and
of all European countries in which we operate imposed significant lockdown measures in order to
control the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic, including the temporary closure of almost all of
our clubs. During this First Lockdown, we decided not to charge members whilst their club was
closed, in line with our priority to retain members and treat them fairly. Consequently, almost all
of our revenue ceased until the phased reopening of our clubs in Europe starting from June 3, 2020
and in the U.K. on July 25, 2020. Approximately 44 thousand members canceled their membership
during the First Lockdown, and, in contrast with the pre-COVID situation, we sold very few new
memberships because our clubs were closed, resulting in unusually high levels of net member loss
over the second half and in particular the second quarter of 2020. We also recorded negative
Adjusted EBITDA from March 2020 to July 2020.

During the First Lockdown, we reacted swiftly to minimize our costs reducing our pre-lock

down monthly operating cash outflow by 86% from £37.7 million to £5.3 million, primarily due to
cash savings from furloughing staff (£50 million in aggregate across the First Lockdown and the
Second Lockdown) and deferred rent savings (£53 million in aggregate across the First Lockdown
and the Second Lockdown) as presented in the following chart:


-----

In addition to our costs saving initiatives, we focused on maximizing our members’

engagement and maintaining a dialogue with them. On March 23, 2020, we were one of the first
U.K. fitness, health and leisure operators to offer a remote exercise platform through the launch of
our “@home” mobile app. While memberships were frozen, we strove to keep our members
engaged with @home by offering them a weekly timetable of fitness classes and interactive events
and an extensive library of on-demand classes and tailored workout plans. Members used our
@home app not only for our signature fitness classes, but also for social events such as cooking
classes, quiz nights and make up tutorials. We also ensured that members who paid subscription
fees during months of partial closure were treated fairly by crediting their accounts with pro-rated
fees for the number of days we were closed. In addition, we kept an uninterrupted line of
communication with our members throughout the First Lockdown, giving them updates about our
reopening plans and new safety and hygiene protocols to be put in place in order to reassure them.
The success of our efforts to keep members engaged during the First Lockdown is evidenced by an
internal survey according to which 76% of them thought that the speed of communication was
“extremely good or very good” and 80.1% believed our implementation of government guidelines
was “extremely good or very good.” These high satisfaction rates served to reinforce our clubiness
and allowed us to minimize member loss during the First Lockdown to approximately 10% of our
total membership base, compared to approximately 27% for certain low-cost operators, according
to management estimates.

Following the reopening of the majority of our clubs in August 2020 after the First

Lockdown, we recorded our highest ever monthly new membership sales between August 2020
and October 2020, surpassing month-on-month 2019 sales in August by 70% (29.8 thousand new
members), in September by 59% (32.0 thousand new members) and in October by 57% (26.9
thousand new members) and our prior best sales month (January 2018) in August by 28%, in
September by 37% and in October by 15% evidencing the strong demand for our offering and
services. Furthermore, monthly new membership sales in November 2020 and December 2020
were also on track to exceed month-on-month 2019 sales prior to the announcement of the Second
Lockdown. The following chart illustrates the success of our membership sales following the First
Lockdown:


-----

The strong sales results of our clubs after the First Lockdown were recorded in spite of

fears of a looming Second Lockdown and the unavailability of vaccines at the time, which
demonstrates the appeal of our clubs where, in contrast to many of our competitors, we can
organize our activities outside and there is sufficient space to comply with social distancing rules
and COVID-19 protocols. After reopening in July 2020, based on an internal survey, our members
rated us 4.5 stars out of 5 stars for safety and wellbeing, which indicated our members and staff
felt comfortable coming back to our clubs.

Due to the recurring nature of our membership subscriptions revenue which we started

charging again upon reopening of our clubs after the First Lockdown, our business immediately
returned to profitability generating approximately £1 million, £7 million and £8 million of
Adjusted EBITDA in August, September and October 2020, respectively, as illustrated by the
following chart:

The Second Lockdown

On October 31, 2020, the U.K. Prime Minister announced a second national lockdown,

which came into effect on November 5, 2020 and required the temporary re-closure of all of our
English clubs until December 2, 2020. By January 5, 2021, all of our clubs in England were forced
to close again as a result of the Second Lockdown being reinstated, with other U.K. and European
clubs following a similar pattern of closures and reopening (with the exception of two clubs in


-----

Spain which remained open with certain operating restrictions). The chart below shows our total
number of clubs open throughout the First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown:

Consistent with our approach during the First Lockdown, club memberships in the U.K.

were frozen throughout the Second Lockdown, which led to our revenue almost ceasing during
this period. Our European clubs also generally followed the same approach. The higher number of
members leaving due to the closure of the majority of our clubs and the continued uncertainty
caused by the pandemic and our inability to sell new memberships, in contrast to pre-COVID-19
periods, resulted in a net member loss of approximately 51 thousand members during the Second
Lockdown. Based on our experience from the First Lockdown, we managed to minimize our
Adjusted EBITDA losses and cash burn during the Second Lockdown thanks to staff furloughs
and rent deferral negotiations.

April reopening

Following the Second Lockdown, the reopening of our clubs in England and Scotland has

been carried out on a staggered basis, with outdoor facilities reopening on March 29, 2021 and
indoor facilities reopening on April 12, 2021, followed by the full reopening of our Scottish clubs
on April 26, 2021. Based on recent government announcements, we anticipate the rest of our clubs
in Europe will start reopening from May 2021. Since the staggered reopening of our facilities at
the end of the Second Lockdown, our business has been performing very well. We believe that
this is partly because the more affluent segments of the population are relatively less impacted by
the COVID-19 pandemic and increased household saving rates are supporting a sustained period
of increased leisure spending. Our strong performance during April and May was also driven by
the fact that, as of March 31, 2021, 38% of our adult members were eligible for a vaccine jab on
the basis of age alone, and for those members who have elected to receive the vaccine it was safer
to return to our clubs, which was evidenced by this group accounting for 42% of attendance during
April 2021, despite making only 28% of our member count as of March 31, 2021. As of April 30,
2021, members who were 40 years and older were eligible for a vaccine jab, representing 60% of
our adult members. Furthermore, the suburban location of our clubs is allowing us to leverage the
new working-from-home trends, as members now have greater flexibility to visit our clubs during
the entire day, rather than at the usual pre- and post-working hours peak periods we used to observe
prior to the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, and some members are working from our clubs in
our business lounges.

In addition, we believe that certain trends spurred on by the COVID-19 pandemic are likely

to bolster demand for our clubs, as travel restrictions in Europe will force households to look for
domestic leisure centers during the summer of 2021, while the potential closures of some of our
weaker competitors’ facilities will reduce overall market supply and correspondingly increase
demand for our services. Furthermore, research on the retail, consumer and leisure sectors from
Strategy& suggests that 80% of adults surveyed in the U.K. expect to be mindful or more mindful
about practicing regular self-care post-pandemic.


-----

Our strong bounceback since the end of the Second Lockdown is evidenced by record new

membership sales, with 36.4 thousand new members added in April 2021 compared to 18.1
thousand new members in April 2019 at “normal” trading levels, representing an increase of 101%,
which led to a net member gain of approximately 27 thousand in April, while only 77% of our
clubs were open as of March 31, 2021 and only 84% of our clubs were open by the end of April
2021. We also recorded approximately 45 thousand new member sales between May 1 and May
31, 2021 compared to 18 thousand new members between May 1 and May 31, 2019, representing
an increase of approximately 150%. We believe that our new membership sales are likely to
continue to increase in the coming months as more clubs reopen and with key drivers of our
offering such as indoor group exercise, kids soft play, our indoor food and beverage offering and
sauna and steam rooms having resumed from May 17, 2021, allowing us to return to full capacity
in the U.K., while our European clubs also begin to reopen. Based on May 2021 levels, web traffic
(up 127.0% compared to March 2021) and web enquiries (up 218.8% compared to March 2021)
demonstrate a strong pipeline for June and July. Based on our all-time high new membership sales
and the pipeline data collected since the staggered reopening of our facilities at the end of the
Second Lockdown, we aim to reach our pre-pandemic membership base of 668 thousand members
by September 2021. The following chart illustrates our cumulative new membership sales since
March 1, 2021:

Many of our members canceled their membership during the First Lockdown and the

Second Lockdown and because our clubs were closed, we sold very few new memberships, in
contrast to normal pre-COVID-19 periods, as a result of which we had a net member loss of
approximately 94 thousand members between February 2020 and February 2021. However, our
strong recovery in membership numbers since the staggered reopening of our facilities has allowed
us to recoup more than a third of these lost members in the months of March and April 2021, while
16% of our clubs had yet to reopen as of the end of April and the further relaxation of social
distancing measures in the U.K. expected to generate a further increase in membership growth, as
our indoor group exercise, kids soft play, indoor food and beverage and wellness offering have
resumed from May 17, 2021. The following chart illustrates our strong recovery in membership
numbers since February 2021:


-----

The rapid bounceback of our membership numbers is expected to be further aided by lower

than normal attrition rates expected in the period June to September 2021 as 18% fewer members
have handed in a notice to terminate their membership as of May 31, 2021 compared to the same
position in 2019, and 22% fewer members lost during the same period compared to the 2019
position, as illustrated by the charts below:

Attrition pipeline as at 31[st] May Attrition as at 31[st] May

We expect our attrition levels in the next twelve months to remain lower compared to

normal pre-COVID-19 levels as a result of the lower sales during 2020, because historically an
element of our attrition is due to members cancelling their membership after the first year of joining
David Lloyd.

Our usage data since the end of the Second Lockdown is a further indicator of our strong

bounceback. Our average club usage from April 12, 2021 to May 30, 2021 was 28.4% higher than
it was following the reopening of our clubs at the end of the First Lockdown, which is testament
to the increasing appeal of our offering to members and increased consumer confidence. Since the
indoor facilities reopening on April 12, 2021, we have recorded an overall member attendance of
70.7%, with 70.2% of our adult membership base having attended our clubs.

Due to the recurring nature of our membership subscriptions revenue which we started

charging again when our clubs reopened, the clubs that reopened immediately returned to
profitability. As a result, we expect our EBITDA to be positive again for May 2021.

**Principal shareholder**

The Issuer is a wholly owned direct subsidiary of the Company, which is indirectly

controlled by funds managed or advised by TDR Capital LLP (“TDR Capital”).

TDR Capital LLP is a leading private equity firm that managed funds of up to €10 billion

of assets under management as at the end of 2020 and is based in the U.K. It was founded in 2002
by Manjit Dale and Stephen Robertson, who were previously partners at DB Capital Partners. TDR
Capital LLP has an experienced team of investment professionals and operating partners and has
a low-volume investment strategy based on principles developed by the investment team over the
past decade. TDR Capital LLP seeks to spend significant resources on each investment and to
focus on operational excellence through a tested and integrated operating partner model.

Intense pre-investment analysis and post-investment involvement mean that TDR Capital

is selective, typically making only one to three investments a year. TDR Capital takes an active
role in overseeing the operations of its investments, working in partnership with management
through board representation and professional support.

TDR Capital has been a longstanding supporter of the business, having acquired the

Company in 2013. It has since supported the management team on its growth journey in
transforming the business into one of Europe’s leading health & leisure club operators, enabling
us to record growth in revenue and member count of 81.1% and 54.9%, respectively, between
2013 and 2019, and growing our EBITDA at a CAGR of 15.6% between 2014 and 2019 (in each
case on a pro forma run rate adjusted basis). In addition, under TDR Capital’s ownership, we have
spent £380 million of capital expenditures on our estate since 2013. TDR Capital’s capital
contribution to the Meridian Group of approximately €80 million represents its most recent
commitment to the Company’s continued success. To date, TDR Capital LLP has completed 22
investments across the leisure, consumer, business and financial services sectors. Some examples
of current and prior TDR Capital investments include Hurtigruten, ASDA, Euro Garages, Pizza
Express and Stonegate Pub Company.

In connection with the Transactions, TDR will inject £100 million into the Company as

part of the Equity Contribution.

**Summary historical consolidated financial and other data**

**Financial statements presented**

**_Financial information of the Issuer and the Company_**

The Issuer is a newly formed entity incorporated on May 6, 2021 for purposes of facilitating

the Transactions and performing certain activities related thereto. The Issuer is a wholly owned
direct subsidiary of the Company. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer has no
revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business operations, material assets or liabilities
other than those acquired or incurred in connection with its incorporation and the Transactions. As
a result, no historical financial information of the Issuer is included in this Offering Memorandum.

The Company was incorporated on May 18, 2018 as a holding company. The Company is

indirectly owned by HoldCo. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Company has no
revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business operations, material assets or liabilities
other than (i) certain existing indebtedness which will be repaid with the proceeds of the
Transactions (see “Use of proceeds”) and (ii) a £2.0 million annual monitoring fee paid to HoldCo.
As a result, no historical financial information of the Company is included in this summary.

**_Historical Financial Information of Holdco_**

The consolidated historical and other financial data presented in this summary have been

derived from (i) the audited consolidated financial statements of HoldCo as of and for the period
from January 4, 2018 to December 31, 2018 and as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019
and 2020, including the accompanying notes thereto, which have been prepared in accordance with
IFRS and which have been audited by Deloitte LLP and (ii) the unaudited condensed consolidated
interim financial statements of HoldCo as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2021,
including accompanying notes thereto (with comparable financial information for the three months
ended March 31, 2020), which have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim Financial
Reporting, in each case included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. References to the
“Group,” “us” or “our” in the context of historical financial information or other financial
information relate to HoldCo and its subsidiaries. The audit reports for the period from January 4,
2018 to December 31, 2018 and as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020,
included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, express an unqualified opinion for each of the
respective periods and the audit report in relation to the audited consolidated financial statements
for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 include a material uncertainty paragraph related
to going concern as set forth in Note 2 to such financial statements.

IFRS 16 (Leases) was published on January 13, 2016 by the International Accounting

Standard Board. It became effective on January 1, 2019 and applies to the first full financial year
commencing on or after that date. Our first full financial year following the effective date of IFRS
16 began on January 1, 2019, and we applied the modified retrospective approach of adopting the
new standard, which did not require a restatement of comparative results for the financial period
ended December 31, 2018. On adoption of IFRS 16, the Group recognized lease liabilities in
relation to leases which had previously been classified as “operating leases” under the principles
of IAS 17. These liabilities were measured at the present value of the remaining lease payments,


-----

discounted using the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate as of January 1, 2019. The weighted
average lessee’s incremental borrowing rate applied to the lease liabilities on January 1, 2019 was
6.8%. For leases previously classified as “finance leases,” the carrying amount of the lease asset
and lease liability immediately before transition were recognized as the carrying amount of the
right-of-use asset and the lease liability at the date of initial application. For more information on
the adoption of IFRS 16 and the adjustments made in relation thereto, see “Management’s
_discussion and analysis of financial conditions and results of operations—Factors affecting_
_comparability of our results of operations—Adoption of IFRS 16” and Note 33 to the HoldCo_
consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2019.

During the year ended December 31, 2020, we identified that both deferred tax asset

balances and reserves had been understated by £21 million as of December 31, 2019. As a result,
we have restated the consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2019. The
Group adopted IFRS 16 Leases retrospectively from January 1, 2019, but did not restate
comparatives for the 2018 reporting period, as permitted under the specific transition provisions
in the standard. The adjustments arising from the new leasing rules were therefore recognized in
the opening balance sheet on January 1, 2019. There were no errors related to the adoption of IFRS
16 itself. The error was restricted to the deferred tax calculation. The misstatement of the deferred
tax balances related to the complexities of the adoption of IFRS 16 Leases retrospectively from
January 1, 2019. There is no impact on the consolidated income statement for the year ended
December 31, 2019 and the effect on the consolidated statement of financial position as of
December 31, 2019 was to increase the opening January 1, 2019 deferred tax assets by £21 million
and to reduce accumulated losses as of January 1, 2019 by £21 million.

Our consolidated financial statements include the results of operations and financial

position of HoldCo, which are not attributable to the Company or its subsidiaries. As a result, the
consolidated financial statements of HoldCo are not directly comparable to the historical financial
information of the Company and its subsidiaries, which is prepared in accordance with IFRS. The
main differences between the consolidated financial position and results of operations of HoldCo
and the Company (i) as of and for the period from January 4, 2018 to December 31, 2018, related
to interest income in relation to shareholder loans from HoldCo to its direct and indirect
shareholders and cash on balance sheet held under HoldCo’s name, which amounted to £2.3
million and £1.0 million, respectively, and a shareholder loan from HoldCo to the Company which
amounted to £5.9 million; (ii) as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, related to the
balance of a shareholder loan from HoldCo to its shareholder and cash on balance sheet held under
HoldCo’s name, which amounted to £2.1 million and £1.5 million, respectively, and £0.2 million
additional finance cost incurred by the Company in relation to interest paid on a £5.3 million
shareholder loan from HoldCo to the Company; (iii) as of and for the year ended December 31,
2020, related to the balance of a shareholder loan from HoldCo to its shareholder and cash on
balance sheet held under HoldCo’s name, which amounted to £2.2 million and £1.4 million,
respectively, and £0.1 million additional finance cost incurred by the Company in relation to
interest paid on a £5.9 million shareholder loan from HoldCo to the Company; (iv) as of and for
the three months ended March 31, 2020, related to the balance of a shareholder loan from HoldCo
to its shareholder and cash on balance sheet held under HoldCo’s name, which amounted to £2.1
million and £1.5 million, respectively, and a £5.7 million shareholder loan from HoldCo to the
Company and (v) as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2021, related to the balance of a
shareholder loan from HoldCo to Deuce TopCo Limited and cash on balance sheet held under


-----

HoldCo’s name, which amounted to £2.2 million and £1.4 million, respectively, and a £6.0 million
shareholder loan from HoldCo to the Company.

As such differences are not material, the financial and operating results and certain other

information relating to HoldCo have been presented in this Offering Memorandum in lieu of the
Company. We believe that HoldCo’s consolidated financial statements, subject to the differences
noted above, adequately reflect the Company’s consolidated financial results and financial position
for the applicable periods.

**Non-IFRS measures**

We have included certain non-IFRS financial measures in this Offering Memorandum.

Non-IFRS financial measures are derived on the basis of methodologies other than IFRS and the
non-IFRS measures we present may also be defined differently than the corresponding terms under
the Indenture.

Our management uses Adjusted EBITDA, Cash Conversion Ratio, Pro Forma Run Rate

Adjusted EBITDA and _Pro Forma_ Run Rate Revenue to assess our operating performance.
Adjusted EBITDA is considered the key measure of profitability. It is considered by management
to be the supplemental measure to understand the underlying trading and financial performance of
our business and is the measure used to report to both the board and external lenders. In addition,
we believe these metrics are measures that are useful to investors. Adjusted EBITDA, Cash
Conversion Ratio, Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue are
not presentations made in accordance with IFRS, and our use of such terms varies from others in
our industry. These metrics should not be considered as alternatives to revenue, profit/(loss),
operating profit/(loss) or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS as
measures of operating performance or operating cash flows as measures of liquidity, and Adjusted
EBITDA and Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA do not necessarily indicate whether cash
flow will be sufficient or available for cash requirements. Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Run
Rate Adjusted EBITDA have important limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider
them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our results as reported under IFRS. Adjusted
EBITDA and _Pro Forma_ Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA may not be indicative of our historical
operating results nor are they meant to be predictive of potential future results.

Such non-IFRS financial information has not been audited or reviewed by Deloitte LLP.

**Adjusted financial information**

We also present below certain unaudited adjusted consolidated financial information of

HoldCo, including adjusted cash and cash equivalents, adjusted interest expense, adjusted net debt
and adjusted total debt and leverage and coverage ratios. Such measures reflect the following:

  - _Adjusted cash and cash equivalents is cash and cash equivalents adjusted for expected_
ordinary course movements in our cash and cash equivalents between March 31, 2021
and June 30, 2021, based on management estimates, including revenue generated and
expenses and interest paid in such period. Adjusted cash and cash equivalents assumes a
cash position of £30.3 million prior to the Transactions taking effect, in each case, as of


-----

June 30, 2021 and based on management estimates. Actual amounts may vary from
estimated amounts. Adjusted cash and cash equivalents is adjusted to give effect to the
repayment of the existing indebtedness from the estimated cash available on the balance
sheet as of June 30, 2021 and the expected proceeds of the Offering of the Notes and the
Equity Contribution available for general corporate purposes, including £20 million to
£30 million which is earmarked for strategic value-enhancing acquisitions, which, if
successful could take place over the course of 2021 (see “Use of proceeds”) and includes
the cash position of DLL Greenwich Limited and its subsidiaries, including the Meridian
Group, following the Internal Reorganization.

  - _Adjusted interest expense is interest expense adjusted for the effect of the Transactions,_
as if they had occurred on January 1, 2019 and assumes the New Revolving Credit Facility
was undrawn.

  - _Adjusted net debt is adjusted total debt less adjusted cash and cash equivalents._

  - _Adjusted total debt is our current and non-current loans and borrowings adjusted for the_
effect of the Transactions, as if they had occurred on March 31, 2021 and including £3
million (euro equivalent) of Meridian Spa & Fitness Deutschland GmbH indebtedness
following the Internal Reorganization and excludes the PIK Instrument, as the PIK
Instrument will be incurred at HoldCo outside the Restricted Group.

Such adjusted measures are not financial measures defined in accordance with IFRS and,

as such, may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.

Such adjusted financial information has not been audited or reviewed by Deloitte LLP. As

all companies do not calculate these financial measures in the same manner, the presentation of
each financial measure may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures used by other
companies. The unaudited adjusted consolidated financial information has not been prepared in
accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the U.S. Securities Act, the Prospectus
Regulation or any generally accepted accounting standards. The unaudited adjusted adjustments
are based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe to be reasonable.

The unaudited _adjusted consolidated financial information has been provided for_

informational purposes only. Results indicated by certain of these measures may not be realized,
and funds depicted by certain of these measures may not be available for management’s
discretionary use if such results are not realized. Further, the unaudited _adjusted consolidated_
financial information does not purport to indicate our future consolidated results of operations or
our cash position or financial position as at any future date. The actual results may differ
significantly from those reflected in the unaudited adjusted financial information for a number of
reasons, including, but not limited to, differences in assumptions used to prepare the unaudited
_adjusted financial information._

The unaudited adjusted consolidated financial information should be read in conjunction

with the information contained in “Presentation of financial of financial and other information

(b) Depreciation and amortization relates to expenses incurred in connection with the depreciation and amortization of property, plant and
equipment and intangibles, including goodwill. The amount for the period ended December 31, 2018 is presented net of amortization
of lease above market rent liability.

(c) Profit/(loss) on disposal of PP&E relates to profit and loss incurred on sale and leaseback transactions of property, plant and equipment
and other intangible assets.

(d) Impairments of right-of-use assets in the year ended December 31, 2020 relates to impairments recorded due to the impact of COVID19 following our annual impairment review.

(e) Cost of lease re-negotiations in the year ended December 31, 2020 primarily relates to stamp duty land tax paid (£5.3 million) in
connection with lease extensions.

(f) Business restructuring costs relates to redundancy costs incurred in connection with operational restructuring initiatives.


-----

(g) Refinancing transaction and acquisition related costs relates to fees incurred in connection with various transactions entered into as
part of the refinancing of our capital structure. The amounts for the period ended March 31, 2021 represents non-refundable refinancing
transaction costs.

(h) Impairment of investment relates to impairments incurred in connection with our Indian joint venture.

(i) Losses associated to our Indian joint venture relates to non-recurring financial losses incurred in connection with our unsuccessful
Indian joint venture.

(j) Onerous lease provision charges relates to charges recorded in our accounts for certain new onerous lease provisions for loss-making
clubs prior to the adoption of IFRS 16 created during the period. Onerous lease provisions reflect the estimated minimum net cost of
exiting or fulfilling the lease.

(k) Release of legal provisions relates to the release of a provision recorded for a potential legal case related to a health and safety incident
that occurred in 2016.

(l) Pre-opening costs relates to the total of all gym site operating costs incurred prior to the opening of a new gym, primarily consisting
of staff costs and marketing costs.

(m) Monitoring fees – managerial advice relates to the recurring fees relating to shareholders.

(n) Non-executive director fees relates to the recurring fees relating to directors.

(o) Long-term incentive scheme and non-recurring redundancies relates to share based payments charges in relation to management
incentive schemes and redundancies not in the ordinary course of business.

(p) Closed club costs relates to ongoing costs incurred in relation to clubs that are permanently closed and consist primarily of payments
under long-term leases, excluding clubs that were closed as a result of local or national lockdowns due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

(q) Acquisition and aborted expenses relates to costs incurred in connection with potential acquisitions and developments that did not
materialize.

(r) Insurance proceeds from damage to property, plant & equipment relates to insurance proceeds received in connection with technical
hazards at our clubs.

(s) IFRS 16 transition and other due diligence costs relates to expenses incurred in connection with the adoption and implementation of
IFRS 16 into our reporting system.

(t) Foreign exchange difference relates to differences between the target foreign exchange in our budget and the actual average foreign
exchange.

(u) Rent (replaced with depreciation and interest under IFRS 16) relates to rental costs that would have been recognized in the income
statement on a pre-IFRS 16 basis.

(v) Utilization of the onerous lease provisions relates to the utilization of certain previously recorded onerous lease provisions for lossmaking clubs prior to the adoption of IFRS 16.

(w) Non-cash rental accrual (excluding lease incentive accrual) relates to the SSAP 21 treatment of rental leases prior to the adoption of
IFRS16.

(x) Share of loss of equity accounted investments relates to the loss of the equity stake in our Indian joint venture.

(y) Existing Portfolio Run Rate Adjustment relates to the annualized effect of our blended price rises implemented in January 2020 of
4.5% (approximately £17.6 million), cost inflation of 2.6% (approximately £8.1 million), additional rent costs following our sale and
lease back transactions completed in the second half of 2019 and in December 2020 (approximately £1.6 million), the positive impact
of rent negotiations (approximately £2.7 million) and our estimate of the full period impact of costs savings resulting from our Fit For
Growth Program implemented in December 2020 following a full review of club structures, duty manager shifts and benchmarking
of departmental hours as well as an increased focus on digital solutions to cut down on certain of our staff and overhead costs, which
is expected to yield approximately £10 million of annual labor cost savings from 2021 onwards compared to our labor costs for the
year ended December 31, 2019. This adjustment does not include any impact of the opening of new clubs or the maturing of recently
opened clubs.

**Risk factors**

_Participating in the Offering and investing in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. You_

_should carefully consider the following risks, together with other information provided to you in this_
_Offering Memorandum, in deciding whether to invest in the Notes. The risks and uncertainties_
_described below are not the only ones we are facing. The occurrence of any of the events discussed_
_below could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations. If_
_these events occur, the trading prices of the Notes could decline, and we may not be able to pay all_
_or part of the interest or principal on the Notes, and you may lose all or part of your investment._
_Additional risks not currently known to us or that we now deem immaterial could also adversely_
_affect our business, results of operations, financial condition, or our ability to fulfill our obligations_
_under the Notes and may affect your investment. Further, to the extent that the COVID-19 pandemic_
_has already adversely affected our business and its results of operations, it may also have the effect_
_of heightening many of the other risks described in this section._

_This Offering Memorandum contains “forward-looking” statements that involve risks and_

_uncertainties. Our actual results may differ significantly from the results discussed in the forward-_
_looking statements. Factors that might cause such differences include those discussed below and_
_elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Please see “Forward-looking statements.”_

**Risks relating to our business and industry**

**_The COVID-19 pandemic has adversely impacted, and will continue to adversely impact, our_**
**_business, financial position and results of operations._**

In late 2019, a new strain of coronavirus was detected in Wuhan, China. In March 2020,

the World Health Organization declared COVID-19 a global pandemic and governmental
authorities around the world implemented measures to reduce the spread of the COVID-19
pandemic. These measures have included imposing restrictions on international travel and closing
borders to all non-essential travel, business closures, social distancing, national and regional
restrictions (including curfews and other lock-down measures) as well as quarantine requirements.
These measures have adversely affected workforces, consumer sentiment, economies and financial
markets, and, along with decreased consumer spending and widespread uncertainty following
months of lockdowns, have led to an economic downturn in all of the countries in which we
operate.

In March 2020, the governments of the U.K. and of all European countries in which we

operate imposed significant lockdown measures in order to control the spread of the COVID-19
pandemic, including the temporary closure of almost all of our clubs (the “First Lockdown”).
During the First Lockdown, we decided not to charge members whilst their club was closed, in
line with our priority to retain members and treat them fairly. Consequently, almost all of our
revenue ceased until the phased reopening of our clubs in Europe starting from June 3, 2020 and
in the U.K. on July 25, 2020. Many of our members also canceled their membership during the
First Lockdown, resulting in unusually high levels of net member loss over the second half of 2020,
with approximately 44 thousand members leaving David Lloyd during this period.


-----

On October 12, 2020, the U.K. Prime Minister announced a three-tiered system of

restrictions across England (the “Tiered System”) which came into effect on October 14, 2020. On
October 14, 2020, Liverpool and a number of other cities in the Merseyside area were placed in
Tier 3. Under the baseline for Tier 3 restrictions, clubs could be closed pursuant to “additional
measures” imposed by national or local government, as was the case in the Merseyside area. While
clubs could remain open where Tier 1 and Tier 2 restrictions applied, there can be no guarantee
that, in the event the Tiered System is re-implemented in the future, this would continue to be the
case or that more stringent rules and restrictions would not be applied in a manner that could
materially adversely impact our business. Additionally, under the Tiered System, local authorities
in England were given the power to impose stricter rules and restrictions in addition to those
imposed by the national government, with the potential to further materially adverse our business
and industry. During the period in which the Tiered System was in place, many of our clubs were
located in Tier 2 or Tier 3 areas. Under the Tiered System, Tier 2 areas could rapidly become Tier
3 areas and, likewise, Tier 1 areas could rapidly become Tier 2 or Tier 3 areas, and these
movements were fluid and outside of our control. The Tiered System applied only to England,
while the devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland had the power to
design and implement their own restrictions, including stricter restrictions than in England. Even
though the Tiered System was subsequently replaced by the Second Lockdown (as defined herein),
the Tiered System, or another set of comparable or more stringent restrictions, could be put in
place in the future.

On October 31, 2020, the U.K. Prime Minister announced a second national lockdown,

which came into effect on November 5, 2020 and required the temporary re-closure of all of our
English clubs (the “Second Lockdown”) until December 2, 2020. By January 5, 2021, all of our
clubs in England were forced to close again as a result of the Second Lockdown being reinstated,
with other U.K. and European clubs following a similar pattern of closures and reopening (with
the exception of two clubs in Spain which remained open with certain operating restrictions).
Consistent with our approach during the First Lockdown, club memberships in the U.K. were
frozen throughout the Second Lockdown, which led to our revenue almost ceasing during this
period and a correlated spike in attrition levels caused by approximately 94 thousand members
leaving David Lloyd during this period, with our European clubs also generally following the same
approach. Following the Second Lockdown, the reopening of our clubs in England and Scotland
has been carried out on a staggered basis, with outdoor facilities reopening on March 29, 2021 and
indoor facilities reopening on April 12, 2021, followed by the full reopening of our Scottish clubs
on April 26, 2021. The rest of our clubs in Europe are expected to start reopening fully from May
2021, however, we cannot assure you that the reopening will not be conditioned or delayed or that
further lockdowns will not be put in place.

During the First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown, we relied on access to government

aid and mitigation programs. Through negotiation with landlords, we were able to minimize cash
outlays by deferring certain rent payments, amending rent review mechanisms and extending leases
in exchange for the write-off of certain rental payments in arrears. Our mitigation strategy was
reinforced by legislation such as the UK Coronavirus Act 2020 and the UK Corporate Insolvency
and Governance Act 2020, which introduced certain protections in relation to lease forfeitures,
restrictions on the use of commercial rent arrears recovery and temporary restrictions on the ability
of creditors to file statutory demands and winding up petitions in the U.K. based solely on the failure
to comply with rent payment obligations as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. We cannot provide


-----

any assurance that during any subsequent waves of the COVID-19 pandemic and/or any subsequent
lockdowns, such government aid, mitigation programs, negotiations with landlords and/or
protective legislation will be available to the same extent as in the past or at all and, if this were the
case, our cash outlay levels would be significantly higher during any subsequent waves than they
were in the previous waves. In the event that government support was unavailable, or available on
a more limited basis only, we would be forced to rely solely on our ability to pause capital
expenditures, implement cost reduction measures and defer payments, which could significantly
reduce our overall ability to mitigate cash burn. Likewise, we cannot provide any assurance that we
will be able to defer payments to the same extent as in the past or at all. Furthermore, payment
deferrals, on rent in particular, create future obligations towards our creditors, and our cash outlays
will increase when the deferred payments become due. We have £35.1 million of deferred payments
due from June 30, 2021 to December 31, 2021 with an additional £45.2 million of deferred
payments due to be settled in 2022.

Our newly reopened clubs in the U.K. and Europe now follow detailed governmental

guidelines in order to maintain social distancing and to increase sanitation and hygiene. These
include extensive cleaning protocols and other policies implemented in an effort to avoid the spread
of the COVID-19 pandemic, all of which may impact the operation and member appeal of our clubs.
For example, members unaccustomed to waiting significant periods of time before using certain
exercise equipment, or to increased cleaning periods, may cancel their membership. Furthermore,
in all of our indoor facilities, members over the age of 12 will be required to wear masks when not
exercising, which may deter members from attending our clubs and lead them to cancel or suspend
their membership. While we believe that our operations are currently in compliance with applicable
guidance, if customers perceive our implementation of these measures to be inadequate or
ineffective, we may suffer damage to our reputation, which could have a significant adverse effect
on our business. Even when social distancing policies are lifted, interest in visiting our clubs may
remain weak due to health concerns or changes in exercise preferences in favor of at home, online
or on-demand platforms. This will affect both current and prospective members, and may lead to
increased levels of attrition. We cannot predict when or if each of our clubs will return to preCOVID-19 membership levels or if they will be able to maintain pre-COVID-19 membership levels
and pricing terms over the mid- to long-term. We also cannot predict whether member cancellation
rates will be higher in subsequent lockdowns than they were during the First Lockdown and the
Second Lockdown. Additionally, policies implemented to slow the spread of the COVID-19
pandemic have impacted and will continue to impact our cost of doing business due to, among
others, the increased cost associated with hygiene measures and track and trace programs.

Although we have taken extensive measures to protect our members and employees, we

cannot be certain that such measures will be sufficient to mitigate the health risks posed by the
COVID-19 pandemic, and we may be subject to litigation as a result of members or employees who
contract, or believe they have contracted, the virus at our clubs. We may also be subject to potential
litigation initiated by employees alleging that we have facilitated an unsafe working environment
or have increased their exposure to the virus. Additionally, we may be at risk of litigation following
a possible outbreak at one or a number of our clubs, which may cause us to incur further significant
costs and may have a negative impact on our reputation. Although recent vaccine approvals have
raised hopes of a turnaround in the pandemic in 2021, renewed waves and new variants of the virus
pose concerns for the global economic outlook and continue to exacerbate the risks posed by the
COVID-19 pandemic and may result in further lockdowns or other restrictive measures that may


-----

impact our operations. For example, in April 2021, the U.K. recorded an increasing number of
cases of the Indian COVID-19 variant, and a surge in these cases may cause the U.K. government
to reconsider its approach regarding the contemplated easing of lockdown restrictions.

We cannot guarantee that the fitness industry will ever return to the norms, lifestyle and

club attendance patterns that existed before the emergence of the COVID-19 pandemic. Further
social distancing measures, governmental lockdowns and curfews may be implemented across the
U.K. and Europe and have a materially detrimental impact on our business, financial condition and
results of operation. Our business is sensitive to reductions in discretionary spending by consumers,
public health events and other factors described in this “Risk factors” section. To date, the COVID19 pandemic has caused, and is continuing to cause, significant disruption in economic activity
globally, which could lead to a decline in discretionary spending by our members. Our revenue may
be negatively impacted by the adverse changes in the perceived or actual economic climate,
including higher unemployment rates and declining income and personal wealth levels resulting
from the COVID-19 pandemic. Our revenue may not increase in proportion to our fixed and deferred
costs, and it may not be sufficient to offset the full impact of the shutdown of our clubs during the
First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown. If our cost base is higher than our revenue, our cash
management policies may fail due to factors beyond our control.

The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business will ultimately depend on a

number of factors that cannot be accurately predicted at this time, including the duration (and the
extent of any resurgence in the future) and severity of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, the threat
posed by new variants and the discrepancies of the vaccination efforts across the world. There are
no comparable recent events that provide us with guidance, and so we cannot currently estimate
this with any certainty, nor can we provide any assurance that the COVID-19 pandemic will not
continue to have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations. The adverse impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business, financial condition
and results of operations may also have the effect of heightening other risks described in this “Risk
_factors” section. If the industry in which we operate is fundamentally changed by the COVID-19_
pandemic in ways that are detrimental to us, our business may continue to be adversely affected
even as the pandemic abates and the broader economy begins to recover.

**_Legal, political and economic uncertainty surrounding the exit of the U.K. from the EU_**
**_(“Brexit”) may be a source of instability in international markets, create significant currency_**
**_fluctuations, and adversely affect our clubs._**

Whilst the U.K. officially exited the EU on January 31, 2020, the legal status quo from

before January 31, 2020 continued during a so-called “transition period” during which the U.K.
and the EU negotiated the terms of the separation and any future trade deal. This transition period
ended on December 31, 2020. On December 24, 2020, the U.K. and the EU announced that they
had agreed a new trade and cooperation deal (the “Trade and Cooperation Agreement”) governing
certain aspects of the future relationship between the U.K. and the EU. The Trade and Cooperation
Agreement was formally approved by the U.K. parliament on December 30, 2020 and applies
provisionally from January 1, 2021. It is currently expected to be formally ratified by the EU
parliament by April 30, 2021. The Trade and Cooperation Agreement provides guidance in respect
of the intended shape of the future relationship between the U.K. and the EU and some detailed
matters of trade and cooperation. However, there remain uncertainties related to Brexit and the


-----

relationship between the U.K. and the EU which will continue to be developed and defined and
could cause instability in the EU, U.K. or worldwide political, regulatory, economic or market
conditions. Any Brexit-related effects are likely to be compounded by the effects of the COVID19 pandemic. See “—The COVID-19 pandemic has adversely impacted, and will continue to
_adversely impact, our business, financial position and results of operations.”_

Due to the size and importance of the U.K. economy, the uncertainty and unpredictability

concerning the U.K.’s legal, political and economic relationship with the EU after the U.K. exits
the EU may continue to be a source of instability in the international markets, create significant
currency fluctuations, and/or otherwise adversely affect trading agreements or similar cross-border
cooperation arrangements (whether economic, tax, fiscal, legal, regulatory or otherwise) for the
foreseeable future.

The long-term effects of Brexit will depend on the evolution of any agreements (or lack

thereof) between the U.K., the EU and those third countries with which the U.K. currently enjoys
tariff-free access. Brexit is likely to impact the legal rights and obligations of commercial parties
across all industries, including health and fitness. Given the high correlation between demand on
the one hand, and economic growth and stability in the markets generating such demand on the
other hand, there is a risk that Brexit, other political developments or developments otherwise
affecting market confidence could negatively impact consumer behavior and, consequently, the
demand for our services. Changes in health and safety laws and regulations, as well as volatility
in food, drink and energy prices, in each case as a result of Brexit, could also adversely impact our
ability to smoothly operate our clubs.

We are based in the U.K. and as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, approximately

19% of our clubs were located in the EU. Lower levels of economic growth and changes in the
macroeconomic environment in the U.K. or in the European countries in which we operate as a
result of Brexit could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results
of operations.

**_Our geographic concentration heightens our exposure to adverse regional developments._**

Our geographic concentration in the U.K., in the Southeast of England and London in

particular, heightens our exposure to adverse developments in these areas, including those related
to negative political and economic trends, demographic changes, competition or other unforeseen
events that reduce consumers’ ability or willingness to spend. For instance, an uncertain economic
outlook as a result of an unforeseen event in London, whether related to Brexit (as defined herein)
or not, could materially and adversely affect consumer spending habits in those regions, which
could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_The health, fitness and leisure industry in which we operate is highly competitive and we may_**
**_fail to compete effectively._**

The health, fitness and leisure industry is highly competitive and fragmented, with several

large operators operating on a local, national or international level and smaller operators providing
services in their local areas. We operate in the premium segment of the health, fitness and leisure
industry in the U.K. and Europe. While this market segment has few players of considerable scale,
the mid-market and value segments of the health, fitness and leisure industry in the U.K. and


-----

Europe are highly competitive. As a result of the increasing number of value clubs in the U.K. and
Europe, we may face increased competition from this segment of the market, especially since the
operators of such value clubs likely charge lower membership prices than us or are able to gain
access to significant amounts of capital to enable them to rapidly build new sites. The appeal of
the value segment of the market may be magnified as a result of the economic disruption created
by the COVID-19 pandemic, with discretionary spending tightening. Additionally, there is a risk
that traditional value and mid-market health and fitness club operators may change their models
or create premium brand alternatives in order to more effectively compete with us.

We compete with many other businesses, including gym operators, tennis clubs, physical

fitness and recreational facilities established by local non-profit organizations, governments,
hospitals, local salons, cafés, exercise studios, golf and other athletic clubs, country clubs, online
personal training, fitness coaching, the home fitness equipment industry and businesses offering
similar ancillary services to ours. Nonprofit organizations and local authorities in our markets may
be able to obtain land and construct clubs at a lower cost and may be able to collect membership
fees without paying taxes or receive preferential tax treatment, thereby allowing them to
potentially charge lower prices. In addition, because we do not have exclusive rights to many of
the elements that comprise our in-club experience and service offering, competitors may attempt
to copy or improve on our business model, or portions thereof, which could erode our competitive
position, market share and brand recognition and have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.

Individuals wishing to exercise have a wide variety of options available to them other than

using purpose-built health and fitness facilities. These include outdoor activities such as cycling,
running and group exercise programs, team sports, weights, personal training, fitness apps or other
online programs at home (including Peloton), participation in which increased considerably during
the temporary closure of traditional facilities as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Our inability
to stay competitive by constantly anticipating and responding to the competitive factors affecting
our industry, including the introduction of new products, services or pricing policies by our
competitors, changing consumer preferences and regional and local economic conditions, could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

We may have to lower our prices or increase our expenditure to maintain our market share.

Due to the inherent risks associated with advertising and new product introductions, including
uncertainties about consumer response, increased expenditure may not prove successful in
maintaining or enhancing our market share and could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Changes in the general economic climate and consumer preferences could have a detrimental_**
**_impact on our revenue._**

Our business is affected by changes in general economic conditions that impact consumer

confidence and discretionary spending. Our business, financial condition and results of operations
have been, and in the future may be, adversely affected by negative political and economic trends
and developments that reduce consumers’ ability or willingness to spend. In a depressed economic
and consumer environment, individuals and businesses may postpone spending in response to
factors such as negative financial news, higher unemployment, tighter credit, declines in income


-----

or asset values, increases in fuel and other energy costs, and conditions in the residential real estate
and mortgage markets. Reductions or delays in consumer spending could have a material negative
effect on the demand for our services and products. These risks are exacerbated by the fact that the
outlook for the U.K. and European economies remains highly uncertain in light of the impact of
the COVID-19 pandemic.

Our success is dependent on the continuing popularity of health and fitness in the countries

in which we operate, and the popularity of premium clubs in particular. Although we believe that
consumers increasingly view health and fitness as an essential rather than discretionary
expenditure, customers may still reduce their health and fitness spending in response to an actual
or perceived reduction in discretionary spending power. Alternative forms of fitness or venues for
fitness may become popular and trends in the type of clubs that consumers wish to join may change
in the future, especially as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Consequently, deterioration of general economic conditions in the U.K. or in the European

countries in which we operate, as well as demographic shifts in these markets, could materially
and adversely affect consumer spending habits, which in turn could have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_The success of our business depends on our ability to attract and retain club members, while_**
**_maintaining sustainable and profitable membership fees._**

As of May 31, 2021, we had approximately 632 thousand members and we had

approximately 45 thousand new member sales between May 1 and May 31, 2021. Our success is
dependent on our ability to attract and retain members to our clubs, as our revenue is mainly
generated from membership subscriptions revenue representing 78.2%, 78.2% and 80.4%,
respectively, of our total revenue for the periods ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020. As a
result, we must continually engage with existing members and attract new members in order to
maintain or increase our club membership levels. Our customers can usually terminate their
membership within one to three months’ notice once the initial term of their contract has expired,
and can also terminate their membership prior to the expiry of their contract’s initial term for a
number of reasons, including medical condition and changes in personal circumstances. We
believe, based on internal data, that most of our members typically maintain their membership
beyond the initial term of their contract, but we experience material member attrition, including
certain members who abandon their contracts before the term has expired, and we must therefore
continually engage existing members and attract new members in order to maintain our
membership levels and ancillary sales. Our inability to attract and retain club members could have
a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

There are numerous factors that could lead to a decline in membership levels or ancillary

sales in mature clubs, or that could prevent us from increasing membership and ancillary revenue
at newer clubs where membership is generally not yet at targeted levels. These factors include
changing desires and behaviors of consumers, changes in discretionary spending trends and general
economic conditions, including the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business (See “—
_The negative impact of COVID-19 on our business is significant and its effects will continue to_
_materially negatively impact our business, financial condition and results of operations due to_
_many factors, some of which are beyond our control”), the indirect local competition from_


-----

premium and other health and fitness club operators, the saturation of local health and fitness club
markets, harm to our reputation or brand, a decline in our ability to deliver a high-quality service
to our members, the increasing popularity of home fitness equipment (including Pelotons), fitness
applications and other online exercise programs, the increasing popularity of studio clubs,
freelance personal trainers and outdoor fitness activities, a decline in the public’s interest in health
and fitness and changes in the level of positive referrals from current and former members caused
by any of the aforementioned reasons. Lastly, to the extent our corporate clients are adversely
affected by negative economic conditions, they may decide, as part of expense reduction strategies,
to curtail or cancel club membership benefits provided to their employees.

There is a direct correlation between our ability to attract and retain club members and the

membership and joining fees we charge. Specifically, we are dependent on our ability to charge
membership and joining fees at a level that allows us to attract and retain members while also
generating an appropriate fee yield relative to our costs. We use flexibility on a club-by-club basis
in order to carefully vary our membership and joining fees to adapt to the local demographics and
varying levels of affluence of the areas in which we operate. While we have been able to
successfully increase our membership fees in the past without it resulting in an increase of our
attrition rates, we may not be able to do so in the future and our ability to increase such fees to offset
potential costs without suffering membership decline is limited, which could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

In order to continue to attract and retain members, we have to be able to respond to

consumer sentiment and consumer preferences, which may change rapidly and as a result of forces
outside of our control. If we fail to identify, anticipate and respond to such changes quickly, we
may lose a significant number of members. The challenges we face in attracting and retaining club
members are bolstered by the fact that our clubs target families as a whole rather than individuals
alone. As a result, it is harder to adjust our offering, and memberships are often canceled in bulk.
A decline in membership levels, membership and joining fees and profitability as a result of any
of the above factors, individually or in aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We may incur rising costs related to the maintenance of our existing clubs and construction of_**
**_any new club, and if we are unable to identify and acquire suitable existing clubs or acquire and_**
**_develop sites for any new clubs, or if we are delayed in any new club opening or not able to pass_**
**_these cost increases through to our members, the operating results of our business may be_**
**_adversely affected._**

Our clubs require significant upfront and ongoing investment. Existing clubs require

ongoing maintenance and refurbishment expenditure to maintain the quality of our facilities and
offer our members the latest high-end exercise equipment. We are also likely to incur increased
operating expenses or capital expenditures in relation to our properties in order to comply with
applicable COVID-19 related regulations as well as members’ expectations relating to measures
to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.

If we wish to grow our business through acquisitions, we will face risks related to

identifying appropriate targets, conducting effective due diligence and integrating the acquired
businesses in a timely fashion in order for any acquisitions to be accretive to earnings over the


-----

long-term. Additionally, we may be exposed to unexpected costs or liabilities resulting from
acquisitions which may not be covered by contractual representations and indemnities. If we
choose to grow our business through the development of new clubs, we will face a number of
challenges and risks. For example, we must identify and acquire sites of sufficient size with the
right demographic and other measures we employ in our selection process. We also need to
evaluate the penetration of our competitors in that market. We face significant competition (both
within and outside the health and fitness industry) for sites that meet our criteria, and as a result
we may lose those sites, or we could be forced to pay significantly higher prices for those sites. If
we are unable to identify and acquire sites for new clubs, our revenue growth rate and profits may
be negatively impacted. In addition, if our analysis of the suitability of a site is incorrect, we may
not be able to recover our capital investment in developing and building the new club.

Opening new clubs requires significant upfront investment, and a new club typically takes

approximately one year of full operations to break even, and even as we open new clubs our
underlying performance, including Adjusted EBITDA, is reduced by these losses. Upon opening
a new club, we typically experience an initial period of opening losses as the club builds its
membership base and due to the initial expense of pre-opening costs, which include legal and other
costs associated with lease negotiation and permitted use requirements, as well as depreciation and
amortization expenses. For example, we opened two new clubs between 2018 and 2020 by way of
greenfield expansions at our Acton Park and Emersons Green locations, which generated an
average loss of Adjusted EBITDA of £0.4 million. These operating losses and lower margins could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Additionally, the amount of the investment made in the opening of a new club may

materially change from the amount we have budgeted. Because of the larger average size of our
racquet clubs and because we tend to own rather than lease our clubs, our overall costs of
constructing any new club tend to be higher than our competitors’, particularly those operating in
the low cost and mid-market segments. If our actual investment in a particular club is higher than
we had planned, we may need to outperform our operational plan to achieve our targeted return.
In the event that operational performance is worse than we had initially planned, we may not be
able to achieve our targeted returns on investment. In addition, it has been our experience that
opening a new club in the catchment area of an existing club may result in some members being
detracted from the other club already operated by us, thereby diminishing that club’s revenue. If
we are unable to implement, integrate and manage our expansion plans successfully or if we are
unable to manage the risks associated with new club openings, our business, financial condition
and results of operations could be materially adversely affected. Additionally, in the process of
constructing or opening new clubs, we or our agents may breach relevant local laws and
regulations, which could subject us to fines, loss of permits, licenses or approvals to implement
and operate the relevant project, and/or other penalties.

New club openings are also subject to the risk of delays. These are caused by the need to

obtain planning consents from local authorities, if not already in place, as well as shortages of
materials or skilled labor, labor disputes, construction issues and modifications in design. If we
are significantly delayed in opening new clubs, our competitors may be able to open new clubs in
the same market or improve clubs currently open before we open ours. This change in the
competitive landscape could negatively impact our pre-opening sales of memberships and increase
our investment costs. Our ability to open new clubs on schedule depends on a number of factors,


-----

many of which are beyond our control. These factors include obtaining acceptable financing for
construction of any new site, obtaining permits and licenses necessary to complete construction of
any new club on schedule, recruiting, training and retaining qualified management and other
personnel, securing access to labor and materials necessary to develop and construct our clubs,
delays due to material shortages, labor issues, weather conditions or other acts of God, discovery
of contaminants, accidents, deaths or injunctions and general economic conditions.

In addition, we may decide to close an underperforming club and attempt to move members

of that club to a different location, or we may have to temporarily relocate members if a club is
closed for refurbishment or due to fire or other reasons. As a result of these factors, membership
levels might not be adequate to maintain or permit the expansion of our operations and a decline
in membership levels could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and
results of operations.

**_If we are unable to renew or replace our club leases or enter into leases for new clubs on_**
**_favorable terms or if any of our current leases are terminated prior to the expiry of their stated_**
**_term and we cannot find suitable alternate locations, our growth and profitability could be_**
**_harmed._**

We currently lease on a short-term basis approximately 55.7% of our club locations. These

leases expire between 2023 and 2056. Our leases provide for rent reviews, generally annually, at
which time our rents could increase and many of our leases contain upwards-only rent reviews.
Our ability to maintain our existing rental rates during renewals or to renew any expired lease on
favorable terms will depend on many factors that are not within our control, such as conditions in
the local real estate market, competition for suitable properties and our relationships with current
and prospective landlords. We have made certain assumptions about future rent reviews in respect
of our properties. If rent reviews were to be agreed at rates higher than currently anticipated, there
would be an adverse impact on the operating results of our business.

In addition, there is a risk that the leases may not be renewed in due course or at all due to,

among other factors, the state of the real estate market at such time and the competition for rental
space. If this risk materialized, we would have to identify and secure sufficient replacement sites
that meet our selection criteria. This would result in additional costs being incurred in selecting
appropriate or equally suitable alternative premises and relocating to them. Furthermore, we face
competition, typically, from other health and fitness club operators as well as other potential
occupants for suitable sites and, as a result, we may be unable to secure those sites at all, or we
could be forced to pay significantly higher rents or prices for those sites. If we are unable to identify
and secure sufficient replacement sites, or if we are forced to pay significantly higher rents for
those sites, such developments could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations.

**_We are generally unable to terminate our property leases for a specified time period from the_**
**_start of the lease and we may be obliged to pay rent and pay losses if we close a location._**

The majority of our leases do not provide a right for us to terminate the lease before the

end of the lease term, whether through the exercise of tenant-only break rights or otherwise. In
circumstances where we are unable to terminate our property leases, we may not be able to sublet


-----

or assign our leases on commercially acceptable terms or at all. Accordingly, if we close a club
prior to being able to exercise our tenant-only break right, or prior to the end of the lease term in
cases where we do not have a tenant-only break right, we may be obligated to continue to pay rent
and incur operating losses at the relevant site, which could adversely affect our business, financial
condition and results of operations. For example, although we closed our Kembrey club in 2016,
we are contractually obliged to continue making rental payments in respect of this location until
the expiry of the lease agreement related thereto, in 2032.

**_We cannot assure you that the locations of our clubs will continue to be economically viable._**

The location of our clubs has significant influence on their results of operations. We cannot

assure you that current locations will continue to be economically viable. As demographic and
economic patterns change, current locations may not continue to be attractive and profitable.
Decrease in the population of neighborhoods where our clubs are located or adverse economic
conditions in these areas and those surrounding those neighborhoods could result in reduced
revenue at the relevant clubs and our ability to terminate the leases on our existing clubs is limited
by our lease arrangements. Similarly, the COVID-19 pandemic could lead to demographic shifts
that will detrimentally impact some of our existing clubs.

Businesses in the U.K. are required to pay “business rates” for occupying a commercial

property. The U.K. government adjusts the value of business rates to reflect changes in the property
market approximately every five years. As a result of the adverse economic effects caused by the
COVID-19 pandemic, the scheduled April 1, 2021 revaluation of business rates was postponed
until 2023. However, the eventual adjustments of the business rates could result in increased estate
costs and, consequently, could have an adverse effect on the economic viability of certain clubs.
A decline in the economic viability of our clubs could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Increases in rising operating costs due to inflation and other factors may not be directly offset_**
**_by increased revenue._**

As operating costs and expenses increase due to inflation or other factors, we generally

attempt to offset the adverse effects of any increased costs by increasing prices, in line with industry
standards. We are subject to the risk that our costs of operations will increase, and we will be unable
to offset those increases through increased prices without adversely affecting demand.

In addition to inflation, increases in cost of labor, goods, rent, utilities and taxes could cause

operating costs to rise and thereby reduce our operating margins and have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In particular, labor costs may increase
due to increases in minimum pension contributions, changes in the legislative landscape, intensifying
competition for qualified personnel or personal trainers and increases in the U.K. “national living
wage” or similar laws in the other countries in which we operate. Many, and in some cases all, of
the factors affecting these costs are beyond our control. On the other hand, if our revenue declines,
we may not be able to reduce our fixed expenses (such as rent, property taxes, insurance and utilities)
by the same degree or at the same rate to preserve profitability, which could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.


-----

**_Due to the capital-intensive nature of our business, we may incur additional indebtedness in the_**
**_medium term if our cash flow or current facilities cannot support our capital requirements and,_**
**_if we are not able to access additional financing or capital as and if necessary, our ability to_**
**_operate successfully or expand our business may be impaired and our results of operations could_**
**_be adversely affected._**

Opening new clubs and maintaining existing clubs is capital intensive, and we require

significant capital to finance such activities, as well as to fund ongoing investments in our business
and to meet our debt obligations. We are pursuing a robust rollout strategy founded upon identifying
viable sites with strong demographic catchment areas, thus there can be no assurance that we may
not need to incur additional indebtedness or substantially reduce our growth plans to meet our capital
requirements in the medium-term. Raising new debt securities could increase our finance costs or be
available only on terms that restrict our business.

Any inability or delay in raising additional capital when and if required may affect our

ability to execute on our growth strategy or cause us to lose future opportunities or hinder our
ability to respond to competitive pressures, all of which could have a material adverse effect on
our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We may identify and pursue the acquisition of other health and fitness businesses or existing_**
**_clubs and may fail to successfully integrate such businesses or clubs, may assume liabilities that_**
**_we are not aware of, or such businesses or clubs may not be as profitable as we expected them_**
**_to be._**

As opportunities arise, we will continue to assess possible acquisitions of other health and

fitness operators, as well as select clubs from other health and fitness operators, to complement
