**_Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic_**

The First Lockdown

Prior to the First Lockdown, our business was performing on an upward growth trajectory,

with our latest annual price increase enacted in January 2020. Excluding the impact of the COVID19 pandemic, we generated £519.5 million of revenue, a loss of £51.5 million and £577.4 million
of Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue with a Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £170.9 million
for the year ended December 31, 2019. However, in March 2020, the governments of the U.K. and
of all European countries in which we operate imposed significant lockdown measures in order to
control the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic, including the temporary closure of almost all of
our clubs. During this First Lockdown, we decided not to charge members whilst their club was
closed, in line with our priority to retain members and treat them fairly. Consequently, almost all


-----

of our revenue ceased until the phased reopening of our clubs in Europe starting from June 3, 2020
and in the U.K. on July 25, 2020. Approximately 44 thousand members canceled their membership
during the First Lockdown, and, in contrast with the pre-COVID situation, we sold very few new
memberships because our clubs were closed, resulting in unusually high levels of net member loss
over the second half and in particular the second quarter of 2020. We also recorded negative
Adjusted EBITDA from March 2020 to July 2020.

During the First Lockdown, we reacted swiftly to minimize our costs reducing our pre-lock

down monthly operating cash outflow by 86% from £37.7 million to £5.3 million, primarily due to
cash savings from furloughing staff (£50 million in aggregate across the First Lockdown and the
Second Lockdown) and deferred rent savings (£53 million in aggregate across the First Lockdown
and the Second Lockdown) as presented in the following chart:

In addition to our costs saving initiatives, we focused on maximizing our members’

engagement and maintaining a dialogue with them. On March 23, 2020, we were one of the first
U.K. fitness, health and leisure operators to offer a remote exercise platform through the launch of
our “@home” mobile app. While memberships were frozen, we strove to keep our members
engaged with @home by offering them a weekly timetable of fitness classes and interactive events
and an extensive library of on-demand classes and tailored workout plans. Members used our
@home app not only for our signature fitness classes, but also for social events such as cooking
classes, quiz nights and make up tutorials. We also ensured that members who paid subscription
fees during months of partial closure were treated fairly by crediting their accounts with pro-rated
fees for the number of days we were closed. In addition, we kept an uninterrupted line of
communication with our members throughout the First Lockdown, giving them updates about our
reopening plans and new safety and hygiene protocols to be put in place in order to reassure them.
The success of our efforts to keep members engaged during the First Lockdown is evidenced by an
internal survey according to which 76% of them thought that the speed of communication was
“extremely good or very good” and 80.1% believed our implementation of government guidelines
was “extremely good or very good.” These high satisfaction rates served to reinforce our clubiness
and allowed us to minimize member loss during the First Lockdown to approximately 10% of our
total membership base, compared to approximately 27% for certain low-cost operators, according
to management estimates.


-----

Following the reopening of the majority of our clubs in August 2020 after the First

Lockdown, we recorded our highest ever monthly new membership sales between August 2020
and October 2020, surpassing month-on-month 2019 sales in August by 70% (29.8 thousand new
members), in September by 59% (32.0 thousand new members) and in October by 57% (26.9
thousand new members) and our prior best sales month (January 2018) in August by 28%, in
September by 37% and in October by 15% evidencing the strong demand for our offering and
services. Furthermore, monthly new membership sales in November 2020 and December 2020
were also on track to exceed month-on-month 2019 sales prior to the announcement of the Second
Lockdown. The following chart illustrates the success of our membership sales following the First
Lockdown:

The strong sales results of our clubs after the First Lockdown were recorded in spite of

fears of a looming Second Lockdown and the unavailability of vaccines at the time, which
demonstrates the appeal of our clubs where, in contrast to many of our competitors, we can
organize our activities outside and there is sufficient space to comply with social distancing rules
and COVID-19 protocols. After reopening in July 2020, based on an internal survey, our members
rated us 4.5 stars out of 5 stars for safety and wellbeing, which indicated our members and staff
felt comfortable coming back to our clubs.

Due to the recurring nature of our membership subscriptions revenue which we started

charging again upon reopening of our clubs after the First Lockdown, our business immediately
returned to profitability generating approximately £1 million, £7 million and £8 million of
Adjusted EBITDA in August, September and October 2020, respectively, as illustrated by the
following chart:


-----

The Second Lockdown

On October 31, 2020, the U.K. Prime Minister announced a second national lockdown,

which came into effect on November 5, 2020 and required the temporary re-closure of all of our
English clubs until December 2, 2020. By January 5, 2021, all of our clubs in England were forced
to close again as a result of the Second Lockdown being reinstated, with other U.K. and European
clubs following a similar pattern of closures and reopening (with the exception of two clubs in
Spain which remained open with certain operating restrictions). The chart below shows our total
number of clubs open throughout the First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown:

Consistent with our approach during the First Lockdown, club memberships in the U.K.

were frozen throughout the Second Lockdown, which led to our revenue almost ceasing during
this period. Our European clubs also generally followed the same approach. The higher number of
members leaving due to the closure of the majority of our clubs and the continued uncertainty
caused by the pandemic and our inability to sell new memberships, in contrast to pre-COVID-19
periods, resulted in a net member loss of approximately 51 thousand members during the Second
Lockdown. Based on our experience from the First Lockdown, we managed to minimize our
Adjusted EBITDA losses and cash burn during the Second Lockdown thanks to staff furloughs
and rent deferral negotiations.

April reopening

Following the Second Lockdown, the reopening of our clubs in England and Scotland has

been carried out on a staggered basis, with outdoor facilities reopening on March 29, 2021 and
indoor facilities reopening on April 12, 2021, followed by the full reopening of our Scottish clubs
on April 26, 2021. Based on recent government announcements, we anticipate the rest of our clubs
in Europe will start reopening from May 2021. Since the staggered reopening of our facilities at
the end of the Second Lockdown, our business has been performing very well. We believe that
this is partly because the more affluent segments of the population are relatively less impacted by
the COVID-19 pandemic and increased household saving rates are supporting a sustained period
of increased leisure spending. Our strong performance during April and May was also driven by
the fact that, as of March 31, 2021, 38% of our adult members were eligible for a vaccine jab on
the basis of age alone, and for those members who have elected to receive the vaccine it was safer
to return to our clubs, which was evidenced by this group accounting for 42% of attendance during
April 2021, despite making only 28% of our member count as of March 31, 2021. As of April 30,
2021, members who were 40 years and older were eligible for a vaccine jab, representing 60% of
our adult members. Furthermore, the suburban location of our clubs is allowing us to leverage the
new working-from-home trends, as members now have greater flexibility to visit our clubs during
the entire day, rather than at the usual pre- and post-working hours peak periods we used to observe
prior to the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, and some members are working from our clubs in
our business lounges.


-----

In addition, we believe that certain trends spurred on by the COVID-19 pandemic are likely

to bolster demand for our clubs, as travel restrictions in Europe will force households to look for
domestic leisure centers during the summer of 2021, while the potential closures of some of our
weaker competitors’ facilities will reduce overall market supply and correspondingly increase
demand for our services. Furthermore, research on the retail, consumer and leisure sectors from
Strategy& suggests that 80% of adults surveyed in the U.K. expect to be mindful or more mindful
about practicing regular self-care post-pandemic.

Our strong bounceback since the end of the Second Lockdown is evidenced by record new

membership sales, with 36.4 thousand new members added in April 2021 compared to 18.1
thousand new members in April 2019 at “normal” trading levels, representing an increase of 101%,
which led to a net member gain of approximately 27 thousand in April, while only 77% of our
clubs were open as of March 31, 2021 and only 84% of our clubs were open by the end of April
2021. We also recorded approximately 45 thousand new member sales between May 1 and May
31, 2021 compared to 18 thousand new members between May 1 and May 31, 2019, representing
an increase of approximately 150%. We believe that our new membership sales are likely to
continue to increase in the coming months as more clubs reopen and with key drivers of our
offering such as indoor group exercise, kids soft play, our indoor food and beverage offering and
sauna and steam rooms having resumed from May 17, 2021, allowing us to return to full capacity
in the U.K., while our European clubs also begin to reopen. Based on May 2021 levels, web traffic
(up 127.0% compared to March 2021) and web enquiries (up 218.8% compared to March 2021)
demonstrate a strong pipeline for June and July. Based on our all-time high new membership sales
and the pipeline data collected since the staggered reopening of our facilities at the end of the
Second Lockdown, we aim to reach our pre-pandemic membership base of 668 thousand members
by September 2021. The following chart illustrates our cumulative new membership sales since
March 1, 2021:

Many of our members canceled their membership during the First Lockdown and the

Second Lockdown and because our clubs were closed, we sold very few new memberships, in
contrast to normal pre-COVID-19 periods, as a result of which we had a net member loss of
approximately 94 thousand members between February 2020 and February 2021. However, our


-----

strong recovery in membership numbers since the staggered reopening of our facilities has allowed
us to recoup more than a third of these lost members in the months of March and April 2021, while
16% of our clubs had yet to reopen as of the end of April and the further relaxation of social
distancing measures in the U.K. expected to generate a further increase in membership growth, as
our indoor group exercise, kids soft play, indoor food and beverage and wellness offering have
resumed on May 17, 2021. The following chart illustrates our strong recovery in membership
numbers since February 2021:

The rapid bounceback of our membership numbers is expected to be further aided by lower

than normal attrition rates expected in the period June to September 2021 as 18% fewer members
have handed in a notice to terminate their membership as of May 31, 2021 compared to the same
position in 2019, and 22% fewer members lost during the same period compared to the 2019
position, as illustrated by the charts below:

Attrition pipeline as at 31[st] May Attrition as at 31[st] May

We expect our attrition levels in the next twelve months to remain lower compared to

normal pre-COVID-19 levels as a result of the lower sales during 2020, because historically an
element of our attrition is due to members cancelling their membership after the first year of joining
David Lloyd.

Our usage data since the end of the Second Lockdown is a further indicator of our strong

bounceback. Our average club usage from April 12, 2021 to May 30, 2021 was 28.4% higher than
it was following the reopening of our clubs at the end of the First Lockdown, which is testament
to the increasing appeal of our offering to members and increased consumer confidence. Since the
indoor facilities reopening on April 12, 2021, we have recorded an overall member attendance of
70.7%, with 70.2% of our adult membership base having attended our clubs.


-----

Due to the recurring nature of our membership subscriptions revenue which we started

charging again when our clubs reopened, the clubs that reopened immediately returned to
profitability. As a result, we expect our EBITDA to be positive again for May 2021.

**Basis of presentation**

**_Financial information of the Issuer and the Company_**

The Issuer is a newly formed entity incorporated on May 6, 2021 for purposes of facilitating

the Transactions and performing certain activities related thereto. The Issuer is a wholly owned
direct subsidiary of the Company. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer has no
revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business operations, material assets or liabilities
other than those acquired or incurred in connection with its incorporation and the Transactions. As
a result, no historical financial information of the Issuer is included in this Offering Memorandum.

The Company was incorporated on May 18, 2018 as a holding company. The Company is

indirectly owned by Deuce Holdco Limited (“HoldCo”). As of the date of this Offering
Memorandum, the Company has no revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business
operations, material assets or liabilities other than (i) certain existing indebtedness which will be
repaid with the proceeds of the Transactions (see “Use of proceeds”) and (ii) a £2.0 million annual
monitoring fee payable to TDR Capital. As a result, no historical financial information of the
Company is included in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Historical Financial Information of Holdco_**

The consolidated historical and other financial data presented in this Offering

Memorandum have been derived from (i) the audited consolidated financial statements of HoldCo
as of and for the period from January 4, 2018 to December 31, 2018 and as of and for the years
ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, including the accompanying notes thereto, which have been
prepared in accordance with IFRS and which have been audited by Deloitte LLP and (ii) the
unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of HoldCo as of and for the three
months ended March 31, 2021, including accompanying notes thereto (with comparable financial
information for the three months ended March 31, 2020), which have been prepared in accordance
with IAS 34 Interim Financial Reporting, in each case included elsewhere in this Offering
Memorandum. References to the “Group,” “us” or “our” in the context of historical financial
information or other financial information relate to HoldCo and its subsidiaries. The audit reports
for the period from January 4, 2018 to December 31, 2018 and as of and for the years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, express an
unqualified opinion for each of the respective periods and the audit report in relation to the audited
consolidated financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 include a
material uncertainty paragraph related to going concern as set forth in Note 2 to such financial
statements.

IFRS 16 (Leases) was published on January 13, 2016 by the International Accounting

Standard Board. It became effective on January 1, 2019 and applies to the first full financial year
commencing on or after that date. Our first full financial year following the effective date of IFRS
16 began on January 1, 2019, and we applied the modified retrospective approach of adopting the


-----

new standard, which did not require a restatement of comparative results for the financial period
ended December 31, 2018. On adoption of IFRS 16, the Group recognized lease liabilities in
relation to leases which had previously been classified as “operating leases” under the principles
of IAS 17. These liabilities were measured at the present value of the remaining lease payments,
discounted using the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate as of January 1, 2019. The weighted
average lessee’s incremental borrowing rate applied to the lease liabilities on January 1, 2019 was
6.8%. For leases previously classified as “finance leases,” the carrying amount of the lease asset
and lease liability immediately before transition were recognized as the carrying amount of the
right-of-use asset and the lease liability at the date of initial application. For more information on
the adoption of IFRS 16 and the adjustments made in relation thereto, see “Management’s
_discussion and analysis of financial conditions and results of operations—Factors affecting_
_comparability of our results of operations—Adoption of IFRS 16” and Note 33 to the HoldCo_
consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2019.

During the year ended December 31, 2020, we identified that both deferred tax asset

balances and reserves had been understated by £21 million as of December 31, 2019. As a result,
we have restated the consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2019. As
mentioned above, the Group adopted IFRS 16 Leases retrospectively with the cumulative effect of
its application being recognized as of January 1, 2019, but did not restate comparatives for the
2018 reporting period, as permitted under the specific transition provisions in the standard. The
adjustments arising from the new leasing rules were therefore recognized in the opening balance
sheet on January 1, 2019. There were no errors related to the adoption of IFRS 16 itself. The error
was restricted to the deferred tax calculation. The misstatement of the deferred tax balances related
to the complexities of the adoption of IFRS 16 Leases retrospectively from January 1, 2019. There
is no impact on the consolidated income statement for the year ended December 31, 2019 and the
effect on the consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2019 was to increase
the opening January 1, 2019 deferred tax assets by £21 million and to reduce accumulated losses
as of January 1, 2019 by £21 million.

In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain financial and other operating data as of

and for the year ended December 31, 2019. In addition to its usefulness as regards our historical
performance, this data represents the ordinary course operations of our business in a steady state,
before the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. We have also presented the historical financial and
other operating data as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the three months ended
March 31, 2021, which represents the impact on our business of the COVID-19 pandemic as the
majority of our clubs were closed during the First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown (each as
defined herein).

Our consolidated financial statements include the results of operations and financial

position of HoldCo, which are not attributable to the Company or its subsidiaries. As a result, the
consolidated financial statements of HoldCo are not directly comparable to the historical financial
information of the Company and its subsidiaries, which is prepared in accordance with IFRS. The
main differences between the consolidated financial position and results of operations of HoldCo
and the Company (i) as of and for the period from January 4, 2018 to December 31, 2018, related

-----

amounted to £5.9 million; (ii) as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, related to the

respectively, and £0.1 million additional finance cost incurred by the Company in relation to

the three months ended March 31, 2020, related to the balance of a shareholder loan from HoldCo
to its shareholder and cash on balance sheet held under HoldCo’s name, which amounted to £2.1
million and £1.5 million, respectively, and a £5.7 million shareholder loan from HoldCo to the
Company and (v) as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2021, related to the balance of a
shareholder loan from HoldCo to Deuce TopCo Limited and cash on balance sheet held under
HoldCo’s name, which amounted to £2.2 million and £1.4 million, respectively, and a £6.0 million
shareholder loan from HoldCo to the Company. As such differences are not material, the financial
and operating results and certain other information relating to HoldCo have been presented in this
Offering Memorandum in lieu of the Company. We believe that HoldCo’s consolidated financial
statements, subject to the differences noted above, adequately reflect the Company’s consolidated
financial results and financial position for the applicable periods.

**Factors affecting comparability of our results of operations**

**_Adoption of IFRS 16_**

IFRS 16 (Leases) was published on January 13, 2016 by the International Accounting

Standard Board. It became effective on January 1, 2019 and applies to the first full financial year
commencing on or after that date. Our first full financial year following the effective date of IFRS
16 began on January 1, 2019, and we applied the modified retrospective approach of adopting the
new standard, which did not require a restatement of comparative results for the financial period
ended December 31, 2018.

On adoption of IFRS 16, the Group recognized lease liabilities in relation to leases which

had previously been classified as “operating leases” under the principles of IAS 17. These
liabilities were measured at the present value of the remaining lease payments, discounted using
the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate as of January 1, 2019. The weighted average lessee’s
incremental borrowing rate applied to the lease liabilities on January 1, 2019 was 6.8%. For leases
previously classified as “finance leases,” the carrying amount of the lease asset and lease liability
immediately before transition were recognized as the carrying amount of the right-of-use asset and
the lease liability at the date of initial application.

Due to the high number of leased assets that the Group holds, the application of IFRS 16

resulted in a right-of-use asset of £904.4 million and a lease liability of £838.5 million on our
statement of financial position as of January 1, 2019. The adjustments recognized in our statement
of financial position on January 1, 2019 as a result of the adoption of IFRS 16 are as follows:

**Key factors affecting our results of operations**

Our operations and the operating metrics discussed below have been, and may continue to

be, affected by certain key factors as well as certain historical events and actions. The key factors
affecting the ordinary course of our business and our results of operations are discussed below.

**_Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic_**

For the reasons discussed above under “—Recent developments—Impact of the COVID-19

_pandemic,” we expect our financial condition and results of operations to differ in respect of the_
current year and for future periods when compared to the 2018, 2019 and 2020 historical financial
condition and results of operation presented in this discussion.

**_Capital expenditures_**

We distinguish three types of capital expenditures: Pipeline Capital Expenditure,

Investment Capital Expenditure and Maintenance Capital Expenditure.

Pipeline Capital Expenditure is the discretionary spend relating to the expansion of our

facilities through the development or acquisition of new sites. Opening new clubs requires


-----

significant upfront investment, whether we are refitting existing facilities or building them anew,
including pre-opening costs such as legal and other costs associated with lease negotiation and
permitted use requirements. The costs we incur in connection with the opening of new clubs are
especially significant because of the premium segment of the health and fitness industry in which
we operate. It takes a club typically three to four full years of operations to reach Adjusted
EBITDA maturity. We follow a selective, value-enhancing approach towards new club
acquisitions and developments, targeting a minimum unlevered return on our investment-related
capital expenditures of 15 to 20% when we look to acquire a freehold property. The initial upfront
capital cost for new clubs was £8.8 million for the period ended January 3, 2018, relating to
investments in our Aravaca, Harrogate and Malaspina clubs, £25.4 million for the period ended
December 31, 2018, relating to investments in our Harrogate, Acton Park, Malaspina, Geneva,
Emersons Green and Bad Homburg clubs, £19.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019,
relating to investments in our Emersons Green, Bad Homburg, Bicester, Acton Park and Geneva
clubs and £0.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, relating to investments in our Bad
Homburg club. See also “—Acquisitions.”

Investment Capital Expenditure is the discretionary spend comprising refurbishment works

and club upgrades that improve an existing club’s offering, resulting in increased satisfaction rates,
membership count and membership yields. In addition, Investment Capital Expenditure also
relates to new developments and investments in our clubs, such as the development of group
exercise spaces such as our Blaze studios, extensive refits and the development of spa facilities,
all of which serve to improve our product offering, enhance the quality of our services and increase
member satisfaction. Our Investment Capital Expenditure was £21.9 million for the period ended
January 3, 2018 relating primarily to refits of our newly acquired Virgin Active clubs, £17.7
million (or 3.7% of our total revenue) for the period ended December 31, 2018 relating primarily
to the rollout of our Blaze Studios, £38.2 million (or 7.4% of our total revenue) for the year ended
December 31, 2019 relating primarily to extensive refits of our Cambridge, Chigwell and
Warrington clubs and the rollout of our Spa Retreats and £4.5 million (or 1.7% of our total revenue)
for the year ended December 31, 2020 relating primarily to the Spa Retreats being added to our
Northwood and Cheadle clubs. Our refurbishment program conducted from 2013 to 2017 equipped
us with a well-invested estate and has delivered returns of more than 40% on our investments.
Phase 1 of our investment plan was completed in 2014 and comprised a £22.1 million investment
into 18 clubs, an average of £1.2 million per club. Phase 2 was completed in 2015 and comprised
a £18.8 million investment into 18 clubs, with an average of £1 million per club. Phase 3 was
completed in 2016 and comprised a £32.4 million investment into 41 clubs, with an average of
£800,000 per club. We achieved a 43% return on investment from phase 1 with an increase of £9.5
million in club Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017, a 42% return on
investment from phase 2 with an increase of £7.9 million in club Adjusted EBITDAR for twelve
months ended June 30, 2017 and a 48% return on investment from phase 3 with an increase of
£15.5 million in club Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended June 30, 2018, in each case
compared to the club Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended prior to the investment of
the capital expenditure. Investment Capital Expenditure typically allows us to increase our average
yield above RPI levels, increase our number of members and improve our membership mix, in
each case at the relevant clubs. For example, following the Investment Capital Expenditure spent
on the rollout of our Spa Retreats, we introduced a more expensive “Spa Retreat” membership
package, and following the rollout of our Blaze studios, we told new members that they had to
purchase our “platinum” membership package in order to access the Blaze studios, leading in each


-----

case to an increased average yield for the relevant clubs. In addition, these investments attracted
new members and encouraged existing members to subscribe to more expensive packages, thereby
bolstering our membership mix.

Maintenance Capital Expenditure is our spend required to keep our facilities at a high

standard and to support our back-office services, such as IT and network services. Maintenance
Capital Expenditure includes expenses related to kitting out our facilities with the latest, highestquality equipment and replacing such equipment on a regular basis, undertaking cyclical
refurbishment programs (on average, every seven years per club) in order to retain freshness in
club appearance and provision for identified dilapidations and emergency repair works. We believe
the maintenance and refurbishments works funded by Maintenance Capital Expenditure help us to
justify increasing our average yield at RPI levels.

Management estimates the required through-cycle requirement for Maintenance Capital

Expenditure to range from 5.5% to 6.0% of mature revenue per annum. Our Maintenance Capital
Expenditure is driven by the usage of our facilities and the mix of new and old clubs. Our
Maintenance Capital Expenditure was £19.8 million for the period ended January 3, 2018, £26.3
million for the period ended December 31, 2018, £28.8 million for the year ended December 31,
2019 and £21.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Between 2017 and 2019, our
Maintenance Capital Expenditure represented 5.2%, on average, of our yearly total revenue. In
2020, we incurred approximately £1.2 million in capital expenditure in connection with the
installation of sanitizing devices and temperature sensors in our clubs to ensure compliance with
the latest COVID-19 safety protocols. While Maintenance Capital Expenditure is required in order
to run our business, it can also be decreased significantly during a set period of time without a
major impact on the business, which offers us additional flexibility in managing our capital
expenditures.

**_Membership volumes_**

We derive the vast majority of our revenue from membership subscriptions revenue

(78.2%, 78.2% and 80.4% of our total revenue in the period ended December 31, 2018 and the
years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020) paid by our club members, which includes
administration and joining fees. We also generate ancillary revenue, including retail revenue from
our food and beverage offering, childcare, wellness and miscellaneous sources such as
merchandizing sales and other revenue from personal training sessions, swimming and tennis
tuition. See “Description of key income statement items—Revenue.” Ancillary revenue (including
retail and other revenue) represented 21.8%, 21.8% and 19.6% of our revenue in the period ended
December 31, 2018 and the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020. Accordingly, each of the
categories of our revenue is significantly dependent on membership volumes. Membership
volumes are affected by numerous factors, including the total number of clubs in operation, the
price of our membership offerings, the sizes and locations of our clubs and competitive dynamics
in the premium club market, among others. Our membership volumes and revenue for the year
ended December 31, 2020 were significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. See “—Recent
_developments—Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.”_

Our membership has grown from 608,602 members as of December 31, 2018 to 626,120

members as of December 31, 2019, representing a CAGR of 2.9%. This growth has been driven


-----

primarily by existing business, the organic rollout of our clubs in the U.K., the maturation of
recently opened clubs and the acquisition of high-value club portfolios in Europe. Due to the
uncertainty caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and the closure of our clubs during 2020, our
membership has declined in 2020 and the first quarter of 2021 from 626,120 members as of
December 31, 2019 to approximately 580,005 as of March 31, 2021. This negative trend resulting
from the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic was partly offset when our clubs reopened at the end
of the First Lockdown. We recorded our highest ever monthly new membership sales between
August 2020 and October 2020, which resulted in a net member gain of approximately three
thousand members between August 2020 and October 2020.

**_Average yield_**

Our revenue is also dependent on the membership fees we charge as part of our

membership subscription revenue, as 76.6% and 77.2% of our total revenue in the period ended
December 31, 2018 and the year ended December 31, 2019, respectively, was generated from
membership fees, excluding administration and joining fees. Growth in our membership fees is
driven by an increasing average yield, which represents the average monthly membership fee paid
per member calculated by dividing the total membership fees received in a period by the average
member count for such period and by dividing the result thereof by 12. Our average yield is a
function of the prices we charge for membership packages and the mix of membership packages
sold.

Our average yield for the period ended December 31, 2018 and the year ended December

31, 2019 on a like-for-like basis was £52.6 and £54.3. We do not present like-for-like average
monthly yield for the year ended December 31, 2020 because our membership fees were frozen
for a significant part of such period due to the COVID-19 pandemic, while our average member
count did not substantially fluctuate during such period. We therefore believe that like-for-like
average monthly yield for the year ended December 31, 2020 was not representative of what our
like-for-like average monthly yield would have been if we had not frozen our membership fees
during such period.


-----

The below chart shows the yearly evolution of our average yield and its correlation to our

total number of members on a like-for-like basis:

We are dependent on our ability to charge fees at a level that allows us to attract and retain

members while also maintaining the most profitable member mix in order to generate an
appropriate fee yield. Membership fees are set locally on a club-by-club basis based on the local
demographics and varying levels of affluence of the areas in which we operate ensuring the optimal
number of members per club and taking into account the price elasticity of members of the
respective club. In general, during the periods under review we have been able to increase our
membership fees on a yearly basis above RPI levels without increasing attrition, mainly due to
high customer satisfaction as our members value the high standard and improved offering of our
facilities resulting from our Maintenance Capital Expenditure and Investment Capital Expenditure.

**_Fixed operating costs_**

We benefit from high operating leverage resulting from our fixed cost base. Our costs are

split across cost of sales, administrative expenses and other operating expenses. In December 2020,
we implemented our Fit For Growth Program which is expected to yield approximately £10 million
of annual labor cost savings from 2021 onwards compared to our labor costs for the year ended
December 31, 2019. The program was implemented following a full review of club structures,
duty manager shifts and benchmarking of departmental hours as well as an increased focus on
digital solutions to cut down on certain of our staff and overhead costs. While cost control is
important, our primary focus is on delivering a best in class service for our members.

_Cost of sales_

Cost of sales represents the costs involved in generating all retail and other revenue,

including food and beverage consumables, staff for all sports lessons and personal training sessions
and stock costs incurred in connection with product sales, whether online or onsite.

Our staff costs include costs related to personal coaches and fitness specialists, sales teams,

service personnel, as well as a host of freelance class instructors, some of which create additional
costs that our competitors in the value and mid-market segments of the market can typically avoid.
Our staff costs generally increase as a result of growing headcount and inflation. Staff costs within
our cost of sales grew from £59.6 million for the period ended January 3, 2016 to £84.1 million
for the period ended December 31, 2019.

Our food and beverage consumable and stock costs in connection with product sales are

related to our ancillary revenue and increase or decrease depending on the fluctuation of our


-----

ancillary revenue. Costs related to our food and beverage consumable and stock costs grew from
£32.2 million, including £0.1 million of overheads, for the period ended January 3, 2016 to £46.0
million, including £0.1 million of overheads, for the period ended December 31, 2019.

_Administrative expenses_

Administrative expenses comprise the costs incurred in administering our operations,

including head office and operational overheads, marketing, insurance, professional fees, credit
card and bank charges as well as IT and office costs. We employ a number of marketing
professionals in our home office to increase brand awareness and recognition. In recent years, we
have made substantial investments into our head office in order to facilitate continued innovation
and differentiation, to gain more control over our information technology system and ensure that
our management and technology infrastructure are sufficient to support our existing clubs as well
as our future growth plans.

Our operational overheads included in the administrative expenses generally increase as a

result of growing headcount and inflation. Our operational overheads within our administrative
expenses grew from £7.6 million for the period ended January 3, 2016 to £9.5 million for the
period ended December 31, 2019.

Our club support costs included in the administrative expenses relate to professional fees

and office costs. Our club support costs within our administrative expenses grew from £26.8
million for the period ended January 3, 2016 to £31.3 million for the period ended December 31,
2019.

_Other operating expenses_

Other operating expenses comprise expenses related to rent costs, business rates, utilities,

cleaning and laundry, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible
assets as well as maintenance and repairs and exceptional items.

Our rent costs include costs related to our real estate leases and constituted £53.3 million

for the period ended January 3, 2016, on an adjusted basis to reflect £16.0 million of additional
rent costs payable following the completion of the sale and leaseback of a portfolio of clubs to
M&G, and £63.3 million for the period ended December 31, 2018. Rent costs as they would have
been recorded under IAS 17 were £72.7 million and £73.6 million, respectively, for the years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020, representing 13.1%, 14.2% and 28.4% of our revenue for the period
ended December 31, 2018 and the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020. On a like-for-like
basis, our rent costs constituted £58.2 million for the period ended December 31, 2018 and £58.9
million and £58.9 million as they would have been recorded under IAS 17 for the years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020. Increases in rent costs were primarily driven by inflation.

Our other costs, including overheads and club support costs, included in the other operating

expenses are generally consistent across all our clubs and do not typically vary significantly on an
individual basis. Such costs relate to cleaning and maintenance expenses which are driven by the
number of clubs, usage of our equipment and inflation. The business rates we pay are reviewed on
a 5-year cycle. We aim to control our operating costs through the efficient use of our utilities, such


-----

as lighting and waste management, and we evaluate the terms of our contracts with our utility
providers on an ongoing basis. Our overheads within our other operating expenses grew from
£67.2 million for the period ended January 3, 2016 to £100.7 million for the period ended
December 31, 2019. Our club support costs within our other operating expenses grew from £0.6
million for the period ended January 3, 2016 to £0.7 million for the period ended December 31,
2019.

Our staff costs included in the other operating expenses include costs related to our

maintenance and service personnel. Our staff costs within our other operating expenses grew from
£20.4 million for the period ended January 3, 2016 to £32.3 million for the period ended December
31, 2019.

Depreciation for the period ended December 31, 2018 includes depreciation of land and

buildings and equipment and constituted £43.9 million. Depreciation for the years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020 includes depreciation of land and buildings and equipment and rightof-use assets and constituted £77.0 million and £73.1 million. Increases in our depreciation over
the periods under review were mainly driven by the impact of IFRS 16. Amortization includes
amortization of goodwill, brands, software & licenses and leasehold health clubs intangibles and
constituted £8.0 million, £11.3 million and £8.0 million for the period ended December 31, 2018
and the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020.

Exceptional items include impairment of property, plant and equipment, impairment of

right-of-use assets, impairment of intangible assets, costs of lease re-negotiations, business
restructuring, acquisition related costs, impairment of investment and India joint venture losses.
Exceptional items constituted £13.0 million, £14.4 million and £37.8 million for the period ended
December 31, 2018 and the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020. The increase in exceptional
items in the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the year ended December 31, 2019 was
due to our costs incurred in relation to our lease re-negotiations during the year which we did not
incur in 2019 and a larger impairment recorded on our right-of-use assets as a result of the impact
of COVID-19 following our annual impairment review in 2020.

_Like-for-like data_

Our like-for-like staff costs grew at a CAGR of 3.6% from £79 million for the

period ended January 3, 2016 to £91 million for the period ended December 31, 2019. Our likefor-like overheads grew at a CAGR of 4.3% from £73 million for the period ended January 3, 2016
to £87 million for the period ended December 31, 2019. Our like-for-like club support grew at a
CAGR of 4.4% from £27 million for the period ended January 3, 2016 to £32 million for the period
ended December 31, 2019. Our rent costs grew at a CAGR of 2.8% from £53 million for the period
ended January 3, 2016 to £59 million for the period ended December 31, 2019.

**_Acquisitions_**

In the periods under review, we made certain acquisitions which have affected our results

of operations. We proactively manage our club portfolio by pursuing value-enhancing strategic
acquisitions of small portfolios as well as standalone sites in Europe, in line with our overall
growth plan. Our most recent significant acquisitions are:


-----

- Virgin Active: in June 2017, we acquired 14 U.K. racquet clubs with approximately 74
thousand members from Virgin Active, one of our direct competitors, for a purchase price of
£62.9 million which was paid on May 31, 2017. The Adjusted EBITDA generated by these 14
Virgin Active clubs has more than doubled since our acquisition, from £8.7 million for the year
ended December 31, 2017 to £18.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 (on a pro
forma run rate adjusted basis).

- Bad Homburg: in June 2018, we expanded our operations into the German market with the
purchase of a HealthCity-branded club in Bad Homburg, near Frankfurt, for a purchase price
of approximately £1.6 million, which was paid on June 1, 2018.

- Meridian: in January 2020, we acquired the Hamburg Meridian Group, which operates eight
premium health and spa clubs in Germany, for a purchase price of approximately £69.0 million,
which was paid on January 30, 2020.

- Geneva: in September 2020, we purchased a country club in the affluent, high-potential
Bellevue suburb of Geneva in Switzerland, for a purchase price of approximately £9 million,
which was paid on September 30, 2020.

**_Changing consumer preferences and prevailing macroeconomic conditions_**

Our financial results are impacted by changes in consumer habits and preferences within

the U.K. and Europe. Examples of changes in consumer habits that have favorably impacted our
financial performance include long-term growth in the eating-out market, focus on overall
customer experience, fitness and wellbeing being perceived as an essential rather than
discretionary expenditure, the growing appeal of working-from-home arrangements and an
increase in popularity of clubs attracting entire families. On the other hand, if members’
preferences evolve in such a way that outdoor activities such as cycling, running, team sports,
weights, fitness apps or other online programs at home become favored at the expenses of purposebuilt health and fitness facilities, particularly in light of consumer behavior during the COVID-19
pandemic, we are likely to experience a decline in our revenue. See “Industry.” Because changes
in consumer preferences and trends have historically impacted our financial results, we strive to
anticipate, identify and respond to such changes by evolving our brands and offering adequately
and in a timely fashion.

Changes in the general macroeconomic environment may also have an impact on the appeal

of our clubs. The outlook for the U.K. economy is currently subject to significant uncertainty,
particularly in light of the impact of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit, which may lead
the U.K. into a prolonged period of economic downturn, recession or depression. Our business is
also subject to macroeconomic factors such as interest rates, disposable income, unemployment
rates, taxes, consumer credit levels and house prices, which has a bearing on the level of consumer
confidence and, in turn, the level of consumer spending on eating and drinking out and other leisure
activities.

**Description of key income statement items**

**_Revenue_**

Revenue is derived from the provision of goods and services across the full range of our

differentiated offering, including our state-of-the-art gyms, swimming pools, racquet facilities,
group exercise studios, luxurious spas as well as our restaurants and bars. Revenue is measured at
the fair value of the consideration received or receivable and represents amounts receivable for
goods and services provided in the normal course of business, net of discounts, VAT and other
sales-related taxes. Our revenue stems from two main sources: membership subscriptions and
ancillary revenue. Ancillary revenue is split into six categories, which are, in descending order of
importance: food and beverage, personal training sessions, swimming and tennis tuition, childcare,
wellness and miscellaneous.

- Membership subscriptions revenue:

`o` Membership fees: can be paid annually in full or monthly by direct debit. Subscriptions
are recognized over the period of the membership, with any subscriptions received in
advance of the period in which the service is provided being recorded as a contract
liability on the statement of financial position.

`o` Administration and joining fees: are paid upfront and are non-refundable. They
represent a fee for the initial set-up costs of the contract and for the right to renew the
membership for no additional fee when such contract expires. Revenue is recognized
over the average membership period, when performance obligations are performed,
including any period of renewal. Revenue relating to future periods of membership are
recognized as contract liabilities in the statement of financial position.

- Ancillary revenue:

`o` Food and beverage (retail revenue): food and beverage is the largest contributor of our
total ancillary revenue, with a strong growth supported by frequent menu changes and
frequent investments into our facilities.

`o` Personal training (other revenue): personal training demand continues to grow as more
members partake in our “PT Journey” program. Personal training sessions are paid for
monthly by direct debit, via @home or on the date they are taken. The revenue is
recognized in the month they are paid for, because this is when the performance
obligation is satisfied. The period over which this revenue should be recognized
requires judgement. See “—Critical accounting estimates and judgments.” Revenue
received in relation to future periods is recognized as a contract liability on the
statement of financial position.

`o` Tuition (other revenue): swimming and tennis lessons are predominately driven by
children’s coaching lessons, with growth generated by the increasing mix of children
in our membership base. Swimming and tennis lessons are paid for upfront at the
beginning of the term or monthly by direct debit. Revenue is recognized over the period


-----

that lessons are provided, and any upfront payment is recognized as a contract liability
on the statement of financial position.

`o` Childcare (other revenue): comprises all of our child-oriented products and services,
including children’s parties, crèche services and “David Lloyd Holiday Camps,” which
have all been growing as a result of our increased child count and longer crèche
operating hours.

`o` Wellness (other revenue): includes all revenue generated through our high-quality wet
spa facilities, our full range of onsite treatments, including aromatherapy, massage,
acupuncture and beauty treatments, physiotherapy and physical rehabilitation services
with qualified physiotherapists as well as a select number of Spa Retreats.

`o` Miscellaneous (retail revenue): represents revenue from sales and other merchandise,
whether sold online or from our physical premises, including nutritional educational
programs, hairdressers, barbers, beauty care and various on-demand tutorials offered
in the form of “pop-up” stands on our premises, for which revenue is always recognized
at the point of sale.

**_Cost of sales_**

Cost of sales represents the costs involved in generating all ancillary revenue, including

food and beverage consumables, labor for all sports lessons and personal training sessions and
stock costs incurred in connection with product sales, whether online or onsite.

**_Gross profit_**

Gross profit is calculated as revenue less cost of sales.

**_Other income_**

Other income relates to support funds received from government grants in the U.K. and

Europe, which are not recognized until there is reasonable assurance that we will comply with the
conditions attaching to them and that the grants will be received. Government grants are
recognized in profit or loss on a systematic basis over the periods in which we recognize expenses
related to the costs for which the grants are intended to compensate.

**_Administrative expenses_**

Administrative expenses comprise the costs incurred in administering our operations,

including head office and operational labor costs, marketing, insurance, professional fees, credit
card and bank charges as well as IT and office costs.


-----

**_Other operating expenses_**

Other operating expenses comprise expenses related to rent costs, business rates, utilities,

cleaning and laundry, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible
assets as well as maintenance and repairs.

**_Profit/(loss) on disposals of PP&E_**

Profit/(loss) on disposals of PP&E includes the gain or loss arising on the disposal or

scrappage of an asset, which is determined as the difference between the sales proceeds and the
carrying amount of the relevant asset.

**_Operating profit_**

Operating profit is calculated as gross profit less administrative expenses, other operating

expenses and profit/loss on disposals of PP&E.

**_Net finance costs_**

Net finance costs are finance costs net of finance income. Finance costs represent interest

on bank loans, notes, lease liabilities, amortization of debt issue costs, and certain other interest
expenses. Finance costs are recognized using the effective interest method. Finance income
represents interest accrued on our overnight bank deposits, which we recognize as it accrues using
the effective interest method.

**_Income tax credit on ordinary activities_**

Income tax credit on ordinary activities comprises current and deferred tax. Current tax is

the expected tax payable or receivable on the taxable income or loss for the relevant period, using
tax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date, and any adjustment to tax payable
or receivable in respect of previous years. Deferred tax is recognized in respect of temporary
differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes
and the amounts used for taxation purposes. Deferred tax is recognized, without discounting, in
respect of all timing differences between the treatment of certain items for taxation and accounting
purposes which have arisen but not been reversed by the balance sheet date, except as otherwise
required by International Accounting Standard 12.

**Liquidity and capital resources**

Our liquidity requirements are primarily related to the need to fund our debt servicing

requirements, working capital and investments in capital expenditure. Historically, our principal
sources of liquidity have been our net cash generated from operating activities and borrowings
under our financing arrangements, including, inter alios, the revolving credit facilities entered into
with Barclays Bank PLC and Lloyds Bank plc and certain loan notes issued by the Company to
Talos Capital Designated Activity Company, TCI REP INTERNATIONAL ICAV, an Irish
collective asset-management vehicle acting solely in respect of its sub-fund TCI REP
INTERNATIONAL FUND III and The Children’s Investment Master Fund as original
noteholders.


-----

Following the Transactions, our principal sources of liquidity will primarily be our net cash

generated from operating activities, proceeds from the Equity Contribution and borrowings under
the Notes and the New Revolving Credit Facility pursuant to the New Revolving Facilities
Agreement. The New Revolving Credit Facility, which we expect to be undrawn on the Issue Date,
will provide for an aggregate principal amount of up to £125.0 million in revolving credit and,
subject to certain exceptions and conditions, amounts may be borrowed, repaid and reborrowed
thereunder at any time for general corporate purposes. For further information, see “Description
_of other financing arrangements—New Revolving Facilities Agreement.”_

After the completion of the Transactions, we will have £903.0 million equivalent in

aggregate principal amount of Notes outstanding. The Issuer is a special purpose finance
subsidiary with no material operations or assets of its own. As a result, the Issuer will primarily
depend on the cash flow generated by the operating subsidiaries of the Group and paid to the Issuer
by way of interest payments under, or repayments of, intercompany loans, dividend distributions
or otherwise to meet its obligations, including its obligations under the Notes. The Issuer’s ability
to pay cash interest on the Notes offered hereby will be determined by its cash available for debt
service.

As of March 31, 2021, after giving pro forma effect to the Transactions, the Issuer and the

Guarantors would have had £903.0 million equivalent in aggregate principal amount of third party
financial indebtedness, excluding the £928.1 million of lease liabilities under IFRS 16, of which
£903.0 million equivalent was secured.

While we believe that following the Transactions we will have sufficient liquidity and

capital resources to meet our current operating requirements, our ability to generate cash depends
on our future operating performance, which is in turn dependent on a variety of factors, many of
which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in the section titled “Risk factors.”
For further information, see the section titled “Capitalization.”

**Quantitative and qualitative disclosures about market risk**

We are exposed to the following risks related to the use of financial instruments:

- liquidity risk;

- price risk;

- interest rate risk;

- foreign exchange risk;

- capital risk; and

- credit risk.

**_Liquidity risk_**

Liquidity risk arises from the Group’s management of working capital, loan facilities and

the finance charges on our debt instruments. In order to ensure that the Group always has sufficient
cash to meet its liabilities, we seek to maintain cash balances (or agreed facilities) to meet expected
requirements according to predicted cash flows. The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our
liquidity was significant. As a result, our liquidity in the next 12 months will be influenced by the
trading performance of clubs when open and any periods of club closure due to further disruption
caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. During the First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown, we
had no income and operated with a monthly cash burn of approximately £5 million. The impact of
the COVID-19 pandemic on our business is considered a going concern, as further disclosed in
note 2 to our consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2020.


-----

**_Price risk_**

We are exposed to increases in the price of electricity and gas. The Group manages its

exposure to electricity and gas price risk by purchasing its utility requirements in advance through
industry leading advisers. For 2021, 75% of our U.K. electricity volumes and 63% of our U.K. gas
volumes were purchased in advance. Unused utility volumes are sold back to the market, leaving
the Group liable for any losses due to lower pricing. We have recently extended our electricity
supply contract to October 2022.

Inflation risk is the risk that the cost of key services and products procured by the Group

will rise with inflation and affect the Group’s margin. A large proportion of the Group’s leasehold
rents are subject increases related to retail and consumer price indexed, which present an ongoing
risk. The Group has comprehensive cost control processes in place to ensure these inflation driven
risks are minimized.

If membership price changes do not reflect market sensitivities and elasticities, this may

result in a corresponding decrease in revenue and profit through higher attrition or eroded margins.
The Group has a comprehensive pricing policy which is reviewed annually to ensure this risk is
mitigated.

The Group’s U.K. employees are subject to the Working Time Regulations. On April 1,

2020, the national hourly living wage in the U.K. increased to £8.72 per hour for individuals aged
25 or more, and to £8.91 per hour for individuals aged 23 or more, effective from April 1, 2021.
In response, the Group has introduced a minimum hourly rate above both the national minimum
wage and the national living wage. On April 1, 2020, we increased our minimum hourly rate to
£8.82 per hour for all employees, and on April 1, 2021, we increased it further to £9.00 per hour,
in each case irrespective of age. These increases minimize the Group’s exposure to further
increases in the national living wage regulations.

**_Interest rate risk_**

The Group’s sensitivity to changes in interest rates is limited because part of our existing

financing arrangements, which will be repaid in full as part of the Transactions, have a fixed rate
of 10%. The Euro Notes will be subject to variable rates based on EURIBOR. The New Revolving
Credit Facility will be subject to variable rates based on EURIBOR, LIBOR and SONIA. We
monitor interest rates on a regular basis and react accordingly.

**_Foreign exchange risk_**

Foreign exchange risk arises when individual Group entities enter into transactions

denominated in a currency other than their functional currency. The Group’s policy is, where
possible, to allow Group entities to settle liabilities denominated in their functional currency with
the cash generated from their own operations in that currency. Where Group entities have liabilities
denominated in a currency other than their functional currency (and have insufficient reserves of
that currency to settle them), cash already denominated in that currency will, where possible, be
transferred from elsewhere within the Group.


-----

**_Capital risk_**

Capital risk arises from the management of the capital structure, which primarily consists

of the loans and borrowings detailed in Note 23 to the consolidated financial statements for the
year ended December 31, 2020 as well as shareholder equity. Our capital structure is managed to
ensure that the Group can remain a going concern, and to maximize shareholder funds. Detailed
cash flow forecasts based on expected working capital requirements and expected capital projects
are maintained throughout the year to ensure that the Group has sufficient funds to operate as a
going concern using the available facilities.

**_Credit risk_**

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument

fails to meet its contractual obligations. The Group’s credit risk is primarily attributable to its trade
debtors. The credit risk of the Group is minimized due to the fact that a large number of customers
generally pay by direct debit in advance.

**Critical accounting estimates and judgments**

Estimates and judgements are continually evaluated and are based on historical experience

and other factors, including expectations of future events that are believed to be reasonable under
the circumstances. We make estimates and assumptions concerning the future. The estimates and
assumptions that have a significant risk of causing a material adjustment to the carrying amounts
of assets and liabilities within the next financial year are addressed below.

**_Lease accounting_**

_Lease payments_

Our lease payments are discounted using the lessee's incremental borrowing rate, being the

rate that the individual lessee would have to pay to borrow the funds necessary to obtain an asset
of similar value to the right-of-use asset in a similar economic environment with similar terms,
security and conditions. In order to determine the incremental borrowing rate, we consider three
main risk premiums adjustments: reference rate, credit risk premium and asset specific adjustment.

- Reference rate (risk free rate): in assessing the relevant reference rate, we factor in the
currency, economic environment and unexpired terms of the leases under review. Relevant
government bond yields have been used as a proxy for the risk-free rate.

- Credit risk premium: we use credit risk to reflect the difference in risk profile between a
government bond and another corporate debt security with the same maturity.

- Asset specific adjustment: we use property yields as a proxy to differentiate between different
property types and locations. Asset specific adjustments are based on property initial yield
benchmarks, taking into account the expected annual rental growth rate and the expected
annual building depreciation rate.


-----

The key factors influencing our discount rate are the economic environment, the length of

the lease, the lessee entity, the type of collateral used and the rent review mechanism used for the
relevant lease.

We have developed a categorization of leases and a matrix of discount rates to reflect these

specific factors. During the year ended December 31, 2020, a number of the Group’s leases were
re-negotiated and have been treated as lease modifications under IFRS 16. A revised discount rate
at the effective date of the modification has been used to re-measure the lease liabilities, with a
corresponding adjustment to the right-of use-asset. The incremental borrowing rate we calculated
as at December 31, 2020 ranges between 2.8% to 9.24% (compared to 2.8% to 9.0% as at
December 31, 2019) translating to an average rate of 7.1% (compared to 6.8% as at December 31,
2019). A 4-basis point fluctuation in the rate would cause the lease liabilities to increase or
decrease by £5.0 million and lead to a corresponding increase or decrease in the right-of-use assets
of £5.1 million. The incremental borrowing rate can change due to the type of leases that are held
by the Group, the economic environment, the lease terms and the underlying asset types.

_Lease terms_

In reviewing the terms of our leases, management considers all facts and circumstances

that create an economic incentive to exercise an extension option, or not to exercise a termination
option. Periods covered by an option to extend are included in the lease term if the lessee is
reasonably certain to exercise such option, and the same rationale applies to termination options.

Significant judgement is required to determine the period over which a lease is considered

to be “enforceable.” When leases have an outstanding term greater than 10 years, we consider
there to be an unclear indication that the lease would in substance be deemed “enforceable” beyond
its original contractual term, despite the rights provided by the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954. In
these situations, we use the lease end date as the reference end date. For leases with an outstanding
term of 10 years or less, the likelihood of extension is assessed up to the year end with reference
to the facts available and looking at the Group’s history of renewing leases beyond their contractual
end date.

For the current leases held by the Group, we have estimated the minimum lease term to be

the term of each relevant lease contract, including revisionary leases in connection with the
COVID-19 pandemic. Each lease is assessed on an individual basis, having regards to our current
plans and expectations, and we decide whether to extend or terminate accordingly.

**_Key assumptions used for assessing goodwill for impairment_**

The Group assesses impairments to goodwill on an annual basis. Goodwill arising in

connection with our acquisition by TDR Capital on November 1, 2013 was tested at the Group
level. Goodwill is generally monitored at the group level because it is considered to be the smallest
relevant cash-generating units for goodwill impairment testing. Goodwill is also recognized in
relation to the acquisition of individual clubs, for which we consider the acquired club as the
relevant cash-generating unit. When testing goodwill for impairment, the Group determines the
recoverable amount by estimating the value in use of the cash-generating units within the Group.
The calculation of value in use requires estimation of future cash flows and a discount rate to


-----

determine the present value. The sensitivity to changes in this assumption are disclosed in note 15
to our consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2020.

**_Key assumptions used for value-in-use calculations_**

The Group tests the carrying amounts of individual club non-current assets for impairment

for clubs that meet pre-defined impairment indicators. For the years ended December 31, 2019 and
2020, the recoverable amount of the cash-generating units was determined based on value-in-use
calculations which require the use of assumptions. The calculations use cash flow projections
based on financial budgets and business plans covering a three-year period approved by
management. Cash flows beyond the three-year period are extrapolated using an estimated growth
rate of 1.8% for the U.K. and Dutch clubs, 1.7% for Spanish clubs and 1.4% for French and Belgian
clubs. These growth rates are consistent with industry- and country-specific forecasts in which
each relevant cash-generating unit operates. The pre-tax discount rates of 10.5% in the U.K. and
11.5% in Spain have been determined based on the weighted average cost of capital. The
sensitivity to changes in assumptions used for value-in-use calculations are disclosed in note 15 to
our consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2020.

**_Judgements in determining the timing of satisfaction of performance obligations under_**

**_IFRS15_**

The timing of satisfaction of performance obligations in respect of administration and

joining fees for members requires judgment. Administration and joining fees represent a fee for
the initial set-up costs of the contract and for the right to renew the membership for no additional
fee when such contract expires. The set-up costs are critical to the contract with the new member,
but they do not satisfy performance obligations, as no good or service is transferred to the member.
The member effectively pays for the future right of renewing their membership for no additional
fee. Because it is only when renewal occurs that the performance obligation is fulfilled, revenue is
released over the full duration of membership, which includes any renewal period. In order to
determine the average duration of a membership and the relevant number of renewals for each
package type, the group considers historical data and trends, as well as the detailed criteria for the
recognition of revenue set out in IFRS 15. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to the closure of the
majority of our clubs during the First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown, as a result of which
no revenue was recognized during this period because no performance obligations were satisfied.
Following the detailed review of our membership base and historic trends, we are satisfied that the
recognition of revenue in accordance with the above method for the current year is appropriate.

**_Control and option valuation_**

On January 30, 2020, DLL Greenwich GmbH purchased the entire issued share capital of

the Meridian Group. On the same date, Deuce TopCo Limited and DLL Greenwich GmbH entered
into an agreement with David Lloyd Leisure Limited pursuant to which David Lloyd Leisure
Limited agreed to provide certain management and operational services and to license its trade
marks to the Meridian Group. In consideration for these services, Deuce Topco Limited granted
David Lloyd Leisure Limited an option to acquire the entire issued share capital of DLL Greenwich
Limited. The option is exercisable at any point from January 30, 2020 to January 30, 2023. In order
to exercise the option, DLL Greenwich Limited would need to obtain consent from its banking


-----

group. Given this requirement and the economic and legal barriers in place, we have concluded
that the Group does not have control over DLL Greenwich Limited until the option is exercised
and have therefore not consolidated DLL Greenwich Limited into our financial results as at
December 31, 2020.

The fair value of the option is derived using option valuation techniques, with key inputs

for the market value of DLL Greenwich Limited, the cost to exercise the option and other key
factors such as market volatility. The key driver of the valuation is the equity value of DLL
Greenwich Limited, which requires significant management judgement due to the fact that this
entity is not publicly listed. Using the purchase price of the Meridian Group and the year-end
enterprise value of the business, we have concluded the value of the option to be £nil.

We operate in the premium segment of the health and fitness club market in the U.K. and

Europe, which is large and presents significant growth opportunities. We believe this market is
structurally attractive, particularly as the world emerges from the COVID-19 pandemic.

**_Overview of the U.K. health and fitness club market_**

The U.K. health and fitness club market was growing before the COVID-19 pandemic. The

total value of the U.K. health and fitness club market increased from £4.3 billion as of December
2015 to £5.1 billion as of December 2019, reflecting a compound annual growth rate (“CAGR”)
of 4.4% (Source: LDC Report). Over this same period, the number of health and fitness clubs in the
U.K. grew from 6,312 to 7,239, reflecting a CAGR of 3.5%, while the number of health and fitness
club members grew from 8.8 million to 10.4 million, reflecting a CAGR of 4.3% (Source: LDC
_Report). As of December 2019, 16% of the U.K. population, or approximately one in six people,_
were a member of a health and fitness club (Source: LDC Report) and 11%, or approximately one
in ten people, were a member of a private health and fitness club (Source: LDC Report).

The 4.3% CAGR in U.K. health and fitness club members from December 2015 to

December 2019 may be primarily attributed to U.K. consumers increasing their focus on health
and wellbeing and expenses related thereto being increasingly perceived as essential rather than
discretionary expenditure (Source: LDC Report). This increased focus on wellbeing is driven by
consumers’ growing awareness of the significant benefits of a healthy lifestyle and stimulates
growth in penetration rates. Modest population growth, increases in consumers’ disposable
incomes and innovation and new technology in fitness have also contributed to the growth of the
U.K. health and fitness club market over the past five years.


-----

The U.K. health and fitness club market is split into two main segments: public clubs and

private clubs. The private clubs segment can be further split into: (i) premium clubs, which is the
segment in which we operate, (ii) mid-market clubs and (iii) low-cost clubs.

The growth of the U.K. health and fitness club market over the past five years has largely

occurred in the low-cost segment and at the expense of the mid-market, with operators in this
segment exiting the market or downsizing their portfolios, as illustrated by the acquisition of LA
Fitness by Pure Gym in 2015. We believe this is a positive trend for us over the long-term as some
of the low-cost members will likely upgrade to the premium segment of the market over time.

**_Private clubs_**

Private clubs are funded and operated by commercial enterprises. The private club market

is significantly larger than the public club market, with approximately 4,510 clubs and 7.0 million
members (Source: LDC Report), equivalent to an average of approximately 1,554 members per
club as of December 2019. On average, private clubs charged monthly membership fees of £41 as
of December 2019 (Source: LDC Report). The number of private clubs increased from 3,550 as of
December 2015 to 4,510 as of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 6.2% (Source: LDC Report).
Over this same period, the number of private club members grew from 5.5 million to 7.0 million,
reflecting a CAGR of 6.5%, while private club revenue has increased from £3.0 billion to £3.7
billion, reflecting a CAGR of 5.6% (Source: LDC Report). The private club market is fragmented,
and the ten largest private club operators only accounted for approximately 25% of the private club
market (by number of gyms) as of December 2019 (Source: LDC Report).

**_Composition of the private health and fitness club market_**

The private club market is split into three primary segments: (i) premium clubs, (ii) mid
market clubs, and (iii) low-cost clubs. We operate in the premium segment, where we are the
largest operator by revenue by a significant margin as compared to the second largest operator in
this market segment, Virgin Active.

Premium clubs are generally larger in size than mid-market and low-cost clubs and usually

contain a wider range of facilities including, for example, wet areas (e.g. swimming pools, spas and
saunas), racquet sports courts (e.g. tennis, squash and padel courts) and social areas for members
(e.g. bars and cafés), in addition to best-in-class gym equipment and exercise classes. Members of
premium clubs are often required to sign up to fixed-duration membership contracts, which
typically include early termination fees.

Premium clubs generally have higher operating costs than mid-market and low-cost clubs

due to their larger size, higher breadth and number of facilities offered and better quality of
equipment, greater number of staff (e.g. onsite sales and marketing teams and fully staffed
reception and refreshment areas) and higher maintenance costs (e.g. cleaning and maintenance of
wet areas and trained instructors across a wide range of facilities). The quality of the clubs is
generally higher than mid-market and low-cost clubs and offers a wider offering, which commands
a correspondingly higher membership fee. Premium clubs generally have a stickier membership
base and lower attrition rates when compared to mid-market and low cost clubs, which is
demonstrated by our pre-pandemic attrition rate of 32.6% for the year ended December 31, 2019,
compared to up to approximately 100% reported by certain low cost operators pre-pandemic
(Source: public information).

Mid-market clubs constitute a middle ground between the premium and low-cost segments.

Their offering includes stationary and cardio equipment, as well as additional facilities that lowcost clubs do not offer such as a pool and spa and membership fees in between those of the lowcost and premium clubs. In the last several years, there has been an increasing bifurcation in the
health and fitness market, with a rise in the number of premium and low-cost clubs and a decrease
in the number of mid-market clubs, as large mid-market players such as L.A. Fitness exited the
market in 2015.

Low-cost clubs sit at the other end of the spectrum. They typically charge lower monthly

membership fees, do not require their members to enter into fixed duration contracts, provide a
smaller range of facilities (typically restricted to gym equipment) and have longer opening hours.
