**Public clubs**

Public clubs are funded and operated by local authorities or county councils. They typically

offer a wide variety of facilities such as sports halls, exercise studios and swimming pools. Some
public clubs are managed or operated by private companies on behalf of local authorities and
county councils. Public clubs are generally open to members of the public on a pay-and-play or
membership basis. As of December 2019, there were 2,729 public clubs with a total of 3.4 million
members in the U.K., equivalent to an average of 1,237 members per club (Source: LDC Report).
On average, public clubs charged monthly membership fees of £30.1 as of December 2019
(Source: LDC Report). The number of public clubs decreased marginally between December 2015
to December 2019 from 2,762 to 2,729, while the number of public club members increased from
3.3 million to 3.4 million, reflecting a CAGR of 0.3% (Source: LDC Report). The revenue
generated by the public club market increased from £1.3 billion to £1.4 billion during the same
period, reflecting a CAGR of 1.5% (Source: LDC Report). The three largest public club operators
in the U.K. (by number of clubs) are Greenwich Leisure Limited, Sports and Leisure Management
Ltd. (trading as Everyone Active) and Places for People Leisure (Source: LDC Report). We believe
that while public clubs compete broadly with the mid-market and low-cost segments, they do not
effectively compete with the premium club segment because their offering lacks ancillary services
comparable to ours as well as trained instructors and digital solutions.

**Overview of the European health and fitness market (including continental Europe and the**
**U.K.)**

The European health and fitness club market was growing before the COVID-19 pandemic.

The total value of the European health and fitness club market increased from €24.6 billion as of
December 2015 to €26.2 billion as of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 1.6% (Source:
_Statista). Over the same period, the number of health and fitness clubs in Europe grew from 51,204_
to 63,644, reflecting a CAGR of 5.6%, while the number of members also grew from 52.4 million
to 64.8 million, reflecting a CAGR of 5.3% (Source: Statista).

**Outlook and impact of Covid-19**

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, governments in the U.K. and in all European

countries in which we operate have implemented strict social distancing measures with varying
degrees of lockdowns and closures of non-essential businesses, including leisure facilities such as
ours. The COVID-19 pandemic presents an unprecedented disruption to the health and fitness
industry, and the wide variations in potential outcomes present a material challenge to our business
and our industry. Due to the closure of clubs, many operators have frozen memberships in order to
retain members and have therefore generated no to very little revenue throughout the lockdown
periods. As a consequence, health and fitness club operators have had to shift attention and resources
to managing their operating expenses and cash balances in order to maintain sufficient liquidity


-----

during the First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown. Operators that have not managed to retain
sufficient capital have experienced significant financial distress or filed for bankruptcy.

Many governments have offered support packages for businesses and employees that are

unable to operate due to the COVID-19 pandemic. As one of the hardest hit, the health and fitness
industry has generally benefitted from extensive government support, including job-retention
schemes, tax deferrals, business rates holidays, loan schemes and other measures. In addition,
many operators have renegotiated their lease agreements or obtained rent reductions and rent
deferrals from their landlords to share the burden of non-operating health and fitness club facilities.
For more information about the risks associated with the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and
our ability to minimize cash burn through government aid, see “Risk factors—Risks relating to our
_business and industry—The COVID-19 pandemic has adversely impacted, and will continue to_
_adversely impact, our business, financial position and results of operations.”_

Recent vaccine approvals have raised hopes of a turnaround in the pandemic and economic

recovery in 2021 in the U.K. and across Europe, and the health and fitness industry is now focused
on reopening and bouncing back. While the COVID-19 pandemic has had a negative impact on
the industry, we believe it will bounce back strongly, as evidenced by the reopening of clubs after
the First Lockdown in 2020. Following the staggered re-opening of facilities at the end of the Second
Lockdown in April 2021, we have seen better than expected attendance, membership sales and enquiries,
thereby providing us with confidence for the year ahead.

We believe the COVID-19 pandemic is shaping trends that will benefit our industry over

the medium-term and reinforcing the importance of a healthy lifestyle. We believe that there will
be a shift to experimental spend by our target demographics, with 35% of people in the U.K. with
no prior gym membership surveyed during April 2020 reporting that they would consider buying
a membership following the uplifting of COVID-19 restrictions, according to research conducted
by UKactive.

In addition, structural changes such as working from home are likely to benefit certain segments

of the industry. According to Barclays’ research, post-pandemic, white collar employees expect
working from home days to increase by 60% (to 1.6 days per week on average), while employers
expect working from home days to double (to 2.0 days per week on average) (Source: Barclays
_Research Work from Home: A Global Revolution Special Report). Working from home may_
provide health and fitness club members with more flexibility in their schedule to attend a club, a
trend which is likely to further reinforce our competitive offering.

**_Recessionary resilience_**

The health and fitness club industry has been historically resilient to recessions and is less

likely to be impacted significantly when compared with other industries, as evidenced during the
last global recession from 2007 to 2009 when the overall U.K. market did not contract (Source:
_LDC Report). In fact, between 2007 and 2010, the U.K. health and fitness market grew by a CAGR_
of 2.2% (Source: LDC Report).

Premium clubs may be even more resilient to recessions because of the demographics of

their membership base, which typically include more affluent members living in suburban areas,
due to their higher average membership costs. Affluent target demographics have a larger income
buffer, which serves to protect their discretionary spend during a recession. Furthermore, higher
earners have historically recovered faster from a recession as compared to other tranches of the
population with a lower level of disposable income.

**Business**

**Overview**

We are the leading premium lifestyle club operator in Europe based on revenue for the year

ended December 31, 2019. On a pro forma run-rate adjusted basis, pre-COVID-19 pandemic, we
had approximately 668 thousand members as of December 31, 2019. As of March 31, 2021 we
operated 99 clubs in the U.K., one club in the Republic of Ireland and 22 clubs in continental
Europe. Our mission is to provide high-quality destinations suitable for the whole family and all
age ranges with an emphasis on the quality of our offering and expert delivery of multiple products
and services, creating a sense of belonging and improving our members’ lives. Our clubs are places
for me-time, together-time, work, rest and play-time under one roof, improving the lives of our
members and providing a home away from home under our “My Club for My Life” ethos.

We differentiate ourselves from our competitors by blending our distinguished social

offerings with our market-leading sports and leisure facilities and fitness offerings, allowing us to
cultivate a loyal and “sticky” membership base. Our club rooms and outdoor spaces encourage
member interaction and provide a social, destination environment where members can relax and
socialize in a vibrant setting. The breadth and quality of our offering allows us to attract and retain
members of all ages, including families and older demographics, whom we believe are more likely
to become long-term members because our clubs become an integral part of their lives. We believe
our distinctive family focus, with programs and services catered to the whole family, enhances
member engagement, promotes membership retention and differentiates us from our competitors.
We believe that we have maintained markedly lower attrition rates than our peers, with a prepandemic attrition rate of 32.6% for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to up to
approximately 100% reported by certain low cost operators pre-pandemic (Source: public
_information), and the average membership tenure for our long-term members (i.e. those who had_
their membership for over 18 months) was seven years and our long-term members represented
63% of our member base, in each case, as of February 29, 2020 (excluding our Meridian clubs).
Based on the aggregate monthly membership fees paid by our long-term members for the month
February 2020, our aggregate implied recurring revenue over the seven year tenure would have
been approximately £1.9 billion. Our total membership subscription revenue, including joining
fees and administration fees, represented 78.2% of our total revenue for the year ended December
31, 2019. Our retail revenue generated by services such as our food and beverage offering,
childcare services and wellness products and our other revenue generated primarily by personal
training sessions and swimming and tennis tuition produce significant ancillary revenue and
represented 10.2% and 11.6%, respectively, of our total revenue in the year ended December 31,
2019.

Our business model focuses on operating a portfolio of strategically located clubs in

suburban areas, with each site situated in close proximity to an affluent demographic population.
Our clubs are well-invested and include heated indoor and outdoor pools, top-class racquet
facilities, well-equipped group exercise studios, state-of-the-art gyms, luxurious spas, crèches,
family-oriented club rooms and outdoor spaces, lounges with restaurants and bars as well as a fully
complementary digital offering, thereby delivering an outstanding customer experience to our
members. In addition, the range and breadth of services offered by our clubs results in longer


-----

customer dwell-time, increased secondary spending, higher market penetration and improved
retention rates compared to our competitors.

While we operate mainly in the U.K., with 99 of our clubs located in the U.K. as of March

31, 2021, we see significant growth potential in Europe. Our recent acquisition of the eight
Meridian Group clubs in Germany has increased our penetration significantly into one of the most
important European markets. We expect to continue to consider additional international sites
through selective, value-enhancing strategic acquisitions of small portfolios as well as standalone
sites in Europe, in line with our overall growth plan. We believe that there are currently no
European competitors of significant scale in the premium health and fitness market segment, which
presents us an opportunity to capture additional market share through organic growth and
opportunistic acquisitions. The map below illustrates the location of our clubs:

For the year ended December 31, 2019, we generated £519.5 million of revenue, a loss of

£51.5 million and £577.4 million of Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue with a Pro Forma Run Rate
Adjusted EBITDA of £170.9 million and Cash Conversion Ratio of 72.9%. We increased _Pro_
_Forma Run Rate Revenue, Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA and actual operating cash at_
a compound annual growth rate (“CAGR”) of 14.8%, 28.0% and 27.2%, respectively, from the
financial year ended January 3, 2016 to December 31, 2019.

**Our strengths**

**_Leading player in structurally attractive and growing U.K. and European health and fitness_**
**_club market with further growth expected post the COVID-19 pandemic_**

We are the leading premium lifestyle club operator in Europe based on revenue for the year

ended December 31, 2019, with 99 clubs in the U.K., one club in the RoI and 22 clubs in
continental Europe. The U.K. and European health and fitness club market in which we operate is
large and growing. We believe that this market is structurally attractive, particularly as the world
emerges from the COVID-19 pandemic. The total value of the U.K. health and fitness club market
increased from £4.3 billion as of December 2015 to £5.1 billion as of December 2019, reflecting
a CAGR of 4.4% (Source: LDC Report). Over this same period, the number of U.K. health and


-----

fitness clubs grew from 6,312 to 7,239, reflecting a CAGR of 3.5%, while the number of health
and fitness club members grew from 8.8 million to 10.4 million, reflecting a CAGR of 4.3%
(Source: LDC Report). As of December 2019, 16% of the U.K. population, or approximately one
in six people, were a member of a health and fitness club (Source: LDC Report) and 11%, or
approximately one in ten people, were a member of a private health and fitness club. The total
value of the European health and fitness club market increased from €24.6 billion as of December
2015 to €26.2 billion as of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 1.6% (Source: Statista). Over
this same period, the number of health and fitness clubs in Europe grew from 51,204 to 63,644,
reflecting a CAGR of 5.6%.

We believe that growth in the U.K. and European health and fitness club market, including

a growth in penetration rates, is largely attributable to the increasing focus of consumers on health
and wellbeing and a growing awareness of the significant benefits of a healthy lifestyle. These
same consumers also increasingly view health and fitness as an essential rather than discretionary
expenditure. Modest population growth, increases in consumers’ disposable incomes and
innovation and new technology in fitness may also have driven growth of the U.K. and European
health and fitness club markets over the past five years. We anticipate that demand for health and
fitness clubs will accelerate post-pandemic as the COVID-19 pandemic has reinforced the benefits
of a healthy lifestyle.

We believe the COVID-19 pandemic is shaping trends that will benefit our industry over

the mid-term. With more people working from home, our members have greater flexibility to
spend more time at our clubs, which are predominantly located in suburban areas. According to
Barclays’ research, post-pandemic, white collar employees in the U.K. expect working from home
days to increase by 60% (to 1.6 days per week on average), while employers in the U.K. expect
working from home days to double (to 2.0 days per week on average) (Source: Barclays Research
_Work from Home: A Global Revolution Special Report). We believe that this trend is further_
supported by a long-term shift to experiential spend by our target demographics, with 35% of
people in the U.K. with no prior gym membership surveyed during April 2020 reporting that they
would consider buying a membership following the uplifting of COVID-19 restrictions, according
to research conducted by UKactive.

Our expectations for growth in the U.K. and European health and fitness club market post
pandemic present an opportunity for our business. As a result of market growth and recent healthfocused trends, we anticipate more members being able to join and spend time at our clubs.

**_A broad and highly differentiated offering that makes us more than just a gym which is_**
**_unmatched by any scale competitor_**

We offer our members a distinguished selection of facilities and services which we believe

are unrivalled in breadth and quality. In particular, we differentiate ourselves from our competitors
by blending our social and wellness offerings with our market-leading sports and fitness facilities,
thus cultivating a loyal and “sticky” membership base.


-----

_Our social offering_

Our “clubiness” is a key to driving our social offering. We want our members to feel they

belong to their club rather than visiting solely for exercise and our vibrant club rooms and social
outdoor spaces are a key component of our offering which provide members with a destination
environment where they can relax and interact with each other. We pride ourselves upon our local,
and often member self-started, societies among our clubs, which build loyal communities centered
around common interests and create a distinctive “clubs with clubs” culture. We also organize
various bespoke social events to drive member engagement and retention, all of which are tailored
to meet the specific needs of our members. In addition, several of our training options, such as
tennis leagues and running and triathlon clubs, feature a strong social element to encourage
participation via group coaching and friendly competitions. Most of our clubs have lounges with
a restaurant service and licensed bar, which represents our largest source of ancillary revenue
(47.5% of ancillary revenue (including retail and other revenue) in the year ended December 31,
2019). Many of our outdoor pool areas also have a barbecue or other food and beverage service,
thereby creating a destination area in the summer months. We regularly update our menus in
response to member feedback to maximize the appeal of our food and beverage offering and stay
in touch with our customers’ preferences.

Our clubs are open to all ages and have a distinctive family focus, with families and couples

representing approximately two thirds of our membership base as of March 31, 2021, leading our
clubs to become an integral part of the families’ lives. We believe that this offering enhances
member engagement, promotes membership retention and differentiates us from our competitors.
We believe, based on management estimates, that we are one of the largest U.K. child activity
providers, as we offer extensive facilities for children (who represented approximately a quarter
of our members as of March 31, 2021). These include daycare, crèches, structured activity
programs, kids play-frames, child-friendly tablets, dedicated splash pools and family friendly areas
such as soft play and DL Kids activity areas, family lounges and family changing rooms, with an
average of approximately 500 family classes every week and 38,500 kids enrolled in the swimming
and tennis lessons of our All Stars programs for children aged 3–11 during the year ended
December 31, 2019.

More recently, we have further expanded our social offering by introducing quiet spaces

within our clubs to allow members to work directly from our premises. Our dedicated adult-only
business lounges have been designed so that members are given sufficient flexibility to take
advantage of our facilities while tending to their professional duties, in line with the recent
working-from-home trend spurred on as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. As an increasing
number of our members are choosing or needing to work from home, we seek to facilitate the
transition to a comfortable and reliable remote working environment by offering on-site spaces to
work from, thereby further strengthening our “clubiness.” As of March 31, 2021, all of our clubs
offered large and spacious lounges with complimentary WiFi access. In addition, we offer
dedicated adult-only lounges and business hubs in a select number of clubs.

_Our sports, fitness and wellness offering_

We believe we are one of the market leaders in privately-owned sports facilities in the U.K.

Our racquets, swimming and sports facilities are some of the highest quality in the market and are


-----

accompanied by leading professional coaches. As of March 31, 2021, we operated 117 squash
courts and, based on management estimates, we operated approximately 36% of all indoor tennis
courts in the U.K. Further, as of March 31, 2021, we operated 196 indoor and outdoor pools across
the U.K. Our innovative group exercise programs, extensive studio facilities and state-of-the-art
gyms complement the full suite of our offering, helping us meet the varied needs of our members.
We believe group exercise is a significant driver of member retention, and have capitalized on this
trend by offering weekly 18,800 adult classes across all our clubs in the year ended December 31,
2019. We also offer extensive high-quality gym facilities, with an average of 120 pieces of gym
equipment per club as of March 31, 2021.

Our holistic approach to health includes what we believe to be market-leading wellness

offerings, which includes relaxing spa facilities, dedicated mind and body studios and a healthy
and nutritious menu. As of March 31, 2021, approximately 99% of our clubs included saunas,
steam rooms and jacuzzies. During the year ended December 31, 2019, we hosted approximately
2,500 mind and body classes every week. A select number of our U.K. clubs now include Spa
Retreats, which provides members with a high-end, luxurious wellness experience.

Lastly, we are cognizant of the preference of some of our members to exercise from home,

and have bolstered our digital offering in order to keep our members engaged and connected during
the First Lockdown and the Second Lockdown. Our @home app is the flagship of our digital
offering and offers our members a weekly timetable of fitness classes and interactive events and
an extensive library of on-demand classes and tailored workout plans, all of which are designed
by our professional staff. The @home app also benefits from the integrated services of ancillary
service providers such as Boditrax and Myzone, which further reinforce our digital ecosystem. As
of March 31, 2021, our @home app had over 1,500 pieces of content, which were viewed 8.2
million times and used by approximately half of our members during the First Lockdown and the
Second Lockdown.

_No scale competitors with comparable offerings_

We offer a wide breadth of services and facilities that traditional gym groups and country

clubs do not match on a comparable scale, which reinforces our competitive advantage. Our
comprehensive club offering includes gyms, exercise and spinning studios, group exercise classes,
indoor and outdoor pools, saunas, steam rooms, jacuzzies, crèches, tennis courts with a range of
surface types, treatment rooms and squash courts. By contrast, most private clubs are only able to
provide a subset of our offering. For example, as of March 31, 2021, while 100% of our clubs had
dance studios, group exercise classes and indoor pools, private clubs that include those services
only amounted to 60%, 52% and 35%, respectively (according to management estimates). As of
March 31, 2021, approximately 99% of our clubs included saunas, steam rooms and jacuzzies,
while only 48%, 38% and 30% of private clubs included those same facilities, respectively
(according to management estimates). Moreover, while as of March 31, 2021, 90% of our clubs
included a crèche, 83% included a tennis offering and 73% included an outdoor pool, only 8%,
3% and 4% of private clubs featured those same services (according to management estimates).

We believe that our varied offering, including our outdoor facilities, tennis courts,

swimming pools, spas, restaurants, crèches and both live and on-demand workouts with our
@home app, allows us to stand out competitively within the premium segment of the market, and

that there are no scale competitors with a comparable offerings. The breadth of our offering as

**_Our scale and well-invested and strategically located club offering is difficult to replicate_**

_Catchment areas_

We believe that new entrants to the premium segment of the health and fitness club market

would experience difficulties in attempting to disrupt our strong presence and member base, both
in the U.K. and Europe. This is because significant capital, time, know-how and available land are
required to locate and develop a site that can be operated profitably. An attractive catchment area
is crucial for our clubs to be successful. As of March 31, 2021, according to management estimates,
there were only 39 target catchments in the U.K. that we had identified as suitable for the
development of a profitable club where we do not yet have a presence. The below charts illustrate
our current incumbency in the U.K. and the limited number of attractive target catchments where
we are not present:

David Lloyd’s incumbency Available sites


-----

Developing a profitable club requires finding a sufficiently affluent catchment area.

Against this background, we have a well-invested portfolio of premium locations throughout the
majority of affluent catchment areas in the U.K, which we believe are located in prime locations
and easily accessible by most of the population. As of March 31, 2021, based on management
estimates, 91% of our current members lived within a 20 minute drive of our clubs.

In addition, the significant capital requirements, time and know-how required to develop a

site, once located, present a significant investment cost to any new entrant. Our sites, from the
purchase of land to the fit-out of the club, cost approximately £13 million on average to develop.
To achieve a scale comparable to that of David Lloyd, we estimate that a potential new entrant
would need to invest over £1.5 billion over a significant period of time and with high execution
risk, while also having to source considerable know-how and devote a significant amount of time
to each site development project. We estimate that the full process from the initial scope (including
planning permission, detailed design, construction and fit out) to the opening of a site (including
membership ramp-up to the maturity of the site) would take a competitor six to seven years to
complete for each new club.

While our operations are primarily concentrated in the U.K., we also cover some of the

most affluent areas in some of Europe’s most important markets. Our European clubs in Italy,

in some of Europe’s most affluent markets by Affluence Mix, as illustrated by the below chart:

We have substantially increased our market share in key European markets and we

currently have a presence in countries that represent more than 72% of the entire European market
(Source: Statista, 2020). We also have plans for further selective expansion via value-enhancing
strategic acquisitions. For example, our recent acquisition of eight clubs in Germany has increased
our penetration significantly into one of the most important European markets.
