**_Consistent delivery of growth and strong cashflow generation_**

Our rapid topline growth, underpinned by new member sales and price increases and

combined with a disciplined approach towards cost control, allows us to drive substantial cash
generation. We were operating at all-time highs in revenue, Adjusted EBITDA and operating cash
flow prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, with strong underlying performance driven by multiple
levers. In particular, our membership subscriptions revenue grew at a CAGR of 12.4% between
the financial year ended January 3, 2016 and the year ended December 31, 2019.

Between the financial year ended January 3, 2016 and the year ended December 31, 2019,

our total revenue increased from £330 million to £520 million (£413 million on a like-for-like
basis), representing a 12.0% increase in CAGR (5.8% on a like-for-like basis), our EBITDA
increased from £65 million to £135 (£108 million on a like-for-like basis), representing a 19.9%
increase in CAGR (13.3% on a like-for-like basis) and our operating cash increased from £38
million to £99 million, representing a 27.3% increase in CAGR, in each case as illustrated by the
charts below:

Our impressive earnings growth and margin expansion prior to the COVID-19 pandemic,

which we believe will resume following the staggered reopening of our facilities at the end of the
Second Lockdown, is supported by a well-controlled cost base. We have also implemented new
cost saving initiatives. Our Fit For Growth Program implemented in December 2020 is expected
to yield approximately £10 million of annual labor cost savings from 2021 onwards compared to
our labor costs for the year ended December 31, 2019, following a full review of club structures,
duty manager shifts and benchmarking of departmental hours as well as an increased focus on
digital solutions to optimize our staff and overhead costs. However, while management’s


-----

disciplined approach towards cost control has made our substantial revenue growth visible at
Adjusted EBITDA level, with our staff costs, overheads, club support and rent costs growing at a
CAGR substantively below our revenue CAGR between the financial year ended January 3, 2016
and the year ended December 31, 2019, our primary focus remains on delivering a best in-class
service and outstanding customer experience for our members. Therefore, while cost discipline
remains important, it does not take precedence over delivering a high-quality experience for our
members.

**_Industry leading management team_**

Our management team has a deep wealth of experience and talent. Their track-record of proven
success places us in a position to expand upon our robust market position. Our Executive
Chairman, Glenn Earlam, joined us from Merlin Entertainments (formerly Tussauds), where he
was Managing Director of Midway Attractions. Mr. Earlam was responsible for a successful
cultural change at Tussauds and led the global rollout of Midway Attractions. Under Mr. Earlam’s
leadership, we have been focusing on a number of operational initiatives aimed at improving our
customer service delivery, lowering customer attrition and bolstering brand awareness. While at
Merlin Entertainments, Mr. Earlam worked with our Chief Executive Officer, Russel Barnes for
over 20 years. Mr. Barnes brings considerable transformation and rollout experience to the team.
Another key member of our team, Patrick Burrows joined us as Chief Financial Officer from
London City Airport where he oversaw the £2.4 billion sale of the business. Prior to London City
Airport, Mr. Burrows worked at New Look and Tesco. The current management team expanded
our footprint through strategic value-enhancing acquisitions and organic growth, including the
acquisition of 14 Virgin Active clubs in 2017 and the acquisition of eight Meridian clubs in
Germany, growing our number of clubs from 94 clubs in 2016 to 122 in 2021. Our team is rounded
out by a dedicated group of directors with over 60 years of tenure between them.

**Our strategy**

The core of our strategy is to continue to deliver sustainable, profitable growth by focusing

on creating a premium experience for our club members. With our well-invested estate and wide
product offering, we put our members at the heart of our proposition, enabling us to deliver yield
and growth. Through reinvesting our profits into our existing estate to deliver an ever-improving
member experience, we create a virtuous circle that is proven and sustainable, as illustrated by the
chart below:


-----

**_Listening to members_**

We want our members to feel like David Lloyd is their club. We have a sophisticated,

comprehensive and targeted member communications program in place, covering the duration of
a member’s lifetime with us to encourage a high level of engagement and to allow us to understand
the desires of our members. We emphasize the quality of our offering and expert delivery of
multiple products and services, and we focus on member engagement and a tailored
communication strategy in order to stay in touch with our members frequently and effectively. We
ask our members for feedback on a regular basis, with an average of approximately 15 thousand
pieces of feedback received weekly through feedback stations in our clubs and push notifications
received through our @home app after each member visit. In addition, we track our members’ club
visits and directly reach out to them when we notice a drop in attendance, which allows us to assess
each member’s particular needs, offer bespoke programs, demonstrate our strong commitment to
member satisfaction and altogether rekindle engagement. We believe that this model allows us to
closely stay in touch with our members’ needs and foster a unique sense of belonging within our
clubs.

**_Improving our product offering_**

Our members have a keen view on value for money. Our track-record has proven that our

members are generally willing to pay membership fees at a premium provided that the quality of
our product offering and their experience justifies this cost. We leverage the feedback and insights
received from our members by investing heavily in our clubs to deliver a premium and
differentiated product proposition. For example, we rolled out our Spa Retreats and grew the
number of Blaze studios across our estate based on membership feedback. Our facilities include
heated indoor and outdoor pools, top class racquet facilities, well-equipped group exercise studios,
luxurious spas, family-oriented club rooms and outdoor spaces, lounges with restaurants and bars,
high-quality gyms as well as a fully complementary digital offering. The success of our product
initiatives is evidenced by the increasing quality scores our facilities have received from members
based on our internal surveys, with the quality of our facilities being endorsed by 92% of our
members in 2019 compared to 73% in 2015.

**_Enhancing the quality of the service that we provide to our members_**

We focus on enhancing the quality of the services we provide to our members by ensuring

that our clubs are staffed with great personnel who are motivated and engaged with the business.
Accordingly, we will continue to select our staff carefully and invest in their training to deliver
consistent, high-quality service to our members. Every new staff member receives formal training
during which they learn about our clubs and our culture and receive bespoke training in customer
service to ensure they are capable of delivering the premium experience our members expect. We
also have ongoing training for our staff covering health and safety protocols, as well as an online
training academy from which all employees can access a variety of courses, including child
safeguarding and a wide range of technical training. Our personal trainers and coaches are selected
in accordance with strict standards in order to ensure that they can deliver up-to-date advice on
training, fitness, nutrition and lifestyle changes to our members. In recognition of the pivotal role
our employees play in executing our strategy and delivering premium member services, we pay
the majority of our staff at levels above minimum wage and provide them with a comprehensive


-----

benefits package, including a club membership that allows them to use our facilities and gain a
first-hand understanding of our members’ needs. Based on regular employee surveys, employee
engagement improved from 80.0% in 2015 to 94.4% in 2019. We also consistently rank on the
Sunday Times’ Top 25 Best Companies to work for in the U.K. list.

**_Increasing member satisfaction_**

The combination of our high-quality facilities and outstanding customer services allows us

to maintain and increase our members’ satisfaction, leading to our members becoming advocates
for our business, with our Net Promoter Score increasing from 22.0 in 2015 to 57.2 in 2019,
according to our own survey. We intend to deploy a number of new initiatives in order to keep our
members engaged and maintain consistently high satisfaction levels. Since the start of the COVID19 pandemic, we have deployed an extensive digital and social media strategy that enhances our
members’ experience and exploits the power of digital commerce. For instance, both our website
and @home app allow online booking of group classes, and we continue to focus on delivering
fully complementary digital solutions to our members. Our strategy to increase member
satisfaction also hinges on our “clubiness,” as we believe that members value our clubs as a place
to socialize in a family-friendly setting. We will continue to put the social scene at the core of our
offering by organizing a wide spectrum of social events at our clubs and ensuring that our
members’ needs are always taken into consideration.

**_Growing our membership base_**

Our strong and experienced sales team will continue to sell our high-quality offering which

is synonymous with the significant recognition of the “David Lloyd” brand in the markets in which
we operate. In order to increase our membership base, our sales process is organized to encourage
potential members to visit our clubs and experience the full range of our facilities and services,
rather than choosing a club based on price alone. Our sales and marketing activities are also
benefiting from our increasing focus on digitalization and the rollout of our @home app. In order
to cater for situations where prospective members are unwilling or unable to visit our clubs before
purchasing a membership, we now offer a digital joining process, which has generated
approximately £11 million in revenue from its inception to April 2021. We view digital and social
media as an important new channel of communication with prospective members, and this vision
has been further strengthened by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Our social media
presence enables us to tailor our communications to each individual member based on factors such
as demographics and usage patterns, thereby enhancing the relevance of our member
communications and increasing each member’s engagement with their club. We will continue to
advertise our offering through a broad range of media platforms in the U.K., both nationally and
locally, including television, radio as well as all major social media platforms.

Our sales and marketing efforts have successfully increased our membership base at a

CAGR of 8.5% from 452 thousand as of 2015 to 626 thousand as of 2019 and at a CAGR of 2.5%
from 449 thousand as of 2015 to 496 thousand as of 2019 (on a like-for-like basis). Our
membership growth was achieved thanks to consistent net member gains during the same period,
with an average of 37.4 thousand net new members added each year between 2015 and 2019. In
addition, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, we had identified approximately ten of our clubs that
were approaching their maximum capacity, which indicates ample room for further growth of our


-----

like-for-like membership base. The charts below illustrate the growth of our total membership
base, net new members and average yield:

**_Confidently pricing membership fees_**

We will continue to collect feedback from our members and measure members’ satisfaction

with the quality and availability of our product offering and the prices paid for membership. Our
pricing strategy reflects our understanding, based on feedback, that our members are willing to
pay premium prices for a premium offering as members have acknowledged our investments in
our clubs and accepted price increases linked with improved quality and availability of our product
offerings and customer service. We generally announce price increases to our existing members
highlighting and reflecting investments that improve the facilities in their clubs. We
simultaneously update the membership fees for new members of the relevant clubs to reflect the
improvements at those clubs. Since 2016, we have delivered annual yield growth in excess of
annual retail price index (“RPI”) increases while continuously growing our membership base. In
addition, if based on certain capacity indicators, we identify clubs that are reaching their maximum
level of utilization, we implement price increases to manage the utilization levels at those clubs,
which allows us to generate further yield and EBITDA growth. For example, prior to the COVID19 pandemic, we had identified a small number of our clubs with limited excess parking or class
booking availability at peak times, and implemented price increases as demand for those clubs
exceeded availability. We intend to maintain our successful pricing strategy in order to continue
to deliver accretive and sustainable profit growth while continuing to increase our membership
base.

**_Reinvesting our growing profits_**

Enabled by our strong cash conversion, we will continue to reinvest our growing profits

into our estate in order to modernize, refurbish and expand our portfolio and thereby further
improve our product offering and enhance the quality of our services, which in turn drives
members’ satisfaction and yield growth, which can then be reinvested, creating a virtuous circle
that is proven and sustainable and which constitutes the basis of our strategy.

As our members value the quality of their clubs, we will continue to refresh and improve

our facilities with the latest, highest-quality offering and equipment. Capital expenditures are an
essential part of our strategy, and we have invested approximately £284 million into refurbishing
and transforming our clubs over the last six years. By October 2020, we had rolled out Spa Retreats
at a select number of clubs located in our most affluent catchment areas, which provide members
with a high-end, luxurious wellness experience and deliver significant uplift in club Adjusted


-----

EBITDAR. For example, we invested £3.6 million in the rollout of the Spa Retreat in our Royal
Berkshire club in the first half of 2019 and achieved a 31% return on investment with an increase
of £1.1 million in club Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended February 29, 2020 (based
on the club Adjusted EBITDAR for the eleven-month period April 2019 to February 2020, runrated for a twelve-month period), compared to the club Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months
ended prior to the investment of the capital expenditure. We have also been developing our free
weight capacity, adding more Olympic platforms on our gym floors and increasing the space in
our studios, and plan on bolstering our offering of onsite self-administered health products such as
cholesterol and DNA tests while also adding massage and stretching rooms to our clubs, offering
members a more bespoke fitness experience.

Historically, returns on Investment Capital Expenditure have been strong. Phase 1 of our

investment plan was completed in 2014 and comprised a £22.1 million investment into 18 clubs,
an average of £1.2 million per club. Phase 2 was completed in 2015 and comprised a £18.8 million
investment into 18 clubs, with an average of £1 million per club. Phase 3 was completed in 2016
and comprised a £32.4 million investment into 41 clubs, with an average of £800,000 per club. We
achieved a 43% return on investment from phase 1 with an increase of £9.5 million in club
Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017, a 42% return on investment from
phase 2 with an increase of £7.9 million in club Adjusted EBITDAR for twelve months ended June
30, 2017 and a 48% return on investment from phase 3 with an increase of £15.5 million in club
Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended June 30, 2018, in each case compared to the club
Adjusted EBITDAR for the twelve months ended prior to the investment of the capital expenditure.

**_Expanding our footprint in the U.K. and in Europe via selective value-enhancing strategic_**
**_acquisitions_**

We have implemented a successful acquisition strategy since Glenn Earlam joined the

Group in 2015, pursuing value-enhancing investments which have granted us access to new
catchment areas and increased our membership base. We proactively manage our club portfolio
by pursuing value-enhancing strategic acquisitions of small portfolios as well as standalone sites
in Europe, in line with our overall growth plan.

Prospective acquisitions are consistently assessed according to strict investment criteria, as

we look for a demonstrated ability to deliver returns both on a standalone and an aggregate basis.
We seek locations in a catchment area that has a significant affluent target population within a 20
minute drive, ideally without a competing club in the catchment area. A detailed demographic
analysis of the catchment area allows us to calculate a potential membership number for the site
to determine maximum club size and potential profitability. We then produce a detailed model for
each new site, using assumptions based on local catchment area characteristics and similar clubs
from our existing portfolio. Our approach enables us to determine the layout, mix of facilities,
membership categories and pricing characteristics of each club on an individual basis.

Our value accretive greenfield expansions are generally assessed on a single site basis,

given the factors associated in finding a suitable catchment area for a premium club. The
economics of sale and leaseback transactions allow us to maximize our return on our Pipeline
Capital Expenditure spend on greenfield expansions by combining a one-off profit on the sale of
the freehold of the club, with EBITDA generation by the club during our leasehold period. For


-----

example, we spent approximately £13 million in Pipeline Capital Expenditure to develop our
Emersons Green club in 2018 and 2019, which was expected to generate a mature EBITDA of
£2.6 million per year, and in December 2020, we sold the site for a net consideration of £21.1
million, representing an immediate profit of approximately £8.1 million. Simultaneous with the
sale, we agreed with the buyer to lease the club for an annual rent cost of £1.1 million, generating
a mature club EBITDA of £1.5 million per year. We will endeavour to use cash on balance sheet
or a prudent mixture of equity and debt to finance any future acquisitions. In addition, we will
continue to use complex data-analytics to assess new opportunities, which has been a key to our
well-proven record of both successful acquisitions and organic openings.

While our operations are currently primarily concentrated in the U.K., we expect to consider
further international sites via selective, value-enhancing strategic acquisitions of small portfolios
as well as standalone sites in Europe, in line with our overall growth plan. In particular, we see
significant growth potential in our current offerings in Europe, having already identified
approximately 700 potential development sites across the continent. Our European clubs
represent a differentiated proposition in several European markets with affluent demographics
and we believe there are no competitors of scale in the premium segment of the health and
fitness market. Our recent acquisition of eight clubs in Germany has significantly increased our
penetration into one of the most important European markets. This acquisition also provides a
blueprint for further strategic and selective European expansion into markets with high
membership growth potentials and low penetration rates.

**History**

We were founded in 1982 by David Lloyd, former captain of the British Davis Cup tennis

team, who recognized that the U.K. had very few indoor sport and leisure facilities and sought to
create high-quality fitness destinations suitable for the whole family. Our first club was opened in
Heston, West London, and is still operating and open as of the date of this Offering Memorandum.
By 1991, we had grown to five domestic clubs, including our first acquisition in Eastbourne, on
England’s southeast coast. Following our initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange in
1993, we were subsequently acquired by British leisure operator Whitbread in 1995, at which point
we totaled 18 clubs in the U.K.

After eight years of steady domestic growth, our international expansion began in 2003

with the acquisition of five Cannon health clubs in The Netherlands, allowing us to reach a total
of 57 clubs, followed by club openings in Barcelona and Brussels in 2005. In 2007, we were
acquired by London & Regional and the private equity arm of HBOS (now Caird Capital).
Following this acquisition, our existing business was merged with 19 Next Generation clubs, and
our former CEO Scott Lloyd oversaw the successful integration of a total of 88 clubs in the U.K.
and Europe to extract synergies and implement best practice across the entire portfolio.

In 2013, we were purchased by TDR Capital, who believed in our potential to grow by

investing capital across the existing estate, expanding into new geographies and significantly
enhancing our customer proposition through a series of operational improvement initiatives. Under
TDR Capital’s ownership, we have undertaken and completed a major capital investment program,
making significant improvements in the style and range of facilities available to members across


-----

our estate, and also expanded our footprint via selective, value-enhancing strategic acquisitions of
small portfolios as well as standalone sites in the U.K. and Europe.

In 2015, Glenn Earlam joined David Lloyd as CEO. In addition to our refurbishment

program, Glenn has also focused on a number of operational initiatives aimed at improving our
customer service delivery, lowering customer attrition and bolstering brand awareness. In the same
year, we launched a new site development program, which led to the opening of 11 new clubs,
including five in Europe (Antwerp, Madrid, Milan, Geneva and Frankfurt).

In 2017, we acquired 14 racquet clubs from Virgin Active in the U.K. and also opened four

individual new clubs. In 2020, we increased our European portfolio from 14 to 22 clubs by
purchasing eight clubs from Meridian Spa & Fitness in Germany, thereby establishing a growth
platform for our most important European target market. In the same year, we also purchased a
country club in the affluent, high-potential Bellevue suburb of Geneva.

While we continue to execute an accretive capital expenditure program across the acquired

estate, we also remain focused on our product offerings, with the launch of our “@home” mobile
app in March 2020 and the use of digital touch points in our clubs as part of our increased focus
on digital offerings. Our @home app reinforces our offer and generates large, easily convertible
standalone digital opportunities that maximize the utility of our membership and allows us to keep
pace with new socioeconomic trends spurred on by the COVID-19 pandemic. See “—Overview of
_our offering—Digital offering.”_

**Our clubs**

As of March 31, 2021, we had a total of 122 clubs, 99 of which were in the U.K., one in

the RoI, two in Belgium, six in The Netherlands, nine in Germany, one in France, one in
Switzerland, one in Italy and two in Spain, and approximately 580 thousand members. On a pro
_forma run-rate adjusted basis, pre-COVID-19 pandemic, we had approximately 668 thousand_
members as of December 31, 2019.

Our business model focuses on operating a portfolio of appropriately located clubs, with

each site located in close proximity to an affluent demographic population, ideally with no similar
competition in the catchment area. All of our clubs are well-invested, to justify premium pricing,
and we have long-term concessions of 25 years or more on the majority of our portfolio in order
to minimize rental expense and maximize operational flexibility. We emphasize the quality of our
offering and expert delivery of multiple products and services, and we focus on member
engagement and a tailored communication strategy in order to stay in touch with our members
frequently and effectively. We believe that this model results in higher margins and increased
secondary revenue, high cash generation and visibility of earnings, significant member retention,
high brand awareness and correspondingly lower marketing spend per new member.

**_Overview of our offering_**

Our facilities include state-of-the-art gyms, heated indoor and outdoor pools, top-class

racquet facilities, well-equipped group exercise studios, luxurious spas, family-oriented club
rooms and outdoor spaces, lounges with restaurants and bars as well as a fully complementary
digital offering. Our clubs are open seven days a week, usually from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. on weekdays


-----

and from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on weekends. We believe that our family friendly environment, together
with the range and breadth of our facilities, results in longer customer dwell-time, increased
secondary spending, higher market penetration and improved retention rates. Our highly
differentiated offering relies on six core pillars: “clubiness”; family; wellness; sports; fitness and
digital offering.

_Clubiness_

Our club rooms and outdoor spaces encourage member interaction and provide a social,

destination environment where members can relax and socialize in a vibrant setting. We pride
ourselves upon our local and often member self-started societies among our clubs, which build
loyal communities centered around common interests and create a distinctive “clubs with clubs”
culture. This culture encourages the sense of community and belonging that being part of a club
can generate, as evidenced by our “We Time” ethos.

We also organize a wide spectrum of social events such as music themed nights, quiz

evenings and barbecues to drive member engagement and retention, all of which are always
tailored to meet our local members’ needs. In addition, a number of our training options, such as
tennis leagues and running and triathlon clubs, feature a strong social element to encourage
participation via group coaching and friendly competitions.

Most of our clubs have lounges with restaurant service and licensed bar, which represents

our largest source of ancillary revenue (47.5% of ancillary revenue (including retail and other
revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2019). We offer a variety of menu and pricing options
based on club demographics and size, including vegetarian and vegan options as well as a
condensed menu for smaller clubs. Many of our outdoor pool areas also have a barbecue or other
food and beverage service, thereby creating a destination area in the summer months. We regularly
update our menus in response to member feedback to maximize the appeal of our food and
beverage offering. We have introduced our DLicious range of healthy food in our clubs, with a
focus on speed, quality and service. Our chefs and nutritionists, working together with our health
and fitness teams, have created a healthy, balanced menu using natural ingredients, which helps
our members enjoy the benefits of healthy eating. Most recently, we have enhanced our offering
with a deli-style grab-and-go offering in partnership with the Yo-Sushi brand, as well as barista
service and freshly prepared smoothies.

More recently, we have been focusing on offering our members quiet spaces within our

clubs to allow them to work directly from our premises. Our dedicated adult-only business lounges
have been designed so that members are given sufficient flexibility to take advantage of our health
and fitness facilities while tending to their professional duties, in line with the recent workingfrom-home trend spurred on as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. As an increasing number of
our members are choosing or needing to work from home, we seek to facilitate the transition to a
comfortable, reliable remote working environment by offering on-site spaces to work from,
thereby further strengthening our “clubiness.” As of March 31, 2021, all of our clubs offered large
and spacious lounges with complimentary WiFi access. In addition, we offer dedicated adult-only
lounges and business hubs in a select number of clubs.


-----

_Family_

Our clubs are open to all ages and have a distinctive family focus, which we believe

enhances member engagement, promotes membership retention and differentiates us from our
competitors. Our distinctive family offering is evidenced by the fact that as of March 31, 2021,
approximately two thirds of our members were families and couples, leading our clubs to become
an integral part of the families’ lives.

We believe, based on management estimates, that we are one of the largest U.K. child

activity providers as we offer extensive facilities for children (who represented approximately a
quarter of our members as of March 31, 2021), including daycare, crèches, structured activity
programs with approximately five thousand kids lessons offered across a broad range of
disciplines, kids play-frames, child-friendly tablets, dedicated splash pools and family friendly
areas such as soft play and DL Kids activity areas, family lounges and family changing rooms. We
provide birthday parties for children (which also serve as marketing events for potential new
members) as well as other family events, including parties at Christmas, Halloween and Easter,
and designated family swimming times in our pools. The broad range of facilities and activities
that we offer makes our clubs an ideal destination for families to spend time together after school,
on the weekends and during school holidays.

As of March 31, 2021, all of our clubs offered child daycare facilities, with daycare hours

coordinated with our exercise class timetable. We also have a wide variety of children’s tennis and
swimming classes through our All Stars programs for children aged 3–11, with up to 40 lessons
per week on offer. Our All Stars programs focus on developing major motor skills, improving
fitness levels and social interaction while having fun. Our children’s programs operate 48 weeks
of the year, thereby maximizing member participation and engagement outside of the school term
timetable and creating a “resort-like,” year-long experience.

The DL Kids Holiday Club is available during school holidays to children aged 5–13 on a

daily or weekly basis. It offers structured programs tailored to specific age groups, including sports
sessions, fun swimming, arts and craft activities, theatre, as well as lunch and breaks during the
day. We have also developed a Fitness-Into-Teens (FIT) program for children aged 10 and above.
It is designed for “aspiring adults” and includes group exercise, gym, swimming and tennis
activities to encourage fitness and a healthy lifestyle in a social environment. Children at our clubs
also benefit from 4G pitches, all of which complement our extensive outdoor facilities and thereby
encourage dwell-time for the entire family.

As the population continues to age, we are also committed to offering bespoke services to

older people. As of March 31, 2021, 18.5% of our membership base was over the age of 55.
Inspired by UKactive’s Reimagining Ageing report, we have recently committed to having one
fitness trainer aged 55 or over per club on average by the end of 2022.

_Wellness_

Our clubs feature mind and body studios that allow our members to find peace of mind

through yoga, meditation and tai chi classes. In addition, our high-quality wet spa facilities provide
a holistic health and wellness offering for members, offering a relaxation space for adults only,


-----

including jacuzzi, sauna and steam facilities. We also offer a range of treatments, including
aromatherapy, massage, acupuncture and beauty treatments. Many of our clubs offer
physiotherapy and physical rehabilitation services with qualified physiotherapists.

In addition, our members also enjoy access to dedicated mind and beauty studios and can

visit the Spa Retreat at a select number of our U.K. clubs. Our Spa Retreat is the flagship of our
wellness offering, providing members with a high-end, luxurious experience with heat treatment
rooms, salt saunas, heated beds and sound meditation pods. The Spa Retreats facilities span both
indoors and outdoors, with dedicated spa gardens segregated into adult-only areas reaching up to
2000 sq ft. The high-end design of our Spa Retreat has started to trickle down to our smaller clubs,
with an increasing number of wellness facilities being developed in these locations too.

Lastly, in order to complement our wellness offering, many of our clubs offer additional

services, such as nutritional educational programs, hairdressers, barbers, beauty care and various
on-demand tutorials. These services are often offered in the form of “pop-up” stands on our
premises, which are operated via concessions.

_Sports_

Our clubs provide members with a wide range of premium racquet sports and swimming

facilities and offer tuition from leading professional coaches.

The majority of our clubs offer a range of tennis, squash, badminton and/or padel courts,

in addition to our traditional health and fitness facilities. A key driver of our racquet offering is the
fact that our clubs are typically located in affluent areas, with an average penetration of our target
demographic groups in the club’s catchment area of approximately 1.8% across the U.K., and
penetration of up to 4% in some clubs. As of March 31, 2021, we had more than 1,050 matchquality tennis courts (more than half of which are indoors), as well as 365 squash and badminton
courts. The strength of our racquet sports offering is exemplified by the high occupancy rate of
our courts, which can be as high as 87.4% during the winter months.

Our leading junior tennis coaching program offers tennis lessons to up to 15 thousand

children each year. Children with a competitive spirit can join our squad program to train at a
higher frequency within smaller groups and play against neighboring teams on weekends. In
addition, we also offer structured programs for adults, coaching and leagues to encourage member
participation, frequency of visits and longer dwell-time, which in turn drives secondary spending
by our members and improves retention. Our members enjoy access to SmartCourts in a select
number of clubs, a state-of-the-art technology which uses advanced image processing and
analytical algorithms to capture and log stroke type, ball trajectory, speed and spin, in-depth shot
data and player movement. Our clubs are also home to vibrant communities of tennis-lovers, with
competitions, group coaching sessions, league tables and social events enhancing our “clubiness”
and contributing to our competitive offer. As such, we believe that our extensive racquet facilities
differentiate us from the rest of the market and represent a significant advantage over our
competitors. As of March 31, 2021, 88.9% of our clubs in the U.K. offered racquet sports facilities,
we operated 117 squash courts and, based on management estimates, we operated approximately
36% of the indoor tennis courts in the U.K. private sector.


-----

We also have an extensive swimming program, with 196 indoor and outdoor swimming

pools across the U.K as of March 31, 2021. Our pools are suitable for both intensive training and
leisure, while shallow, splash pools at most clubs and trained lifeguards on constant watch further
reinforce our family offering. Our cutting-edge facilities allow us to foster communities of
swimming enthusiasts in our clubs, thereby further contributing to the success of our “clubs with
_clubs” culture. As of March 31, 2021, we had more than 700 qualified swimming teachers and up_
to 24 thousand children learn to swim with David Lloyd All Stars each year (starting at age 18-36
months), all of which are operative across the entire year thanks to our heated indoor pools. Our
clubs also offer swimming squads for children, in line with our tennis program. As of March 31,
2021, we operated approximately 25% of the lidos in the U.K. private sector.

_Fitness_

Gym facilities

All of our clubs offer extensive health and fitness facilities. Our gym facilities combine

free weights areas, functional training zones with Plyo boxes, sled tracks, Synrgy 360 training
frames and TRX straps, and a wide array of low-impact cardio equipment and weight machines.
Our facilities are consistently refreshed and kitted out with the latest, highest-quality equipment,
and currently include state-of-the-art Life Fitness machines with interactive screens, Woodway
treadmills, Concept 2 rowers, Wattbikes, SkiErgs, Assault bikes and stages solo bikes with ondemand group content, among others. We seek the best pieces of kit from individual suppliers
instead of using the same ones for various categories of equipment, which allows us to benefit
from a low supplier concentration risk and maintain a consistently high standard for our services.

Most recently, we have been developing our free weight capacity by increasing the number

of Olympic platforms on our gym floors, and have also bolstered our offering of onsite selfadministered health products such as cholesterol and DNA tests, all of which offer members a
more bespoke fitness experience. While we try to maximize the availability of fitness equipment
(approximately 120 pieces per club on average), we are also cognizant of the need for more spacedout facilities. As such, we have made a conscious effort to offer our members a larger personal
space within which to exercise, and also added massage and stretching rooms to our gyms.

Group exercise

Group exercise is a key member retention driver of our business. We pride ourselves upon

offering members content that is entirely unique, as we produce and create our own music and
fitness videos, and also train our instructors to deliver bespoke “signature” classes that can only
be attended at our clubs. We offer a large number and wide variety of fitness classes, including
our Blaze and Ignite high intensity interval training, Spirit yoga and Pilates classes, the Cyclone
and Rhythm cycling classes as well as general strength and conditioning circuit sessions. In order
to maintain the appeal of our clubs, protect our members and employees and mitigate the health
risks posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, we strive, to the extent possible, to offer group classes in
an outdoor setting. The majority of our classes are now offered on an individual basis too. Members
can book a particular piece of gym equipment or training area in advance, and then follow an
online recording of the class they wish to follow alone, using their headphones, which affords them


-----

extra flexibility in their fitness journey. During the year ended December 31, 2019, approximately
25% of our members participated in group exercise.

Our extensive group exercise offering has been developed to match the level of expertise

that boutique-style gyms offer in a particular area across a much broader range, thereby offering a
“one stop shop” with the highest level of services. According to our management estimates,
customers are on average 60% less likely to leave if they enroll in group classes. Lastly, group
classes can also generate significant ancillary revenue, with approximately £2.1 million worth of
gym accessories such as boxing gloves and heart rate systems having been sold during the year
ended December 31, 2019.

Personal trainers

As of March 31, 2021, we had more than 600 qualified personal trainers who deliver

approximately 700 thousand sessions per year to help our members achieve their health and fitness
goals and seamlessly navigate across our facilities. We believe that our extensive personal training
program increases member engagement and reduces membership turnover. Personal training
represented our second largest source of ancillary revenue (18.5% of ancillary revenue (including
retail and other revenue) in the year ended December 31, 2019), and has been one of the largest
drivers of overall ancillary revenue growth over the past four years, with a compound annual
growth rate of 6.8% from 2015 to 2019.

All of our personal trainers hold at least a Register of Exercise Professionals (REP) Level

3 qualification and undergo in-house training at our David Lloyd Campus to ensure they can give
consistent, up-to-date advice on training, fitness, nutrition and lifestyle changes, and also uphold
social distancing protocols. Our personal trainers are trained to use massage guns on our members,
and place as much emphasis on the recovery process as they do on training.

Following the First Lockdown, we have revisited our personal training program by offering

shorter sessions at lower prices. We also put in place group personal training sessions for groups
of up to 8 people for more price-sensitive members and those less familiar with personal training,
which foster comradery and further stabilizes our “sticky” membership base. We are adapting
certain of our clubs to better accommodate personal training sessions, with more open space and
non-traditional resistance equipment, such as TRX straps and kettle bells. Thanks to the large size
of our facilities, we have been able to swiftly adapt to new safety protocols imposed in connection
with the COVID-19 pandemic, allowing our personal trainers to maintain steady activity levels
following the reopening of our facilities.

_Digital offering_

On March 23, 2020, we were one of the first U.K. fitness, health and leisure operators to

offer a remote exercise platform through the launch of our “@home” mobile app. @home offers
our members a weekly timetable of fitness classes and interactive events and an extensive library
of on-demand classes and tailored workout plans, all of which are designed by our professional
staff. In addition, @home allows prospective members to buy membership without in-club
support, thereby shortening the inquiry to conversion process and reducing drop-offs, while
existing members can also digitally book and purchase group classes and personal training. The


-----

videos posted on @home have recorded over 2 million views from 275 thousand unique users
from its launch to March 31, 2021, with members using the app not only for our signature fitness
classes, but also for social events such as cooking classes, quiz nights and make up tutorials.

The success of our new digital solutions is exemplified by the connected bike trail launched

during the Second Lockdown with our Milton Keynes members, which was oversubscribed. We
intend to invest more resources into similar events in the future, as we believe that bike rentals can
provide an alternative source of revenue when members are unable to physically attend classes.
Between July and October 2020, we estimate that 15,000 additional classes were made available
and 45,000 additional bookings were generated thanks to our @home app. In addition to our
@home app, we have also recently started rolling out our @table app, which allows members to
place restaurant orders from their mobile devices, thereby limiting physical exposure to staff and
enhancing safety in our newly reopened clubs.

Overall, our unique digital ecosystem reinforces our offer and generates large, easily

convertible standalone digital opportunities that maximize the utility of our membership. We
deploy medical-grade body composition monitoring devices across our facilities in order to allow
our members to accurately track their progress. Our investment in technology through digital touch
points is coupled with partnerships with ancillary service providers tailored to our local members’
needs, such as Boditrax and Myzone, whose services are integrated into @home.

**_Membership base_**

We offer a variety of membership options to provide our members with the greatest degree

of flexibility. Prospective and current members can deal with all aspects of the subscription process
both onsite at one of our clubs, or digitally via our @home app. We offer two principal types of
membership duration:

- Standard: 12-month initial term for a particular club, terminable on three months’ notice
thereafter; and

- Flexible: a three-month initial term for a particular club, terminable on one month’s notice
thereafter.

Given the premium nature of our offering, our membership is also heavily weighted towards

the most affluent members of society, with 58% of member households earning over £60,000 per
annum compared to the U.K. national average of 18% as of December 31, 2019.

Within each contract type, we have different categories which vary depending on the

facilities used and the time of such use. For instance, the “Club Membership” allows members, at
a lower price, to use their club at off–peak times during the day without access to certain facilities.
We also offer special rates for couples, families, children and corporate members as well as twoweek trial periods in April, August and December. Our individual adult membership fees range
from £44 to £325 per month, depending on the location, facility and type of club. From time to
time, we make promotional offers available for specified periods (e.g., “Join now and pay no


-----

joining fee”). Membership fees are generally payable monthly by direct debit or annually with an
upfront payment.

We focus on attracting and retaining a wide range of members. We have relatively large

bases of older demographics and families, who have markedly lower attrition rates than single,
younger members. This sticky membership base is resilient and allows us to generate significant
recurring subscription revenue, which in the year ended December 31, 2019, represented 78.2%
of our total revenue for that year.

As of December 31, 2019, children and individuals aged at least 50 comprised half of our

membership base, as illustrated below:

We engender a high degree of loyalty from established members, with individuals who

have been members for over 18 months remaining members for an average of seven years, thereby
generating a robust and recurring membership stream which underpins our business model.

**_International_**

We have 22 clubs outside the U.K. and RoI and expect to consider further international

growth via selective, value-enhancing strategic acquisitions of small portfolios as well as
standalone sites in Europe, in line with our overall growth plan. Our European clubs accounted for
18.4% of our Pro Forma Run Rate Revenue and 18.6% of our Pro Forma Run Rate Adjusted
EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019.

_Germany_

We have nine clubs in Germany, located in Homburg, Frankfurt, Berlin and Kiel. Our

German clubs offer a mix of racquet and health and fitness facilities, as well as large-scale saunas
and steam rooms, physiotherapy, sunbeds, child daycare and indoor and outdoor swimming pools.
Our clubs in Germany range in size from 24,972 sq ft to 63,776 sq ft, with membership size ranging
from 2,052 to 6,776 members. Eight of our nine German clubs were acquired from Meridian Spa
& Fitness in Germany in 2020, which has allowed us to establish a growth platform for our most
important European target market.

_The Netherlands_

Our six clubs in the Netherlands are located in Amsterdam, Capelle aan den Ijssel,

Eindhoven, Rotterdam and Utrecht. Our Dutch clubs offer a mix of racquet and health and fitness
facilities, as well as saunas and steam rooms, physiotherapy, sunbeds and child daycare and indoor


-----

pools. Our clubs in the Netherlands range in size from 35,686 sq ft to 101,712 sq ft, with
membership size ranging from 2,920 to 4,493 members. We have implemented a number of
operational changes and improvements in our clubs in the Netherlands, which have helped to
counteract the effects of a weak economy and heightened competition.

_Belgium_

We have two clubs in Belgium.

- Brussels: our club in Brussels is located in a former chateau in an affluent suburb south of
Brussels. The club has been extensively refurbished, and includes five indoor and six outdoor
tennis courts, a relaxation area including a lounge, two saunas, a steam room and a jacuzzi as
well as a bar and restaurant, hair and beauty salon, child daycare and nursery and indoor and
outdoor pools. It is 98,938 sq ft in size and had 6,879 members as of March 2021.

- Antwerp: our club in Antwerp opened its doors in 2015 and is located just off Prins
Boudewijnlaan road, a stone’s throw from Zandbergen Park. The Antwerp club features two
swimming pools, four indoor tennis courts, four outdoor tennis courts and high-end gym
equipment and relaxation facilities. The club size is 56,179 sq ft and had 3,096 members as of
March 2021.

_Spain_

We have two clubs in Spain.

- Barcelona: we acquired our club in Barcelona in 2003. Though it was originally a traditional
tennis club, we have expanded it to offer our full range of services. Located at the end of
Avenida Diagonal, it is convenient to public transportation and the University of Barcelona.
The club’s facilities include 12 tennis courts, 12 padel courts, multiple indoor, outdoor and
children’s pools, a function suite, a café, a restaurant and a spa. The club size is 58,205 sq ft
and had 4,110 members as of March 2021.

- Madrid: we acquired our club in Madrid in 2015. Located in the Valdemarin area of Aravaca,
a short drive from Madrid city center, our Madrid club features two pools, outdoor tennis
courts, three exercise studios and state-of-the-art child care and coaching facilities. The club
size is 53,596 sq ft and had 3,165 members as of March 2021.

_Ireland_

Our club in Ireland is located in the affluent Clonskeagh area of Dublin. In addition to its

extensive gym facilities, the club offers 13 tennis courts (ten indoor and three outdoor), two squash
courts, two swimming pools (one indoor and one outdoor) and a spa with sauna, steam room and
whirlpool. Leisure facilities include a DLicious café, a TV lounge, a hair and beauty salon and
function suite. For children, the club offers daycare and three kids rooms. The club is 138,504 sq
ft in size and had 5,952 members as of March 2021.


-----

_France_

Our club in France is located on the French side of the Franco-Swiss border, by Lake

Geneva. The club offers a mix of premium facilities including 15 tennis courts, three padel
courts and one full -size football pitch, among others. The club size is 117,420 sq ft and it had
2,691 members as of March 2021.

_Italy_

Our club in Italy opened in 2017 following an extensive investment program. Located on

the east side of Milan, the club is a strong fit within our family-focused brand and is ideally situated
to serve a large and active membership. Our Malaspina club is a large, well-established and familyfriendly center offering a vast range of health and fitness facilities, including an Olympic-size
swimming pool, 15 tennis courts and three padel courts, one full -size football pitch, gym facilities,
a luxurious spa and an exclusive cafébar, all of which are spread across a beautiful six hectare
parkland site. The club size is 58,587 sq ft and had 2,691 members as of March 2021.

_Switzerland_

Our club in Switzerland was acquired in September 2020 on a freehold basis. It is a

premium sports and wellness club located on the outskirts of Geneva, offering 11 tennis courts, a
fitness space, a golf driving range and a major spa area. The club size is 57,000 sq ft and it had
1,250 members as of March 2021.

**_New Club Development_**

We have opened five new clubs since December 2017 (excluding Meridian), two of which

were in the U.K. Our Acton Park club opened in 2018, following a £9 million investment program.
The Acton Park club includes a wide range of family facilities for children, including tennis and
swimming coaching programs, kids clubs and holiday camps, a crèche and indoor soft play area,
several cutting-edge fitness facilities, including its PRAMA, Blaze and group cycling studios, both
an indoor and outdoor swimming pool, a luxurious wet spa and an exclusive new restaurant. As of
March 31, 2021, it had 5,237 members. In 2019, we opened our 99[th] U.K. club at Emersons Green,
Bristol. Our Emersons Green club offers four group exercise studios, an indoor spa, an outdoor
heated swimming pool, three air bubble tennis courts, a cafébar and our standard high-end child
care facilities. In addition to opening new clubs, we also invest considerable resources into
refurbishing our existing clubs in order to maintain our competitive advantage, with our
Cambridge, Chigwell and Warrington clubs all having undergone multi-million pound makeovers
in 2019. More recently, our clubs in Northwood and Cheadle were refitted during the First
Lockdown and now feature a Spa Retreat (for more information on our wellness offering and Spa
Retreats, see “—Overview of our offering—Wellness”).

We continually evaluate potential new clubs and properties to add to our portfolio, using

complex data-analytics to assess both internal growth via organic openings as well as external
growth by way of value-enhancing strategic acquisitions. In each case, we consider new sites on
an individual basis, subject to a demonstrated ability to deliver returns both on a standalone and
an aggregate basis. We seek locations in a catchment area that has a significant affluent target
population within a 20 minute drive, ideally without a competing club in the catchment area. A


-----

detailed demographic analysis of the catchment area allows us to calculate a potential membership
number for the site to determine maximum club size and potential profitability. We then produce
a detailed model for each new site, using assumptions based on local catchment area characteristics
and similar clubs from our existing portfolio. This approach enables us to determine the layout,
mix of facilities, membership categories and pricing characteristics of each club on an individual
basis. If our model indicates a sufficient level of profitability, a detailed business case is presented
for board approval, following which we enter into the relevant legal documentation and obtain any
necessary planning or other approvals. The use of data-analytics to conduct due diligence on
potential new clubs and properties is the key to our well-proven record of both successful
acquisitions and greenfield openings.

It typically takes approximately two years to develop a new club, from the time the site is

identified to opening. Once opened, clubs can take up to four years before achieving their target
member base and up to four years to achieve their target profitability. Given their large footprint,
the availability of sites of sufficient size can be an impediment to the development of new clubs
and the identification of suitable targets. Notwithstanding, we currently have identified a number
of U.K. sites with potential for new club developments in the next two years.

Applying our advanced data-analytics to the European market, we currently see potential

for approximately 700 potential sites across Europe. We believe that there are currently no
European competitors of significant scale in the premium health and fitness market segment, which
presents us an opportunity to capture additional market share through organic growth and
opportunistic acquisitions. In order to achieve our expansion plans in Europe, we also engage in
the acquisition and redevelopment of existing clubs, targeting cities such as Madrid, Barcelona,
Brussels, Antwerp, Milan and Geneva. In addition to an adequate catchment area population, our
criteria for these redevelopments include a minimum site area and gross internal area, as well as a
minimum number of car parking spaces.

**Competition**

Competition in the health, fitness and leisure market in the U.K. is fierce and principally

on a local basis. Because of the breadth of our offering across racquet sports, swimming pools, spa
and wellness and high-quality gym facilities, we have a wide spectrum of competitors, including
private racquet clubs, hotels, tennis facilities, as well as a broad range of clubs in the health and
fitness sector ranging from other premium clubs to middle market, low cost gyms and boutique
gym studios such as Barry’s Bootcamp and SoulCycle. We also experience competition from
public gyms and leisure centers, and alternative leisure facilities such as golf clubs and active
holiday locations. In terms of our children’s facilities, we compete with youth football and rugby
leagues, kids camps and family holiday locations such as CenterParcs.

Among private multi-site health and fitness clubs in the U.K., we believe that our principal

competitors are Virgin Active, which also operates in the premium segment and which has the
broadest tennis facilities among our competitors, and Nuffield Health, Bannatynes and Fitness
First in the mid-market segment. We compete principally on the basis of facilities and experience
offered, family friendliness and breadth of services. We believe that we do not have any direct
scale competitors within the premium segment of the health and fitness market.


-----

**Sales and marketing**

Our sales and marketing activities are targeted at both new member acquisition and existing

member retention. We advertise through a broad range of media platforms in the U.K., both
nationally and locally, including television and radio as well as various internet platforms. As a
result, we benefit from high brand awareness as a premium health and fitness club, with an 86%
brand recognition in the U.K. as of March 31, 2020, according to a recent study. Our sales process
is organized to encourage potential members to visit our clubs and experience the full range of our
facilities and services, rather than choosing a club based on price alone. Marketing and product
development is organized centrally at our head office and implemented through our club network,
with marketing tactics tailored to the catchment area of each club. Sales teams are located at each
club and each club has specific targets to increase membership through new sales and retention.

We have a sophisticated, comprehensive and targeted member communications program

in place, covering the duration of a member’s lifetime with us to encourage a high level of
engagement. All members receive the benefits of a bespoke welcome program pursuant to which
their individual needs are assessed to ensure the highest possible engagement. Holders of a flexible
three-month membership are offered to upgrade to a 12-month membership, and we run a program
of e-mail communications for low or flexible users to encourage use, based on detailed member
use records and an analysis within our leaver propensity model. We have also developed a
sophisticated algorithm from our extensive database of member behavior that allows us to target
members at risk of leaving, so that we may encourage them to increase their usage and engagement
with their club in order to postpone or prevent attrition.

We have developed a digital and social media strategy to enhance our members’ experience

and exploit the power of digital commerce. Our website attracts both prospective and current
members and is optimized for display on mobile devices. In addition, our mobile app allows
members to view club timetables, access a club finder, see news and events, trainer profiles and
video and photo guides, and check in each time they visit their club. Both our website and app
allow online booking of group classes and tennis courts. We are also present on all major social
media platforms, including Facebook, Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. Our social media presence
enables us to tailor our communications to each individual member based on factors such as
demographics and usage patterns, thereby enhancing the relevance of our member
communications and increasing each member’s engagement with their club. During the First
Lockdown and the Second Lockdown, we leveraged our strong social medial platform to engage
with and support our club members by publishing videos on the topics of mental health and
wellness. Our sales and marketing activities are directly benefiting from our increasing focus on
digitalization and the rollout of our @home app, with digital joining generating approximately £11
million in revenue from its inception to April 2021. We view digital and social media as an
important new channel of communication with our members, and this vision has been further
strengthened by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. See “—Overview of our offering—Digital
_offering.”_

Our sales and marketing strategies are organized by our Marketing Director, who work in

conjunction with our Sales Director and Club Operations management team. Our Sales Director is
supported by Regional Sales managers who have dotted line access to Club Sales Managers. Each
club has a Sales Manager and a team of Sales Consultants. All new sales staff undergo a three to


-----

four week in-club induction, followed by a sales and marketing course. They are then given weekly
coaching sessions and attend a Sales Excellence course after four to six months. See “—
_Employees—Training.”_

**Property**

Our head office is located at The Hangar, Hatfield Business Park, Hatfield, Hertfordshire

AL10 9AX. Our clubs generally fall into three categories: freehold clubs, which are owned
freeholds in relation to which we could initiate a sale and leaseback process, long leasehold clubs,
which are leaseholds running for at least 50 years, and short leasehold clubs, which are leaseholds
with market rent running for less than 50 years. In addition, we also hold purchase call options on
our clubs in Geneva and Malaspina, which are currently held on leaseholds. As of the year ended
December 31, 2019, none of our clubs accounted for more than 2.2% of our total revenue. Based
on a third-party valuation as of December 31, 2017, the total value of our real estate portfolio was
approximately £700 million.

The majority of our clubs are held via long-term concessions, which allows us to minimize

rental expense and maximize operational flexibility. As of March 31, 2021, 53 of our leasehold
clubs (or 44.9% of our total leaseholds) had an unexpired term of 50 years or more, 34 (or 28.8%
of our total leaseholds) had an unexpired term of 25 to 50 years, 17 (or 14.4% of our total
leaseholds) had an unexpired term of 15 to 25 years, 11 (or 9.3% of our total leaseholds) had an
unexpired term of 5 to 15 years and 3 (or 2.5% of our total leaseholds) had an unexpired term of
less than 5 years.

All of our leasehold clubs with an unexpired term of less than 50 years are leased under

standard fully insuring and repairing operating leases. Of our clubs under operating leases, 49 are
leased from M&G, 15 are leased from London & Regional, with the remainder leased from various
other parties. Our M&G leases may only be forfeited in limited circumstances, which exclude
forfeiture for insolvency or change of control. The terms of the operating leases for our clubs have
expiry dates between 2022 and 2041. All of the leases are subject to rent reviews, which vary on
a club-by-club basis. While some have five year market value reviews, others are linked to the
retail price index and others still provide for fixed annual rent increases. The majority of our short
leases in the U.K. and our M&G long leases are subject to annual rent increases.

ft), Antwerp (56,179 sq ft), Geneva Country Club (57,000 sq ft) and Aravaca (53,596 sq ft).

**Environmental matters**

We are subject to a variety of national and local environmental laws and regulations

relating to land use, environmental protection and health and safety in connection with our
ownership of real property and other operations. While we could incur costs, such as clean-up
costs, fines and third-party claims for property damage or personal injury as a result of violations
of or liabilities under such laws or regulations, we believe that we substantially comply with the
applicable requirements of such laws and regulations and have implemented a continuous program
of reporting against a comprehensive set of internal controls. These laws and regulations are
constantly changing, however, as are the priorities of those who enforce them. We cannot assure
you that environmental conditions relating to any of our prior, existing or future properties will
not have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. See
“Risk factors―Risks relating to the regulatory environment―We could be subject to material
_fines and claims related to health and safety risks at our clubs.”_

We have also undertaken a number of initiatives to reduce the environmental impact of our

clubs. These include reducing flow rates in changing room showers and improving the efficiency
of pool and filter cleaning to reduce water consumption, and installing energy efficient lighting
and combined heat and power generators to optimize electricity usage.

**Intellectual property**

We rely on trademark and copyright laws, confidentiality provisions and contractual

provisions to protect our intellectual proprietary rights. We regard our intellectual property as a
valuable asset in the marketing of our products. We market our products and services under various
trademarks, including “David Lloyd,” “DL,” “DL Kids,” “DL cafébar,” “Amida Spa,” “Life Be
Fit for It,” “Harbour Club,” “The Clubroom,” “Blaze,” “Rhythm,” and “Battlebox.” Where we
believe it to be appropriate, we have registered these and related trademarks and the other
trademarks that we use in our business. We currently have no patents or patent applications
pending. Although we actively take steps to protect our intellectual property rights when and where
we deem appropriate, we cannot assure you that such steps will be sufficient. See “Risk
_factors―Risks relating to our business and industry―Our intellectual property rights, including_
_trademarks and trade names, may be infringed, misappropriated or challenged by others.”_

**Information technology**

Our business depends on the ability of our employees to process transactions on secure

information systems and on our capacity to store, retrieve, process and manage information. We


-----

outsource most of our IT infrastructure needs through a variety of third-party suppliers. BT Global
Services provides our data center and disaster recovery facilities and Gamma provides hybrid SDWAN facilities. We continually review the suitability and performance of our IT applications and
are planning to upgrade or replace a number of legacy systems over the next three years.

Our principal front-office system is Club Centric, which, along with our other information

technology, supports a number of key functions:

    - Membership management, including member type, multi-club access, monthly
billings and renewals;

    - Front desk management, including check-in, bookings, waiting lists, subscription and
other payments, and printing photo membership cards;

    - Court, class and treatment timetables and bookings;

    - Point of sale payments for the front desk, retail spaces and food and beverage
services; and

    - Sales and marketing, including managing prospects, demographic reporting,
membership and package renewal reporting and free trial reporting.

IT also forms a core part of our sales and marketing strategy, and we use our website and

@home app to attract new members, increase member engagement and facilitate use of our clubs
and services, thereby driving member retention. Our increased focus on our digital capabilities as
a result of the COVID-19 pandemic has helped us unlock new sources of value by lowering our
costs of delivery and offering members more access to tailored content. We cannot guarantee you
that we will be able to protect these processes and systems against unexpected adverse events. See
“Risk factors―Risks relating to our business and industry― Disruptions and failures involving
_our information technology systems could adversely affect member enrolment, member services_
_and financial and administrative functions.”_

**Insurance**

We maintain insurance cover for the risks associated with the operations of our business,

including property reinstatement, business interruption (other than in relation to the COVID-19
pandemic), material damage, public, product and employee liability, terrorism, cyber, travel and
motor, directors and officers and engineering. We utilize a recognized insurance broker firm,
Willis Towers Watson, to advise on all insurance matters and run our annual renewal process
where cover and deductibles are reviewed from first principles each year. All our policies are
underwritten by reputable insurance providers. Although we believe that our insurance coverage
is sufficient for the risks associated with our operations, we cannot guarantee that no losses will
be incurred or that no claims will be filed against us which go beyond the type and scope of the
existing insurance coverage, and we do not insure against biological, nuclear or terrorism risks.
See “Risk factors―Risks relating to our business and industry―We may be unable to maintain
_the required level of insurance cover on acceptable terms or at an acceptable cost.”_


-----

**Regulatory matters**

Our operations are subject to governmental regulation concerning, among other things,

consumer and data protection, the advertisement, promotion and sale of our products and services
(including membership contract terms), product safety, the health, safety and working conditions
of our staff and employees (in particular in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic), the safety
of our clubs and their accessibility for the disabled, food and beverage regulations and our
competitive conduct in the marketplace. We believe that we are in compliance in all material
respects with these regulations. We cannot assure you, however, that any future changes in the
requirements or mode of enforcement of these laws and regulations will not have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. See “Risk
_factors―Risks relating to the regulatory environment―We could be subject to material fines and_
_claims related to health and safety risks at our clubs.”_

**Legal proceedings**

We are involved in legal, regulatory, tax and administrative proceedings arising in the

ordinary course of our business. The proceedings initiated against us may include, among others,
the following categories of claims: claims by or on behalf of customers on grounds such as breach
of health and safety regulations (in particular as a result of the new protocols imposed in connection
with the COVID-19 pandemic), personal injury, child care, food contamination, privacy and
unauthorized access or intellectual property claims; claims by landlords and suppliers; claims by
employees; claims by tax authorities with respect to tax matters such as VAT, transfer taxes and
property tax; and claims by other administrative bodies or agencies such as claims for breach of
data protection or consumer protection regulations.

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we are not aware of any legal, administrative,

judicial, regulatory, tax or arbitral proceedings or investigations (including any pending or
threatened proceedings or investigations) that are likely to have, or have had, individually or in the
aggregate, a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, financial condition or results of
operations. The outcome of legal proceedings and investigations, however, can be extremely
difficult to predict with certainty, and we can offer no assurances in this regard. As of March 31,
2021, we had recognized reserves of £0.8 million in respect of pending litigation matters. On April
21, 2018, a child drowned in one of the swimming pools at our Leeds club. On February 15, 2020,
Wakefield Coroner’s Court ruled that the death was the result of an accident, and that David Lloyd
was not criminally liable for it. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we expect Leeds
City Council to press further charges against us, but no action has been initiated yet and we
therefore cannot assess our likelihood of success in the event of further litigation.

thousand in 2018 and 2019 and £25.3 thousand in 2020.

In addition, during the year ended December 31, 2019, we had 5,483 persons working at

our clubs on a self-employed basis, including certain tennis instructors, swimming instructors and
personal trainers, and whose compensation is not included in our labor costs. The number of those
working on a self-employed basis fluctuates in order to meet demand.

None of our employees are members of unions. We believe that our relations with our

employees are good and have not experienced any significant labor disputes or work stoppages.

**_Training_**

The quality of our staff is a key factor in driving new member sales, customer engagement

and membership retention. Accordingly, we invest heavily in training our employees to deliver
consistent, high-quality service to our members. Every new staff member receives formal training
typically lasting three months during which they learn about our business and our clubs, and
receive bespoke training in customer service and applicable technical skills. We also have specific
training based on the employee’s role. For example, all sales staff receive an intensive week-long
training program at the David Lloyd Leisure Campuses at our clubs in Dudley and Heston, during
which they are trained in our sales processes and techniques to ensure consistency, integrity and
efficacy. We also have ongoing training for our staff covering matters such as health and safety
and customer service, and assist eligible employees in obtaining a National Vocational
Qualification or other professional qualifications. Training is delivered both by employees who
are involved in training our staff on a full-time basis and internal professional trainers who deliver
training in addition to their day-to-day roles. We also have an online training academy from which
all employees can access a variety of courses, including child safeguarding, anti-bribery legislation
and a wide range of technical training.


-----

**_Health and safety_**

Health and safety are paramount to the operation of our clubs. As part of our training

process, particular emphasis is placed on safety and health protocols. Following the reopening of
our clubs after the First Lockdown and the staggered reopening of our facilities after the Second
Lockdown, our staff completed dedicated COVID-19 workshops in order to ensure compliance
with the latest safety protocols, while also increasing the number of our trained cleaning staff,
introducing the use of fully virucidal disinfectant cleaner and sanitization stations as well as
spacing out group classes to allow for a more thorough cleaning process between sessions. We
also closely follow government guidelines in each country in which we operate and directly work
in tandem with UKactive, a U.K.-based not-for-profit body overseeing the health and fitness
industry, in order to ensure strict compliance with industry standards. Since the end of the First
Lockdown, we have reduced the overall capacity of our clubs, increased space between individual
pieces of equipment on gym floors, introduced one-way circulation system across our facilities
and also introduced plastic screen at our reception desks to protect members and staff as well as
signage and clear floor markings across our facilities. Lastly, our trained lifeguards and instructors
constantly patrol our gym, racquet and swimming facilities in order to monitor and prevent onsite
accidents.

**_Pensions and benefits_**

We do not operate a defined benefit pension scheme. All our employees are currently

eligible to participate in a Group Personal Pension Plan established by us but to which we do not
contribute. In addition, we also operate a “NEST” scheme to comply with regulations introduced
by the UK Pensions Regulator to encourage all employees to contribute to a pension plan. Both
employers and employees are required to contribute to this scheme, which is operated on an optout basis. We do not pay for insurance or private healthcare for our employees but make such
cover available to our staff through a flexible benefits scheme. Outside of the U.K., we follow
domestic regulations in each of the jurisdiction into which we operate and offer pensions and
benefits in accordance therewith, for instance with a pension plan offered to general managers only
in the Netherlands.

**_ESG and others_**

In line with our members’ growing concern for our business’ impact on the environment,

we constantly strive to improve our environmental performance. We are one of the few recipients
in the leisure sector of the prestigious Carbon Trust Double Standard, in recognition of our efforts
to reduce energy consumption and waste, and also the first company in the U.K. leisure sector to
be granted a self-supply water license. We measure our carbon footprint per member visit and rely
on data insight, operational best practice across our clubs and investment into new utility reduction
technologies to ensure compliance with applicable environmental norms. For the year ended
December 31, 2019, we emitted approximately 113.3 thousand carbon tonnes (consisting of 68%
of gas, transport, refrigerant and fuel emissions, 19% of purchased goods, construction and
refurbishment, waste, water and travel emissions and 13% of electricity emissions), and we are
committed to reducing our overall carbon emissions to net zero by 2030. We have a proven trackrecord of successfully implementing utility-related initiatives to decrease our carbon footprint,
having invested approximately £8 million of capital expenditures into well-established


-----

technologies since 2018, such as LED upgrades to our tennis court lighting, building management
systems and other improvements to our heating and cooling infrastructure. These initiatives have
allowed us to decrease our carbon footprint by 7.7% between 2017 and 2018, and to reduce our
emissions by a further 3.5 thousand tonnes during 2019. Since 2019, we have also committed to
purchasing electricity from renewable sources, allowing us to decrease our carbon emissions by
10 thousand tonnes in 2019 and 2020, and also expect the photovoltaic panels installed at our
Luton site in October 2020 to generate over 20% of this club’s electricity requirements and to
reduce our carbon emissions by 50 tonnes per annum.
